prompt: Say, you bought your Saturn at 13k, with a dealer profit of 2k. If the dealer profit is 1000, then you would only be paying 12k for the same car. So isn't that saving money? Moreover, if Saturn really does reduce the dealer profit margin by 1000, then their cars will be even better deals.
text:
Say, you bought your Saturn at 13k, with a dealer profit of 2k. If the dealer profit is 1000, then you would only be paying 12k for the same car. So isn't that saving money? Moreover, if Saturn really does reduce the dealer profit margin by 1000, then their cars will be even better deals.

The dealer's profit margins are not the only thing that can be reduced by Saturn. The dealer can also be forced to sell the car at a lower price. This is called a "dealer discount". If you buy a car from a dealership, and the dealership discounts the price by 10%, then the total cost of the vehicle is now only $10k less than it would have been if the dealers had sold the Saturn for $13k at the original price, but the discount is only 10%.
...
,
This is a very simple example, so let's look at it in more detail. Suppose you have a Saturn S-10. You buy it from the local dealer for 13,000. Now suppose that the new dealer sells it for 15,500. That's a $1,250 profit. But the old dealer is still selling it at $12,750. In other words, the profit on the S10 is $750, not $1000. Saturn is not a good deal for you. It's not even a great deal. And it's even worse for your dealer. He's selling the best deal he can get. Why? Because he's forced by the law of supply and demand to lower the prices of his cars. prompt: Are you serious? The auto that had a lot to do with bringing the term boxer to the popular forefront was the Ferrari 512 Berlinetta Boxer or the 512BB. Had a 5 liter, opposed 12 cylinder engine.
text:
Are you serious? The auto that had a lot to do with bringing the term boxer to the popular forefront was the Ferrari 512 Berlinetta Boxer or the 512BB. Had a 5 liter, opposed 12 cylinder engine. The engine was a four stroke, and the engine block was made of cast iron. It was also a very powerful engine, with a peak output of around 500 horsepower.

The 512 was an Italian car, but it was not a Ferrari. In fact, it wasn't even a Fiat. This was actually a car that was built by a company called Fiat, which was owned by the Italian government. They were a small company, so they had to make a few cars to sell to government officials. One of the cars they made was this 512. And it had the same engine as the Fiat 500, except it used a different cylinder head. So it's a little bit of a mystery why it got the name "Boxer".

prompt: Primarily milage. Gas is much more expensive, so people are very concerned about it taking a few more liters per kilometer. This, along with narrow old cities, also results in smaller cars with smaller engines. These engines usually don't have the torque to mesh well with an automatic.
text:
Primarily milage. Gas is much more expensive, so people are very concerned about it taking a few more liters per kilometer. This, along with narrow old cities, also results in smaller cars with smaller engines. These engines usually don't have the torque to mesh well with an automatic.

The other problem is that the cars are not designed to be driven on the highway. They are designed for city driving. The cars have to have a lot of power to get the car to the next city. So, the engine is not powerful enough to do the job. It's not a problem for the average driver, but it is a big problem when you're driving a car that is designed specifically for highway driving, and you have no choice but to drive on a highway, because you can't drive a city car on an interstate. That's why the city cars tend to run on gas.

text: Archive Name rec autos part6 New article as of 4 February 1993 rpw Many people want to set up mailing lists for their favorite automotive topics rather fewer know how to do it. This article will provide the essential information for doing so on standard Unix systems. A shell script and examples of alias file setups are included which presently run on a Sparc 2 here at balltown.cma.com for a number of mailing lists. Note that if you do set up an automotive mailing list, please let me know of the request address so that I can list it in the montly rec.autos posting. The script is available at http://www.balltown-cmm.org/~rpwd/automotive.sh. It is also available on the web at: http:/ /www.ballcity. cma. com/ rpc/ auto. sh. The example aliases file is at / usr / local / bin / auto. sh and is in /usr/local/bin/auto. If you are using a Unix system other than Unix, you will need to change the path to the auto script to /etc/rc.d/init. d/. This is done by editing the file / etc / rc.local and adding the following line: / var / run / autos / autos / AUTO_SUBJECT = "Auto" /var/run/ auto_sub_subject = AUTOMOBILE_MESSAGE /bin / rm - rf / tmp / Auto / /tmp /Auto / The auto file will then be run when the user logs in. You can also use the autorec script which is included in this file. / r / c / m / a / s / l / i / o / p / d / e / t / f / g / h / n / v / u / b / k / y / w / x / z / A / C / S / L / I / O / P / D / E / T / F / G

That means that a $25,400 used vehicle is going for about the same as a brand new $30,600 car and a newer $35,700 car (which is what I think the new price will end up being).

The dealer is not going out of business. They are just going through a transition period. You can't just walk into a dealership and buy a vehicle. There are a number of reasons why a dealer might close down. One of them is that they are losing money. Another is because they have a bad reputation. A third reason is they just don't have the money to keep the business going. And a fourth reason might just be that there is no demand for the product. So, if you are looking for an affordable car to buy, you might want to look elsewhere.

prompt: We have seen lots of discussion on automobile engine configuration. Let me ask a similar question from the aviation field. You must have seen images of prop planes with all cylinders exposed. I have seen up to 8 cylinders positioned radially in a circular fashion with the prop at the center of the circle.
text:
We have seen lots of discussion on automobile engine configuration. Let me ask a similar question from the aviation field. You must have seen images of prop planes with all cylinders exposed. I have seen up to 8 cylinders positioned radially in a circular fashion with the prop at the center of the circle. This is a common configuration for a single-engine aircraft. The reason for this is that the engine is designed to be a high-performance, high efficiency engine. It is not designed for low-speed operation. In fact, it is the opposite. A single engine airplane is intended to operate at high speeds. If the propeller is mounted at a low angle to the ground, the airplane will be very unstable.

The propellers on a two-engined airplane are designed so that they can be rotated in the direction of flight. They are not intended for high speed operation, but they are very efficient. When the engines are rotated, they produce thrust. That thrust is used to accelerate the aircraft forward. There is no need for the thrust to go to zero. As the speed increases, so does the amount of thrust produced. So, if the plane is flying at low speed, then the power output will increase. But, as the speeds increase, there is less thrust being produced, and the efficiency of each engine decreases. Therefore, a plane with two engines is more efficient than a one- engine plane. However, this efficiency is only a function of how many engines the two planes have. For example, an airplane with one engine and a propellor is much more inefficient than an aircraft with three engines and two propellers.


In the case of a four- or five-cylinder engine, you can see that there are two different types of efficiency.

From: Max Krasnow <maxkras@gmail.com>
 the gas adsourption system is a very interesting idea. I have been working with it for a while now and have some ideas on how to make it work. The idea is to use a gas that is very reactive to the air and then use the reaction to generate a small amount of heat. This heat is then used to drive a turbine to produce electricity.
The idea of using a reactive gas is not new. It has been done before. For example, in the early days of the automobile industry, gasoline was used as a fuel. When the gasoline ran out, it was replaced by diesel fuel, which was also very reactable. Diesel fuel was very expensive, so the car companies used a mixture of gasoline and diesel to power the cars. Eventually, diesel became the dominant fuel in automobiles. However, this was not a good idea because the diesel engine was much more efficient than gasoline engines. As a result, cars were much less fuel efficient. So, instead of replacing gasoline with diesel, they were replaced with gasoline. Now, there is an alternative to this. A new type of fuel is being developed that has a much higher energy density than diesel. That is, a gasoline-to-diesel ratio of 1:1 is much better than 1.5:2. text:
Well, it depends on what kind of locking lugnuts you have. My previous car had locking lugnuts that weighed about 2.5oz. more than the others. The locking lugnuts were factory equipment, and according to the factory service manual, after tire balancing the technician mechanic was supposed to put a 1 2 oz. weight on the lug nuts to balance the tire. I had a factory set of factory locking lugs that were about 1.25oz heavier than my other car. So, I was able to get the weight off the locking nuts.

The other thing to consider is that the locknuts are not the only part of the car that can be affected by the amount of weight. If you are using a different type of tire, the tires may not be as strong as the ones you use on your car, or the tread may be softer. Also, if you're using different tires, you may have different tread patterns on different parts of your tire that may affect the strength of those parts. For example, a tire with a high sidewall may need a higher weight than a low sidewalder tire because the high-walled tire will have a harder time resisting the impact of a bump. On the other hand, tires with low-wall sidewalls may require a lower weight because they will be less likely to be damaged by a crash.

text:

I know California charges you on the full value of the new vehicle regardless of trade in. If you are a California resident, is it legal to buy a car in a state other than California without also paying California sales tax? How does California enforce any law that requires you to also pay California sales tax on top of the out of state tax?

A: The California Vehicle Code does not require you pay sales taxes on a vehicle that is not registered in California. However, if you sell a used vehicle in another state, you must pay the California vehicle sales and use tax.

Q What is the difference between a radar and a laser? Q A radar is a device that uses a radio frequency to detect the presence of an object. A laser is an electronic device which uses light to create a pattern of light. Radar detectors are used to determine the distance to an approaching vehicle. Laser detectors detect objects by using a light source to produce a beam of visible light which is then reflected back to the detector. The detector then measures the reflected light and determines the size of the object detected. Both types of detectors can be used in the same vehicle, but the laser detector is more accurate. It is also more portable. For more information on radar, see the following: Q How do I know if my vehicle is equipped with a Radar Detector? text:
Bottom line I did it and it worked. Some 'tips and techniques' are included here I found that I needed some smaller sockets to undo the shocks. And a can of WD40 helped... The sockets needed were metric exact fit but I was able to use some SAE sockets... 13 16 and 15 16 are rather close to 21 and 24mm... I used a socket wrench to tighten the bolts and then used the socket to loosen the nuts. I also used some small flat head screwdrivers to remove the shock mounts. The shock mount bolts were a bit loose but the bolt was tight enough to hold the mount in place.

I used an old car jack to lift the car up and put the springs back in. Then I put a small piece of wood under the front of the vehicle and used it to support the rear of my car. This was a good way to get the spring out of there and out from under my vehicle. It was also a way for me to see if the suspension was working properly.


The car was then put back on the jack and I started the engine. After a few minutes I noticed that the motor was starting to spin. So I took the old motor out and replaced it with a new one. Now the bike was running. But it was still a little noisy. A little bit of tuning was needed. First I had to adjust the timing on my timing belt. That was easy. Just loosen and tighten a couple of bolts. Next I adjusted the oil pressure on both the crank and the crankshaft. Again, easy to do. Finally I tightened the tension on all the other bolts on each side of each shock. All in all it took about an hour to tune the motorcycle.

For those that are interested I got my fully optioned Air, ABS, sunroof '92 SE R in September 1991 for 13,555 in Sacramento, CA. It was one of the 1st '92s sold, few of the dealers had any, no local dealer had an ABS equipped SE R. I went straight to the fleet manager at the dealership I liked, told him what I wanted, made him aware that I knew what his price should be. He called me back with exactly what I wanted from a dealer 125mi away, I took delivery the next day. The car was a total loss, the dealer was out of it, and I had to sell it.

I have a few other cars that have been in the same situation, but they were all sold to dealerships that were out-of-state.


The only other time I have ever had a problem with a car is when I bought a '91 SE from the local dealership in San Diego. They had the car for a year and a half, then they sold it to a guy in California who had it for about a month. When I asked him to take it back to California, he said he didn't have the money to do it and he would have to pay for it out the back door. So I drove it home and took it in for the first time. After a week of driving it around, it started to smell like a dead cat. My wife said it smelled like the cat had been dead for two weeks. She said she had never smelled that before. We took the engine out and cleaned it up, put it on the dyno and it ran like new. Then I put the oil in and the problem was gone. That was the only time that happened. But I don't know if it was because of that or because I was driving the '90s.

For example, it can monitor a vehicle for any number of reasons, from a malfunctioning engine to an electrical problem. The Saturn manual is also a bit more forgiving than a manual-transmission car. It's not as forgiving as a stick-shift, and it's a little more demanding on the driver. If you're a driver who likes to be in the zone, the stick shift is for you. You can get a good feel for how the car is shifting, how much torque is being applied, etc. With the shift lever in neutral, you can feel the torque being transferred to the wheels. In the case of the S-Tronic, it feels like the clutch is engaged, which is good. However, if you are a more aggressive driver, or you want to get the most out of your car, then you'll want the shifter in first. That's where the power is. When you shift into first, there is no torque transfer. There is just a very slight amount of power being sent to your wheels, as the engine is still in gear. So, when the throttle is pulled back, your engine will be pulling back on its own. And that's good, because it means you have more power to work with. Dear Netters I am looking to buy a used Eagle Talon '91 or '91 TSi AWD. Question is that the '91 TSi AWD was mentioned in the April Consumer Reports to a car to avoid! In particular, the manual transmission, electrical system, and brakes were below par in both models. I have a friend who owns a TS i and has a similar problem. He has been driving the car for over a year and the clutch is still working. Is there any way to tell if the problem is with the transmission or the brakes? I would like to know if there is any chance of getting a new clutch or a different brake system. Thanks!

A: The clutch and brake problems are not related. The problem with your clutch may be related to the brake pads. If you have the same problem in your brake pad, you may have to replace the pads and/or the caliper.
...
,
The problem may also be caused by the electrical wiring. Check the wiring harness for any loose connections. Also, check the battery for loose connection. You may need to remove the front bumper to check for the wires.

prompt: Don't worry about leaks. Don't worry about which way to turn the damn thing. Take a good claw hammer and pry it straight out. Now, you'll notice, after all the oil pours out, that there are no theads where there used to be.
text:
Don't worry about leaks. Don't worry about which way to turn the damn thing. Take a good claw hammer and pry it straight out. Now, you'll notice, after all the oil pours out, that there are no theads where there used to be. That's because the engine is now running on a new oil.

The oil is a mixture of oil and water. The oil in the crankcase is the same as the water in your bathtub. It's the mixture that makes the car run. When you start the motor, the air in it is compressed and the pressure is released. This causes the piston to move. As the pistons move, they compress the fuel and release the gas. In the case of a car, this is what causes it to run, and it's what makes it run fast. But the problem is that the new mixture is not the old mixture. Instead, it contains a lot of water, which is why the cars run so slowly. If you take a look at the picture above, notice how the blue line is where the original oil line used be? That is because it was the only way the line could be connected to the cylinder head. So, when the head was removed, all that was left was a bunch of old oil that had been sitting there for a long time. And that's why it runs so slow. You can see that it has a little bit of blue in there. What you need to do is to take the little blue blob and put it in a bucket of cold water and let it soak for about an hour. Then, take it out and pour it into a container of fresh oil, like Mobil 1. Put the container in an oil cooler and leave it

But I do know that diesel engines are not as clean burning as gas.

. but they putout a a much higher amount of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon emissions. Carbon monoxides are the most dangerous form of pollution. They are formed when the carbon atoms in the fuel are broken down by the heat of combustion. The carbon dioxide is released as a gas, which is then exhaled. Hydrocarbon emissions are produced when fuel is burned. These are also released in a form that is inhaled, but are much less harmful. Nitrous Oxide is a byproduct of the burning of gasoline. It is formed by reacting the nitrogen in gasoline with oxygen. This reaction is very dangerous, as it can cause severe burns. So, if you are driving a diesel, you should be aware of this. If you have a car that runs on gas or diesel and you don´t want to be burned, then you can use a generator to run the engine. You can also use an electric car battery to power the car.

text:
Perhaps instead of this silly argument about what backup lights are for, couldn't we agree that they serve the dual purpose of letting people behind your car know that you have it in reverse and that they can also light up the area behind your car while you're backing up so you can see? Backup lamps on current models are much brighter than they used to be on older cars. Those on my Taurus Wagon are quite bright enough to illuminate a good area behind the car, and they're MUCH brighter than those on my earlier cars from the 60s and 70s. Insofar as Vettes having side backup lights, look at a '92 or '93 model or perhaps a year or two earlier too and you'll see red side marker lamps and white side marker lamps both near the car's hindquarters.

The other reason I think it's a bad idea to have backup lamps is that it makes it harder to see the road ahead. If you've ever driven on a road with a lot of traffic, you know how hard it is to keep your eyes on the ground. You can't see what's ahead, but you do have to pay attention to what you see ahead of you. With backup lighting, it becomes much harder for you to do that. It's much easier to just look ahead and see where you are going. I've seen cars with backup headlights that are so bright that the headlights are actually blinding the driver behind them. That's not a very good idea.

text:
To wheelspin in an auto, you keep the gear in N gas it then stick the gear in D... I've never tried this but am sure it works but does this screw up the autobox? We're having a bit of a debate about it here... I've known more people to leave their rear ends in pieces doing this, especially if they have reasonable power to transmit and good traction on the road surface. I'm not sure if it's a good idea to do this on a road with a lot of potholes or if you should just leave the rear end in the car and let the engine do the work.

I've seen a few people do it and it seems to work well. It's not a bad idea, but I don't think it is a great idea. If you're going to use a gearbox, it should be a high gear. You can't just put the front end of the vehicle in gear and then put it in reverse. The front axle is going into gear first and the back end is in neutral. So you have to put your front wheels in first, then the wheels on your rear axle, and finally the gears on both wheels. This is not the best way to go about things.

What the heck is an Oxygen sensor? I have never heard of it. I've never seen it on any of my other cars. It is a sensor that is used to measure the amount of oxygen in the air. The sensor is located in a small box on top of your engine. If you have a car that has a manual transmission, the sensor will be on your transmission. In a automatic transmission it will usually be in your clutch. You can see the box in this picture.

The sensor has two wires that go to it, one for the engine and one to your car's air conditioning system. There is also a wire that goes to a switch that controls the oxygen sensor and the other wire is for your air filter. So, if you take your Sprint in to be serviced, you will have to take the car to an air shop and have them replace the sensors. They will charge you for that service. This is why I don't have the money to pay for it myself.

text:
Not to inject a non automotive note to this thread, but the BMW opposed twin used in motorcycles for a long time is and always has been known as a boxer. The BMW is a very good motorcycle, and the twin is not. The twin has a lot of advantages over the boxer, including a much higher top speed, better handling, more power, a better fuel economy, etc. But the two are not the same.

The twin was developed in the late 1950s and early 1960s, when the motorcycle industry was in a state of flux. There was a need for an affordable, reliable, high performance motorcycle that could be used for both city and highway riding. It was also a good choice for the growing number of people who wanted to ride motorcycles but didn't want to spend a fortune on a motorcycle. In the early days, the Twin was the only choice. Today, there are many other choices, such as the Harley-Davidson, Kawasaki, Suzuki, Triumph, Yamaha, Honda, KTM, Polaris, Ducati, BMW, MV Agusta, Harley, Norton, Maserati and others. All of these motorcycles are very similar in design, performance, handling and price. They all have their advantages and disadvantages. Some of the advantages are:

text:
I have been having problems with a slightly different clutch problem on my 90 Prelude. See rec.autos.tech for more detail. My problem is a false engagement point below the actual one. It also seems affected by weather it is most noticeable and annoying on damp or cold days. I have had it for about a week now and it has been a real pain. The clutch is very light and the clutch pedal is not very responsive. This is the first time I've had this problem.

I've been using the same clutch for a few years now. When I first bought it, I was very happy with it. However, it was a bit of a pain to shift. Now, after a couple of years, the problem has become worse. There is no way to get the pedal to engage. If I try to use the brake pedal, nothing happens. So, now I'm using a different pedal. But, this is still a problem, because the car is so light. Also, when I use my foot to push the pedals, they don't engage at all. They just sit there. And, if I push them, there is nothing to stop them from disengaging.


The problem seems to be caused by the fact that the spring is too short. In other words, you can't get a good engagement with the foot. You have to press the accelerator pedal and then push it down. That's not a very good way of getting a clutch to work.

Much discussion about economics of safety deleted This is a very simplistic view of safety. Assuming that you are in a collision less likely with a more agile smaller car, then the important factor is how well does the car sacrifice itself to save you. This is why a thousand pound F1 car can hit a wall at 200 and the driver walks out and why everybody dies when a Suburban hits a wall at 35 as I recall for the last generation Suburban HIC numbers. As an aside, just what is the point of an airbag? It is not to protect you from a car that is going to hit you, it is to stop you hitting the wall. The airbags are there to prevent you getting hit by a bigger car.

The point is that the more you drive, the less you will be able to do to avoid a crash. If you have a lot of miles on the clock, you can drive a little more safely. But if you don't, then you need to drive more carefully. And if the road is too dangerous, or the weather is bad, and you cannot drive safely, there is no point in driving at all. You need a driver. A driver is someone who can take control of a situation and make it safe. It's not a matter of "if" you get into a serious accident, but "when".

text:
That shows how much you know about anything. The brakes on the SHO are very different 9 inch or 9.5? I forget discs all around, vented in front. The normal Taurus setup is smaller discs front, drums rear. I have a T-bird and a SHo.

I have the Tauruses and the S-birds. They are both very similar. Both have 9" discs. T.B. has a 9-inch disc, S.H.O. a 10-incher. SOHO has the same size discs as TBA.


The SHOs are a little different. There is a small hole in the center of the brake disc. It is not a big hole, but it is there. This is to allow the disc to be rotated in a different direction. If you have ever seen a car with a brake light, you will know that the light is on when the car is stopped. When the brakes are on, the lights are off. So the hole is designed to let the discs rotate in different directions. You can see the holes in my SH-Brake.com article. Also, I noticed that there is no brake fluid in either the front or rear brake. That is because the rear brakes have no fluid. In the case of a Soho, there are no brakes at all. Just a lever. But the lever is very small. And the fluid is in there, so it must be there for some reason. Maybe it's to keep the clutch from slipping. Or maybe it has some other purpose. Either way, it makes the braking system very unique.

The fuel system is a very important part of the vehicle. If the pump is damaged, it can cause the air/fuel mixture to become too lean and cause a loss of power. A damaged fuel line can also cause fuel to be lost. In addition, if the oil pump fails, oil can be drained from the transmission. All of these problems can lead to a fuel leak. There are several ways to diagnose a leak in your fuel tank. First, you can check the tank for leaks. You can use a hose to drain the contents of your tank and then check for any leaks in a vacuum pump. Second, a good way to check your oil is to use an oil pressure gauge. Oil pressure is measured in pounds per square inch (psi). A low oil level can indicate a low pressure in one of two ways: 1) The oil has become contaminated with dirt and/or oil. 2) There is an internal problem in which the pressure has dropped too low. the SHOE was a very popular car in the late 60's and early 70's. there were a lot of people who had one, or who were just curious about it. they were also very cheap to buy. you could buy one for $200 or less. and they had some pretty good performance. but they also had problems. one of the problems was that they would not start. this was because the clutch was not properly adjusted. if you had it adjusted properly, it would start, even if the car was cold. so you would have to warm it up before you drove it, which was very inconvenient. another problem was the shifter. when you were in first gear, the shift lever would be in a "dead" position. in second gear it could be moved to the "live" or "neutral" positions, depending on the situation. a third problem with the shifting was, that it had no "feel". it felt very stiff and heavy. after a while, you'd get used to it and it'd work fine. all in all, a good car, if not a great one.

prompt: Personally, i wouldn't use the 1.29 product from KMart. I knew about this previously, but this past weekend on PBS's MotorWeek Pat Goss their resident tech type discussed these products, and recommends not using them i.e, the non isopropyl alcohlo based injector cleaners . Supposedly only the isopropyl based cleaners actually remove moisture from your fuel tank as they clean your injectors. And although the others ethyl based do clean injectors they also cause rubber components in the fuel system to deteriorate, and they don't mix well with water to help remove it from the fuel system.
text:
Personally, i wouldn't use the 1.29 product from KMart. I knew about this previously, but this past weekend on PBS's MotorWeek Pat Goss their resident tech type discussed these products, and recommends not using them i.e, the non isopropyl alcohlo based injector cleaners. Supposedly only the isopropyl based cleaners actually remove moisture from your fuel tank as they clean your injectors. And although the others ethyl based do clean injectors they also cause rubber components in the fuel system to deteriorate, and they don't mix well with water to help remove it from the fuel system. So, if you're going to use these, you should use a cleaner that is specifically designed to remove the moisture.

I've been using the Kmart 1/2 oz. injectator cleaner for a few months now, so I decided to try it out. It's a good cleaner, it's not as strong as the other isobutyls, which is why I'm not going out and buying a new one. But, I do like the fact that it doesn't leave a residue on the injecters, unlike the synthetic ones. The only downside is that the cleaner is a little bit harsh on my injecter, especially when I use it on a cold day. However, this is not a big deal, as I've never had any issues with the cleaning process. If you have any questions about the product, feel free to ask.

text:
Talking about car alarms, there are certain cars in this country that are only insurable if they are fitted with a Vecta alarm. We're talking Coswoths and Porsches and stuff. Just before they the insurance companies decided to make this move, they insisted that the car be fitted with a Scorpion alarm now they've changed to the Vecta... so everyone who's spent on fitting the Scorpion alarm have founbd themselves having to upgrade to the Vecta system.

The VECTA system is a system that's been around for a while now and it's a very good system, but it does have a few drawbacks. One of the drawbacks is that it only works with certain vehicles. If you're buying a car from a dealership, you can't just buy the system and then go and buy a new alarm system for it. You have to go to a dealer and get a different alarm for the vehicle. So if you buy an alarm from the dealership and you don't have the right alarm, then you'll have no insurance. The other drawback is the fact that you have an extra cost to pay for this system because you've got to buy it separately. It's not cheap. But it is worth it, because it works. And it also works very well. I've had a lot of people tell me that they have had problems with the alarms and that I should have bought the new system instead of buying the old one. They say that if I had bought it I would have been able to get the same level of protection. That's the reason why I'm writing this article. Because I want to show you that there's no reason to not buy this new VEC system if it means that your car will be protected.

text:
It seems that there are more and more bands available for police radar each month. I have recently purchased within the last 8 months the BEL 966STW. While it is not a perfect detector by any means, it does do the job fairly well. Now, however, I pick up a car magazine at the airport and read about this Super Ka Wideband which is a superset of the Ka Wideband that this latest generation of detectors was touted as covering. The Super Wide Band is supposed to be able to detect a vehicle traveling at speeds of up to 100 mph. This is the same speed that the police are supposed be looking for.

I have been using the Super KA WideBand for a few months now and have not had any problems. It is very easy to set up and operate. There is no need to use a computer or a scanner. Just plug it into your car's radio and turn it on. You will hear a beeping sound and the radio will automatically turn on the detector. Once the car is detected, the scanner will display the speed of that vehicle. If the vehicle is traveling faster than the limit, you will see a red light on it. When the light is on, a warning will be displayed on your radio. After the warning, if the driver is still driving at that speed, then the signal will turn off. However, this is only a temporary measure. As soon as the red signal turns off, your vehicle will go back to normal speed. So, in order to avoid a ticket, just keep driving. In my experience, there is always a chance that you may be caught by the radar. But, as long as you are not speeding, and you have a good reason for being there, that is all that matters.

The road was built by a consortium of companies, including the Swedish National Roads Company, with the help of a Swedish government grant. It was designed to run from the city of Särköping to the town of Örebro, then on to Stockholm, where it would connect to a new road. This road would be the first of its kind in Europe, but it was not the last. In the 1930s and 40s the roads were expanded, as the country's population grew, to include the suburbs of Stockholm and Gothenburg. These roads would become known as "the suburbs" and were built to connect the cities to each other. They were also used for the construction of new roads and bridges, such as those that connected the towns of Malmö and Malmo to Gotland. Eventually, these roads became the main arteries of Swedish motorways, connecting the major cities of Gotheborg, Malmsborg and Stockholm. As the population of these cities grew and grew they needed more and more roads to get them to and from their suburbs. Diesels fall into the same emissions mythology as alcohol fuels. The main reason they are considered cleaner is because they are better at the emissions we actually measure and regulate. But they also contribute additional emissions which have long been determined to be as harmful, but no suitable control or limits have been defined. Current evidence is pointing to most visible smog actually being diesel emissions and suspended particles and less of a photo chemical reaction.

The main problem with diesel is that it is a very efficient fuel. It is also very cheap. So it has been used in many countries for decades. In the US, it was used for a long time in the 1950s and 1960s. And it still is. Diesel is the fuel of choice for the majority of cars and trucks in Europe. There are many reasons for this. First, diesel has a low carbon footprint. Second, the diesel fuel is very clean. Third, there is no need for expensive filters. Fourth, because diesel engines are so efficient, they can be used on a wide range of vehicles. Fifth, and most importantly, most diesel vehicles are not designed to run on diesel. They are designed for gasoline engines. This means that diesel cars are much more efficient than gasoline cars. For example, a diesel car can run for about 20 miles on gasoline. A gasoline car only can go about 10 miles. That is why diesel can easily be the most efficient vehicle on the road. However, this is not the case for all diesel-powered vehicles, especially those that are used to transport hazardous materials. These vehicles have to use a different fuel, which is much less efficient. As a result, these vehicles can only go a few miles before they need to switch to a more expensive alternative.

In many cases, there was no way to get any sort of a tray under the oil pan because it was boxed in by the bottom of the hull and various floation chambers on each side. And if you did get something there, you'd spill all the oil out of it for sure trying to get it back out again. So, if I had a boat that had an engine, and I wanted to change the engine oil, it would be a lot easier to just dump the whole oil tank out and replace it with a new one. But, that's not what I do. I have a very large oil change tank that I fill with oil every time I change it. It's a big tank, so I can easily get a full tank of oil in there. If I want to, the tank can be filled with water, but I don't want that. The tank is so big, even if it were filled to the brim, all that oil would still be in the water. That's why I use a large, heavy-duty bucket.

I have an old, old boat, a small, small boat. We have two engines, one on the bow and one in a stern. One engine is a diesel engine. There's no oil pump on it, no fuel pump. All the fuel is in this bucket, which is filled up with diesel fuel. When I need to replace the diesel oil with something else, like a synthetic oil or something, or a different type of fuel, this is the bucket I go to. This is what it looks like when I'm filling it up. You can see the pump, where the hose goes to it and the line that goes from the top of this tank to my boat's engine compartment. text:
I don't remember the formula's off hand as it has been awhile since I took aerodynamics and haven't used the stuff since. The Cd is related to the drag force which is what effects top speed and fuel consumption. When the drag force on the car or aircraft is greater than what the vehicle's engine can overcome it has reached its top speed. autos of course also have to overcome rolling resistance Since drag opposes the vehicle's motion, the engine must make up for that by burning more fuel. This is why the Cs are so important.

The C is the amount of energy that is required to accelerate a vehicle to a given speed, and the S is how much energy is needed to maintain that speed at a constant speed (or constant acceleration). The S of a car is equal to its weight times the speed of the acceleration. For example, a weight of 100 pounds is equivalent to 100 feet per second of acceleration, so the weight is 100 x 0.1 = 100. If the driver is driving at 100 mph, then the energy required is 1.0 x 100 = 1,000, which equals 1 S. So the total energy needed is 1000 S, or 1 C.


So the more C's you have, you need more energy to keep the same speed as you are going. In other words, if you want to go faster, more power is necessary. But if the power you use is less than the fuel you burn, it is more efficient to use less power. That is because the less energy you consume, less fuel is used. And the higher the efficiency, greater the number of C-C's.

prompt: Here is a press release from the U.S. Department of Energy. Energy Secretary Hails President's Plan For Alternative Fuel Vehicles To National Desk, Environment and Energy Reporters Contact Larry Hart of the U.S. Department of Energy, 202 586 5806 WASHINGTON, April 21 Secretary of Energy Hazel R. O'Leary today said President Clinton's Executive Order on Alternative Fuels will make the federal government a driving force behind efforts to increase the availability of both alternative fuel vehicles and fuel supplies. President Clinton signed the order today, which calls for federal purchases of alternative fuel vehicles in numbers over the next three years at least 50 percent higher than those called for in the Energy Policy Act of 1992. President Clinton also announced that Texas Land Commissioner Gary Mauro will head up the Federal Fleet Conversion Task Force to advise O'Leary on implementation of the Executive Order.
text: Here is a press release from the U.S. Department of Energy. Energy Secretary Hails President's Plan For Alternative Fuel Vehicles To National Desk, Environment and Energy Reporters Contact Larry Hart of the U.S. Department of Energy, 202 586 5806 WASHINGTON, April 21 Secretary of Energy Hazel R. O'Leary today said President Clinton's Executive Order on Alternative Fuels will make the federal government a driving force behind efforts to increase the availability of both alternative fuel vehicles and fuel supplies. President Clinton signed the order today, which calls for federal purchases of alternative fuel vehicles in numbers over the next three years at least 50 percent higher than those called for in the Energy Policy Act of 1992. President Clinton also announced that Texas Land Commissioner Gary Mauro will head up the Federal Fleet Conversion Task Force to advise O'Leary on implementation of the Executive Order. "The President has made it clear that he wants to see alternative fuels become a major part of our nation's transportation system," said O'the Secretary. The President also directed the Secretary to work with the Department's Office of Alternative Energy to develop a plan to promote the use of alternate fuels in all federal transportation projects. In addition, the President directed O'mey to establish a Federal Alternative Transportation Fund to support the development of a national alternative transportation strategy. This fund will be used to provide grants to states and localities to help them develop alternative energy infrastructure. Secretary O'dley said the Administration is committed to supporting the growth of alternatives to conventional fuels. He said, "We are committed not only to the expansion of fuel-efficient vehicles, but also to expanding the supply of clean, renewable fuels." The Secretary said that the new Administration will continue to encourage the adoption of renewable energy sources, including wind, solar, geothermal, biomass, and hydroelectric power. To support this effort, Secretary Clinton directed Secretary Mauros to continue his work on the National Alternative-Fuel Taskforce. Under the Task force's auspices, O'veley will work to identify and support alternative-fuel vehicle manufacturers, suppliers, distributors, retailers, service providers, research and development facilities, public and private research institutions, energy efficiency and renewable-energy programs, as well as other stakeholders. A number of states have already begun to implement alternative vehicle programs. For example, California has established a program to purchase alternative vehicles

The Continental may have been the first modern era auto to mount the spare on the rear of the car but it was hardly the first car to sport one. Various mounting techniques for rear mounting the spare were quite common in early automobiles, both US and Foreign.

The first known example of a rear mounted spare was a Ford Model T, which was introduced in 1908. The spare had a small hole in the top of it to allow the driver to remove the engine from the vehicle. This was the only way to get the extra space needed for the front spare. In the early years of American automobile production, the Model A was also fitted with a spare, but this was not used until the 1920's. By the 1930's, rear-mounted spare plates were becoming more common. These were usually made of wood and were mounted on a metal plate. They were often mounted in a similar fashion to the original front-mount spare but were not as well made. Some of these were made by the Ford Motor Company. Other companies made spare parts for other manufacturers. For example, Ford made a front mounted rear spare for its Model I and Model II cars. Ford also made rear mounts for some of its cars for use with the Chrysler Corporation.


In the late 1930s, a new type of rear mount was developed. It was called a "front-side" spare and was mounted to a steel plate on top. A small opening was cut in this plate to accept the brake hose. When the brakes were applied, this hole would close and the hose would be pulled through the hole. prompt: I doubt his trans uses standard syncros. There are several mechanisms for coupling a gear with the transmission output shaft, some of which are fine for racing and unsuitable for street use.
text:
I doubt his trans uses standard syncros. There are several mechanisms for coupling a gear with the transmission output shaft, some of which are fine for racing and unsuitable for street use. The most common is a "coupling" mechanism, which is simply a piece of metal or plastic that is attached to the gear shaft. This coupling is usually a small piece that fits into the hole in the shaft and is held in place by a spring. It is not a good idea to use a coupling mechanism on a transmission that has a large number of gears.

The other common mechanism is the "shaft-to-gear" coupling. A shaft is connected to a shaft-shifter, and the shifter is used to move the gears in a chain. In this case, the shaft is also connected directly to an output gear, so the output of the chain is coupled to that gear. If the clutch is engaged, this coupling will not work. However, if the shift lever is in neutral, it will work fine.


A common problem with gearboxes is that the drive shafts are not properly aligned. When the engine is running, a shift shaft will be in front of a drive gear and a clutch will move it to behind the other gear in order to shift the car. As the motor is turning, there is no way to tell which gear is being shifted. To correct this, you need to have the correct gear on the front and rear of your gearbox. You can do this by using a special gear-shift tool, or by having the driver use the manual shift.

This law was passed in the late 90's and was intended to protect the public from RF radiation. However, the law has been interpreted to prohibit the installation of Ka band devices in Texas.

The Texas law is very specific and states that "no person shall use a device to transmit or receive a signal that is capable of being received by a receiver that does not have a frequency-sharing capability." This means that if you have an antenna that can receive Ka, you cannot use it to receive the signal from a Ka-band device. If you are using a band-pass filter, then you can use the filter to block the Ka signal, but you will not be able to use your antenna to send the signals. So, if your bandpass is set to Ka and you want to get a good signal to your receiver, it is best to set it up to work with a low-power Ka device, such as a handheld or portable radio.

text: Archive name rec autos part5 this article is one of a pair of articles containing commonly asked automotive questions the other article contains questions more geared to the automotive enthusiast, and so is not crossposted to misc.consumers. rpw changes as of 14 April 1993 revised brake fluid section, as non silicone DOT 5 fluids are now apparently available rpw Commonly Asked Automotive Questions Tire Questions Q What do the funny numbers on the sides of my tires mean? A Typically, you will see something like 195 60HR14. the 195 is the overall width of the tire in millimeters, the tread is usually narrower. The numbers are usually written in the same order as the sidewall, so the first number is on top of it. For example, if you have a tire with a width 195, it would be written as 195.60. If you had a sidewalls that were 195 and a tread that was 60, then the numbers would read as: 19560HR. Q How do I know if my tire is a "standard" or "high performance" tire?A A "Standard" is an OEM tire that is designed to be used on a wide variety of vehicles. A high performance tire, on average, is made for a specific application. It is intended to handle the stresses of high-speed driving, high acceleration, or high cornering. High performance tires are designed for high speeds and high accelerations. They are not designed or intended for use on low speed, low acceleration vehicles, such as a car, truck, motorcycle, etc. In general, a high speed tire will have more tread than a low-performance tire. This is because a higher speed vehicle will be able to withstand the higher forces that a lower speed one will not be capable of. Also, higher speeds will require a larger tire to hold the load. Therefore, when you see a number like "20" on your tire sidewal, that means that the manufacturer has designed the tires for 20 mph. However, there are some high quality tires that are intended only for higher-end vehicles and are therefore not

As I passed under a rock slammed against the metal between the winshield and right front window. My girlfriend was in the seat next to it. I pulled over and she got out of the car and said, "I think I saw a guy on that over there." I said "What do you mean?" She said she saw him on top of a car. She was right.

I was shocked. It was a dark night and I had no idea what to do. So I got back in my car, pulled out my flashlight and looked. The guy was on his back, his head was down, and he was wearing a white shirt. He was about 5'8" and about 150 pounds. His hair was long and dark. There was no way he could have been wearing any clothes. But he had a black backpack on. And he looked like he'd been in a fight. Then I realized that he wasn't wearing his glasses. They were off. That's when it hit me. This guy had been stabbed. A knife had gone through his chest. We pulled off the highway and called the police. When they arrived, they found the guy's body. In the back seat of his car was his wallet, credit cards, a cell phone, money, keys, etc. All of it was missing. No money. Nothing. Just his clothes and his backpack. After the autopsy, the coroner said that the knife was probably a 9 inch kitchen knife. Now, I'm not a doctor, but I know that a kitchen-knife is a very sharp knife that is used for cutting meat. Click to expand... Click to shrink...
 the drag coefficient is a measure of the aerodynamic drag of a vehicle. It is calculated by dividing the vehicle's mass by the square of its velocity. The drag is the product of mass and velocity squared. For example, a car with a mass of 100 kg and a velocity of 10 m/s has a drag value of.10. A car that has the same mass but a higher velocity has an aerodynamically better drag.The drag can be calculated using the following formula:whereis the mass,is velocity,andis a constant. This formula is used to determine the coefficient of lift. In the case of an automobile, the lift coefficient can also be determined using a similar formula.

prompt: xIf you put a locking lugnut on your tires, do you need to have your xtires rebalanced?? x xJohn Mas x xE Mail Address MAS SKCLA.MONSANTO.COM Since the wheel tire is balanced off the car i.e. the lugnuts are not normally involved, how would they do that? I would think that since the lugs are so close to the center of rotation any slight difference in weight between a normal lugnut and a locking one would not have any noticable effect on the balance.
text:
xIf you put a locking lugnut on your tires, do you need to have your xtires rebalanced?? x xJohn Mas x xE Mail Address MAS SKCLA.MONSANTO.COM Since the wheel tire is balanced off the car i.e. the lugnuts are not normally involved, how would they do that? I would think that since the lugs are so close to the center of rotation any slight difference in weight between a normal lugnut and a locking one would not have any noticable effect on the balance. I have a question about the locking lug nuts. Is it possible to use a lock nut on a lug nut? If so, what is the best way to do it? Thanks. John Mas

A:
.
,
"The locking nut is a special type of lug that is designed to be used with a standard lug. The locking nuts are designed so that the nut will not move when the tire pressure is applied to it. This is to prevent the locknut from being damaged by the pressure applied. If the weight of the vehicle is too heavy for the normal locking bolt to hold, the bolt can be removed and the axle can then be re-balanced. A locking lock is not required for a regular lug."
The lock nuts on most of our tires are standard. They are made of steel and are very strong. We have used them on all of them. You can use them with any standard locking bolts.


John
 the owner of MAS

The speedometers on most cars are about 2.25 inches in length. If you have an older car, you may have one that is longer. It is not a big deal. Just make sure you get the right one.


The speedo on my '68 FireBird is about 3 1/2 inches and it has a red dot on it. My '67 Fire Bird has the same speed scale but it does not have any red dots. So I guess it's a matter of personal preference. You can get a Speedometer with a 3 inch pointer and a 2 inch red line. Or you can have it with the red lines and the 3-1/4 inch speed gauge. text:
This is a tricky situation if the previous owner didn't inform the dealer of the odometer change, then the previous owner committed fraud, and he may be liable. The dealer may also be liable If the previous owner notified the dealer, or if the previous owner had the dash replaced at a dealer, or if the previous owner had the dash changed legally, any records search on the car should turn up the fact that the odometer had been altered. If a dealer changes the speedometer, he has to report it it goes into the car's service record with the manufacturer, and on the title, if I remember correctly the dealer told me that the old mileage, etc. were sent to Ford when my T Bird's speedo was replaced. The dealership should also have a record of any other changes made to the vehicle, such as the new tires, new brakes, the transmission, anything that might have changed the mileage.

If the owner of a car has a new car, it is important to get the original odometers and make sure they are accurate. I have had a few owners who have been able to find out the exact mileage of their car by looking at the records. This is not always possible, but it can be done. It is also important that you get a copy of your odometry. You can get one from the DMV, from your local DMV office, a local auto parts store, your auto dealer or a private company. They will be able tell you the actual mileage on your car.

I consulted with someone working on an electronic odometer. The design was to use a microprocessor based system to write a somewhat ofuscated pattern into an EEPROM. The idea was to make the circuit difficult to program arbitrary values into the EEPROM. The secondary purpose, acutally the primary purpose from the standpoint of practicality, was to distributed the writes so as to avoid exceeing the maximum number of writes fof the EEPROM being used.

The problem was that the microcontroller was not designed to be a general purpose microcomputer. It was designed for a specific purpose. In this case, it was a computer that was used to read and write data to an internal EE PROM, and to do so in a way that would not exceed the number that could be written to the internal memory. This was the purpose of the "write-only" mode. If the computer was programmed to only write to a certain number, then the write-write mode would be used, but if the programmer wanted to change the value of a variable, he would have to modify the program. Thus, the only way to get the desired result was by writing to all the possible values. To do this, a special program was written that read the data from an external EE memory and wrote it to one of two EE storage devices. One of these was an "external" EE device, which was connected to another EE chip. When the external chip was turned on, an interrupt was generated that allowed the user to set the variable. A second EE EE card was also connected, this time to "internal" memory, where the values were stored. These two cards were connected together by a "bridge" that connected the two chips. As the chip turned off, all of this data was read from internal storage and written back to external storage. Since the chips were not connected directly, they could not be read by the processor. text:
Carrying a pistol, loaded or unloaded, in the glove compartment, is considered carrying a concealed weapon in Colorado and is illegal without a concealed weapons permit. Unless the law has been changed recently, carrying a weapon openly is legal in Colorado but concealing it is illegal. I read a newspaper account last year where police stopped a car on a traffic infraction and observed a.357 magnum revolver sitting on the seat. The driver could not be cited for possessing or carrying the weapon because it was not concealed.

The Colorado Supreme Court has ruled that a person who is carrying an unloaded handgun in a glove box is not required to have a permit to carry a handgun. However, the court has also ruled in favor of the state's concealed carry law, which requires a license to openly carry. In the case of a driver who was stopped for a minor traffic violation, a judge ruled the driver was justified in stopping the car because the gun was in plain view. This case is a good example of how the Colorado concealed handgun license law is being interpreted. If the person is stopped by police for an infractions, they are not legally required by law to show a gun. But if the officer finds the handgun, he is required under the concealed pistol license statute to issue a citation for carrying it openly. So, if you are stopped and the police find a loaded handgun on your person, you will be required, under Colorado law and federal law (the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act), to surrender the firearm to the authorities.

 the compressor is used to compress the air. A compressor has a fan to blow air through the system. Air is compressed by the fan. This is called compressor air flow. prompt: I have both an '84 and an '86 Camry, each with manual 5 speed transmissions. The '84 has about 105,000 miles on it and the '86 about 83,000 miles. ABout a year ago I found that the master cylinder on the clutch in the '84 was leaking fluid around the piston seal, leading to air in the system and fluid back into the passenger compartment of the car. I pulled the plunger and got a rebuild kit new plunger, seal, etc.
text:
I have both an '84 and an '86 Camry, each with manual 5 speed transmissions. The '84 has about 105,000 miles on it and the '86 about 83,000 miles. ABout a year ago I found that the master cylinder on the clutch in the '84 was leaking fluid around the piston seal, leading to air in the system and fluid back into the passenger compartment of the car. I pulled the plunger and got a rebuild kit new plunger, seal, etc. and it worked fine. Now the problem is that I have a '87 Camaro with a manual transmission and I am having the same problem. It is a little more complicated than the other one, but I will try to explain.


The problem with the Camaros is the timing belt. When the engine is running, the belt is in a "slack" position. This means that it is not fully engaged. If the camshaft is moving, it will pull the tension on this belt, causing it to slip. As the motor is turning, this causes the crank to move, which causes more tension to be pulled on that belt and so on. Eventually, when the crankshaft is fully turned, that tension is released and that is when you get the "clunk" sound. In the case of my '85 Cam, I had to replace the entire timing chain. There is no way to tell if the chain is worn out or not, so I just replaced it.

I had exactly the same problem with a 1981 Horizon. Third gear would just disengage. Engine would rev up. Kind of disconcerting. I had to take it to the dealer and they said it was a problem of the engine. They said they would look into it.

I called the dealership and asked them to send me a new one. The guy said he would send it out. He never did. So I called them again and said I would like to have it fixed. Again, they never sent it back. It was still in the shop. Finally, I went to a local mechanic and he said that the problem was with the transmission. That's when I realized that this was not a transmission problem. This was an engine problem, and the only way to fix it would be to replace the entire engine with an aftermarket one, which I did, but it still wouldn't work.


So I decided to go to another dealership. And I was told that they had a similar problem and that I should call them. But I didn't. Instead, the guy who had sent me the old one said, "I'm sorry, we don't have any after-market transmissions for this model." I said "Well, what do you mean?" He said the company that makes the after market transmissions had stopped making them, so they were no longer available. Well, that was the end of that. No after sales. Not even a call. Just a phone call and a letter. A letter that said: "We're sorry to hear that you're having problems with your after sale transmission."

text:
Well, there is a difference. I don't happen to have my SAE manual handy, but oil viscosity in general _decreases_ with temperature. The SAE numbers are based on a typical' curve that oils used to all have, running from say the viscosity of a room temperature 90 weight at 0C, down to say that of a room temperature 5 weight at 20C, for a typical 40 weight oil. Oils that are designed for operation in normal' temperatures just have a weight specification.

So, if you have an oil that is designed to run at a temperature of 20 C, and you put it in a car that has a 5 C temperature, it will run much better than if it was designed with a 90 C oil at that temperature in mind. This is because the oil is not designed at the temperature it is going to be used in, so it has to work at lower temperatures. So, the SCEA numbers for oil are not based off of the actual temperature at which the oils are used, they are just based upon the weight of oil used.


The SSEA number is based solely on the number of pounds of weight used per gallon of volume. If you are using a 20 weight, you will use 20 pounds per liter of water. That is the same as if the 20 pound oil was used at 5C. It is just that the 5 pound weight is used for the volume of that oil, not the specific weight. In other words, a 10 pound SGEA oil will be the exact same weight as a 1 pound, 10 ounce, SGS oil if used with the 10 gallon volume, or a 2 pound 10 oz oil as the 1 gallon SEGA. You can see that this is very important. A 10 lb SAGE oil can be as good as 1 lb, 20 ounce SAGA, because it uses the full volume and weight for that specific oil and not just the nominal weight (which is usually

Advertisement

 the car was in the shop for about an hour. It was the first time I had ever driven a Sentri. And I was so excited. My friend was driving it, too. He was very excited, because he had never driven one before. But I didn

I was really upset. This was my first car. How could I have been so stupid? I thought about it for awhile. Finally, after a while, my friend said to me, 'You know, you should have just bought a used Sentris.' I just laughed. 'I'm not buying a new Sentria.

I think the best way to describe the Swedish radar is that it's a radar that's been modified to look like a camera. It's not a real radar, but it does have a very high resolution camera that can be used to detect speed. The Swedish Radar is a great tool for tracking down speeders, especially if you're in a hurry. If you have the right equipment, you can use it to catch speeder's in the act.

I am not a lawyer, but I am a man who has been in the business of law enforcement for over 30 years. My experience is that the law is very clear on this matter. If you are stopped by a police officer, you have the right to refuse to answer any questions. You have a right not to be searched. And you do have an absolute right NOT to consent to a search. The only exception to this is if you were stopped for a traffic violation. In that case, the officer has no right or authority to search you. However, if the police are stopping you for some other reason, such as a DUI, they have no authority over you and you can refuse consent. This is the only time you should ever refuse a consent search, and it is a very bad idea. It is also a bad thing to do to your own safety. A consent is not an admission of guilt. So, in my opinion, it would have been better if they had simply asked you to step out of the car and walk away. That way, there would still be a chance that you could have given a truthful answer. But, that is your choice.

text:
That would be the Opel GT, sold in this country from '69 to '73. It originally had a 1100 cc engine, which was later replaced by the 1900 cc. It was based on the old Kadett drive train and suspension, with leaf springs in the rear and a single transverse leaf spring in the front. It looked good, but was limited as a performer.

The Opal GT was a different story. The car was built in '71, and was the first Opale GT to be sold to the US market. This car had the same engine as the Kadet, a 1200 cc, four-cylinder, DOHC, inline-four. However, it was fitted with a new, more powerful, 1200cc, V-12 engine. In the '70s, the car's engine was replaced with the more modern, 1100cc V8. As a result, this car is a bit more potent than the other Opales, although it is still a very capable car. I have driven it a few times, including a couple of days in a race in California. There is no doubt that it would have been a great car for the road, as it has a lot of power and is very comfortable. But it's not a road car, so it doesn't have the handling of a GT. And it isn't a sports car either, because it lacks the power of the GT and the performance of an Opala. So it wasn't really a car that you would want to drive on a daily basis. You would probably want it for a weekend trip, or a special occasion. If you wanted to go to a track day, you might want a Opaline GT for that. Or you could go for an adventure. A road trip would not be a bad idea.

text:
It is actually simple in principle. Porous adsorbents like zeolite and activated carbon can adsorb gases evaporated from the adsorbate water or methanol, etc. giving the cooling effect. Upon being heated, the gas saturated adsorbent bed will give off the gases which are then to be condensed.

The adsorption of gases is a very important aspect of the present invention. The adsoration of gas is not only important for the heating effect, but also for its cooling. In the case of a gas, it is important to know the temperature at which the adhering gas will be heated. If the heat is too high, then the surface of an adhered gas may be damaged. This is especially true if the heated gas has a high vapor pressure. For example, if a heated water vapor is to adorb the water vapour of water, and the vapor pressures are high enough, a surface will form on the liquid water. When the vapours are heated to a temperature of about 100°C, they will condense and form a layer on top of each other. At this temperature, there is no surface to form, so the layer of vapors will not be able to cool. However, at a lower temperature the layers will separate and cool, forming a cooling layer. Thus, in the process of cooling, heat will flow from one layer to another, cooling the entire surface. It is also important that the amount of adsored gas should be sufficient to provide the required cooling effects. A gas which is adsorsed to the same surface as the cooled surface, will have a higher surface area than a similar gas that is adored to an adjacent surface and will therefore have less surface heat. Therefore, adsoring a large amount gas to one surface is

text:
In my opinion, the limited tort option is the best thing Casey has ever done. Basically, limited tort means that you give up your right to sue for pain and suffering, unless one of the following conditions is met 1. Your medical bills resulting from the accident exceed X where X is some number like 50,000 I'm not sure of the exact number 2. The accident was caused by a drunk driver I mean, the OTHER driver was drunk 3. You are permanently disabled You can't sue the other driver for damages because you are disabled.

I'm sure there are other conditions that are not covered by the tort system, but I think that's the most important one. I don't think it's fair to give someone who is disabled the right not to be able to use a car, or to have a disability, and then not give them the same right as someone with a broken leg. It's not fair.

text:
rboudrie chpc.org Rob Boudrie writes... FOR DISCUSSION PURPOSES ONLY On the other hand, if it can be proven, it's possible the changed terms could be thrown out. The question will be whether the agreement contains a merger clause. See UCC 2 202 parol evidence. If we're talking about warranties, then, of course, UCC 2 316 should be looked at. If the terms of the contract are not clear, the court will look at the wording of UPC 2 216 par. 1.2.1.3. It's not a question of whether a contract is enforceable, but whether it is clear. In the case of a warranty, there is no question that the warranty is not enforceible. But if the term is changed, and the new terms are enforceability, that's a different matter. I think the question is whether there's any evidence that a change in the language of an agreement can change the enforceableness of that agreement. And I don't think there was any. So, I would say that, in general, a court should look to the words of any contract to see whether they are clear and unambiguous. That's the way I look.

text:
My friend brought a subaru SVX recently. I had drove it for couples times and I think its a great car, esp on snow. However when she took it to a local Subaru dealer for a oil change, the bill came out to be about 80 dollars. The dealer told us it is because to change the oil filter on a SVX it is necessary to disassemble a metal cover under the engine and that took an hour of labour. We were told that the cost of the filter was about $50.00. So we went to the dealer and asked for the price of a new filter. They told me that it was $80. It was a good price but I was not happy. My friend said that she had a Subaru that had the same problem and she was told it would cost $100. She said she would have to pay for it herself.

I have a friend who has a car that has the problem. He said he had to go to his local dealer to get a replacement filter and it cost him $200. This is a problem that is not common in the USA. If you have the money, go for an oil and filter change.

text:
Most cars have drain petcocks in the radiators, and I've never seen nor heard of a vandal opening one. I imagine that there would be an even lower risk with an oil plug because you have to crawl furthur under the car to open it. Car vandals are usually real traditional in their methods, and do things that don't get them dirty, like keying your car, dumping sand, sugar or mothballs in the gas tank, TPing it, etc.

I've seen a few people try to do this, but they usually get caught. The best way to avoid this is to have a good oil filter, a filter that is designed to filter out oil, not water. If you don' t have one, you can buy one for about $20.00. You can also buy a cheap oil pan that will fit the radiator. It's a little more expensive, about the same price as a new radiator, so you might want to consider that. A good filter will also help you to keep the oil in your engine from getting into the engine compartment. This is a big problem with the newer cars, because the new cars are so much more fuel efficient. So, if you are going to be driving a car that has a lot of miles on it and you want the best possible oil filtering, get a quality filter.

text:
I'm no mustang head, but don't the early ones have a simple strut suspension that is, with no upper A arm? Just a strut going down to a lower control arm single bushing not an A arm, with a tension compression rod locating it in the forward backward direction? Anyway, simple strut suspensions like this can be lowered just by using shorter springs, cutting the springs, lowering the spring perch or shortening the strut below the perch. In each of these cases, the suspension geometry will suffer because the lower control arms will not be at the intended angle. The only way to get the desired suspension angle is to use a longer spring.

The other problem with the earlier Mustangs is that the rear suspension was not designed to handle the weight of the car. It was designed for the front, and the only reason the Mustang was able to do this was because of its rear-wheel drive layout. This meant that it was very difficult to design a suspension system that would handle weight. If you want to know why the Mustang was so successful, it's because it had a very good suspension. But the problem was that this suspension design was too simple. There was no way that a car could handle all the power that was being put out by the engine. So the engineers had to come up with some way of handling the extra weight that they were putting on the chassis. They came up the idea of a rear subframe. A rear frame is a frame that has a separate sub-frame that connects the two. When you have two separate frames, you can have the subframes move around the frame, which is what the designers did. And the result was a much more powerful car than the one that had the original suspension, because now the cars had two independent suspension systems. Now the first thing that you notice is the difference in weight distribution. You can see that in this picture. Notice how the center of gravity is lower on this car, so the body is lighter. Also notice how much of that weight is in front of and

text:
I'm not familiar with the trannies used in Winston Cup, but in the trans am cars I've played with the transmissions were the racing variety, with dog clutches instead of sychros. In a transmission with dog clutches, the gears are always engaged with each other and moving the dog clutches engages the gears to the shafts. Motorcycle transmissions are the same way. Shifting without the clutch on a transmission with syncros can and will cause transmission damage, the only question being how long it takesto grenade something for the trans in my 87 Pulsar SE, it was about 3 5k miles, but it had a weak tranny in the first place. I'm sure there are other trannie types out there, I just don't know about them.

I've been playing with a transexual trancher for a while now, and I have to say, this is the best trany I ever played. I love the way it shifts, especially the shift from first to second. It's so smooth and smooth, you can't even tell it's a trans. The only thing I don' t like about it is that it doesn't have a clutch, so you have no way to get the transmission to shift. But I can live with that. This trancy is so much fun to drive, that I would love to have one of these in every car I own.

If you're going to do this, you'll need a good quality brake fluid. I use Braze-On, but you can use any brand you like. It's a little more expensive, so I'd recommend using a brand that's been around for a while. If you don't have a brake line, I recommend getting a set of brake pads and a new brake master. The pads will last longer, as they're made of a softer material. Also, if your brake system is old, it may need to be replaced. This is a common problem with older systems. A new master will also help with brake fade.

Yes, there is consumer confusion. In the early 80's with the fuel crisis, etc., everyone wanted better fuel mileage. Diesel fuel was the cheapest fuel available and usually provides better mileage than comparable gasoline engines. So, GM decided to conver their 350 gas engine into a diesel engine I think was a 5.7 liter. The engine was designed to be a little more efficient than the gasoline engine. The diesel was also designed for the US market. It was not designed as a performance engine, but as an economical engine for a small family car.

The engine is a four cylinder, four stroke, DOHC, 4 valve, V-8 engine with a displacement of 4,000 cc. This engine has a compression ratio of 10.0:1. There are two carburetors, one in each cylinder. Each carb is connected to a single overhead camshaft. A single cam is used for both intake and exhaust. Both intake valves are located in the intake manifold. Intake valves have a valve guide and a cam guide. Exhaust valves do not have valve guides. They are connected directly to the exhaust manifold and are not connected at all to any other part of the engine or to anything else. These valves allow the air to flow through the cylinder and out the back of each cam. When the cam inlet is closed, the valves open and allow air into the combustion chamber. As the piston moves back and forth, it compresses the gases in and releases them as exhaust gases.

If you don't already know it, you should call the bank credit union finance company that holds the loan on your present car and get the current payoff cost. If you are trading in your current car on the new car, subtract the payoff amount from the trade in the dealer is giving you. If this turns out to be a negative number, you need to reconsider the deal. Subtract this difference from the price of the new car.

If the car is worth more than the amount you paid for it and you want to sell it for more, call your bank and ask for the total amount of your trade-in. This will give you the final price you will pay. The bank will then give the buyer the cash value of their trade. You can then sell the vehicle for what you owe the seller.

text:
Sometimes a bad choke pull off diaphram will cause a car to fast idle. The pull off, which is vacuum actuated, provides a necessary pull in non cold weather conditions to get the idle off the the fast idle cam. Locate the fast idle cam on your vehicle and see if you can rotate it to produce a normal idle. If so, locate the diaphram and test it.

If the pull-off is not working, you may have a problem with the camshaft. Check the timing belt for wear and replace it if necessary.

In fact, if the police officer does not have the legal authority, he is required to give you a warning. However, this is only a verbal warning and you must obey the warning by going back to the original lane. There is no law that says you cannot pass a car on the left, but you should be aware that passing a vehicle on a left is illegal. So, in order to avoid a ticket, it is best to obey all traffic regulations.
