text:
On the cars mentioned 3 series from the late 80's the electronic odometer is really a mechanical drum type odometer, that is driven by pulses from a speed sensor on the rear axle. These pulses are converted into mechanical pulses that turn the odometer and speedometer. No way changing or erasing an eprom is going to change the mileage reading. It also means the odometer is just as easy or hard to change as any other mechanical odometer.

The only way to get rid of the old odometers is to replace them with new ones. This is not a cheap process. The cost of replacing the original odometry is about $100.00. If you are going for a new car, you will need to pay for the new odometric sensor, the replacement of your old one, and the cost to have the car serviced. You will also need a replacement speedo. I have seen a few people who have had their speedos replaced with the same speedometers. They have been able to keep their odographs and have not had to spend any money on replacing them. However, if you have a car that has been servicing for years, it is possible to find a used speed control unit for about the price of a brand new one. A speed controller is a device that controls the speed of an engine. Most speed controllers are made by a company called Speedmaster. Speedmasters are very popular because they are easy to install and easy for you to use. There are many different speed controls available. Some are more expensive than others. For example, a SpeedMaster speed unit is $300. But if your car has a manual transmission, then you may be able find one for $200. So, for most people, replacing your odograph is probably not going be a big deal.

Remember roads in America are NOT designed for speeds above 80 meaning they would be safe at 55 65. Roads like the Autobahn are smoother, straiter, wider and slightly banked. Example A few months back I was traveling late at night 3 00 am or so and I was changing highways at a bent crosssing. It curved off to the south east becoming hidden by trees after about 1,000 ft and continued to the left strait north. I had to slow down to a crawl to avoid hitting the trees. The road was not designed to be used at that speed.

I was able to get to my destination in about 3 hours. This is a good example of how a road can be designed with a higher speed limit. If you are going to drive at 65 mph you should be able get there in 3-4 hours, not 3 days. You can also use the same example to show how the speed limits can change depending on the weather. In the winter the roads are not as smooth and the curves are more pronounced. When the road is wet and slippery the speeds can go up. Also, the width of the highway can increase. A road with the right width can have a lower speed than a narrower road. So, if you want to travel at 60 mph, you need to have the proper width road to do so.

Right. In the thirties both Buick and Packard had two spares mounted in wells in the front fenders. Of course that was back when the front fenders were long enough to provide room. There were a couple of other marques that did this as well, but memory fades.

The first time I saw a Buicks with a spare in a fender was in '69. I was driving a '67 Builliard and I had a friend who was a mechanic. He was working on a car that had been wrecked in an accident. The car was totaled and the owner had to sell it. So he had the car towed to a junkyard. When he got there he found a bunch of old parts and a few spare parts. One of the parts was the spare tire. It was just a small piece of rubber that he cut off and put in his spare. That was it, he said. No one else had ever seen it before. And it was still there when I got to the junks. But I didn't know what it meant. Then I found out that the Buies had spare tires in their ferrules. They were called "spare tires" because they were used to replace the ones that were worn out. This was before the days of "tire pressure" and "pressure gauge" in cars. You could tell if the tire was worn by the way it felt. If it didn´t feel right, it wasn´T going to go on. Nowadays you can tell the difference between a worn tire and one that is just fine. A worn one is going on and you have to change it or replace it with something. On the other hand, a spare tire is fine and it will go

Depending on how you plan to use your SUV, I might recommend also browsing Trailer Boats and one or more of those Pickup, Shotgun, and 4WD magazines. The car rags mostly seem to consider recently graded pea gravel to be offroading and ten sacks of redwood chips to be a bedload. Considering that most of these SUVs seem to be used mostly as robust station wagons, that's probably not a bad approach, but if your applications are more demanding, pick your information sources accordingly. Of the three vehicles on your short list Explorer, 4Runner, Pathfinder, I'd recommend the 4Runner as being closely based on a rather robust pickup and the Explorer for being comfortably carlike.

The Explorer is a good choice for a long-term offroad vehicle. It's a bit more expensive than the other two, though, so you might want to look at the Pathfinder or 4runner. If you're looking for something a little more affordable, the Jeep Wrangler is probably a better choice. I've had the Wranglers for about a year now and they're a great vehicle for off-roader use. They're also a lot more fun to drive than most other SUVS.

prompt: Sorry, but neither 'dictates' the cost. It's a negotiation. Whether it's up front at a honda dealership in an all out dickering war, or more removed on a larger economic scale ie, if saturn can't sell at it's price, the price drops, or the company stops building them , it remains a negotiated value controlled by market forces. To think that the consumer controls price is ludicrous.
text:
Sorry, but neither 'dictates' the cost. It's a negotiation. Whether it's up front at a honda dealership in an all out dickering war, or more removed on a larger economic scale ie, if saturn can't sell at it's price, the price drops, or the company stops building them, it remains a negotiated value controlled by market forces. To think that the consumer controls price is ludicrous.

The consumer is the only one who can control the value of a product. The consumer can only control what they pay for it. If the manufacturer can charge more than the market will pay, then the consumers will not buy it, and the manufacturers will be forced to lower the prices. This is why the Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a good measure of the true cost of goods and services. In the US, for example, a $100 car costs $120 in the CPI, while a similar car in Japan costs only $80. A $200 car is $140 in CPI. So the Japanese car has a higher cost, because it is more expensive to produce. But the car that costs the same in both countries is still cheaper than a car made in America. And the reason is that in a free market, consumers are free to choose the product they want, not the other way around.

The problem is that the transmission is not properly lubricated. It is a common problem with older cars. If you have a transmission that is in good condition, you should not have any problems. However, if you are having problems, the first thing to do is to check the oil level. You can do this by turning the ignition key to the "on" position and then turning it off. Then, turn the key back to "off" and check for oil.If you find that there is oil in the engine, then you need to replace the trans. This is usually done by a mechanic. There are several different types of trans fluid. Some are more expensive than others. For example, a new trans will cost about $200.00. A used trans can be had for about half that price.The best way to determine if the fluid is bad is by looking at the spark plugs. Look for a white ring around the plug. Also, look for any signs of wear. These include: a black ring on the bottom of the plugs, or a ring of black paint around them. In addition, check to see if there are any cracks in either the top or bottom

...
,
The service light will go out if you change the engine oil. If you have the car for a long time, you may not notice it. But if it's a new engine and you've been driving it a while, it will start to get a bit rusty and the light may go off. You can check the condition of your engine by checking the spark plug wires. They should be good. Also check your oil level. A low oil pressure can cause the fuel pump to stop working and cause a fuel leak. Check the coolant level, too. When the temperature is right, the water in the radiator will evaporate and cool the air inside the cooling system. This will help cool your car.

But I do know that diesel engines are not as clean burning as gas.

. but they putout a a much higher amount of carbon monoxide and hydrocarbon emissions. Carbon monoxides are the most dangerous form of pollution. They are formed when the carbon atoms in the fuel are broken down by the heat of combustion. The carbon dioxide is released as a gas, which is then exhaled. Hydrocarbon emissions are produced when fuel is burned. These are also released in a form that is inhaled, but are much less harmful. Nitrous Oxide is a byproduct of the burning of gasoline. It is formed by reacting the nitrogen in gasoline with oxygen. This reaction is very dangerous, as it can cause severe burns. So, if you are driving a diesel, you should be aware of this. If you have a car that runs on gas or diesel and you don´t want to be burned, then you can use a generator to run the engine. You can also use an electric car battery to power the car.

Thanks Julian Visch jsv math.canterbury.ac.nz
text:
I am presently doing a masters thesis to do with traffic intersections in New Zealand but a lot of the books I am researching from, are from America or Australia and so I was wondering if anyone could please tell me what the road rules are in either country with regard to intersections. Thanks Julian Visch jsv math.canterbury.ac.nz

A: The rules in Australia are different from the rules of New South Wales. In New Australia, the driver must yield the right of way to pedestrians and cyclists. The driver of a vehicle must also yield to a pedestrian or cyclist who is crossing the roadway in the same direction as the vehicle.
...
,
The rules for New York are similar to those in NSW. However, in NY, pedestrians are allowed to cross the street in any direction. A pedestrian who has crossed the sidewalk must wait until the pedestrian has passed the intersection before proceeding. If the person has not passed, he must stop and wait. He may not cross in front of or behind a parked vehicle or a moving vehicle, or in a crosswalk. Pedestrians are not allowed on the sidewalks of any street or highway. They must cross at the curb or edge of an intersection.

text:
Back to the F1 stuff for a second, note that the auto' tranny in F1 _STILL_ shifts at the driver's command, not some preselected schedule. The driver still controls the shifting, not the transmission. I have yet to see a torque multiplier installed on a production automobile. Such systems do exist, but none are presently installed in production autos that I am aware of.

The F2 is a different story. It is the only car in the world that has a manual transmission, and it is also the first car to have a clutch pedal. This is not a coincidence. In the early days of the automobile, the clutch was a mechanical device that was used to shift gears. As the car was driven, it would shift to a higher gear, which would then shift the engine to that gear. When the gear was changed, a lever would be pushed to release the lever, allowing the vehicle to be driven again. With the advent of automatic transmissions, this was no longer necessary. Instead, an electronic device would control the shift, with the electronic control being controlled by the computer. Thus, in order to change gears, you would push a button on the console, or you could press a switch on your steering wheel. If you wanted to go faster, push the button again, if you were going slower, press the switch. You could also use the shifter to select a gear and then press another button to switch to it. There was also a "shift" button, where you pressed a small button and the system would change the gears automatically. These days, most cars have electronic shift controls, so the "Shift" and "Select" buttons are no more. They are now used for other functions. For example, when you are in a parking lot, your car will automatically park itself. Or, as you drive down the highway, there

text:
Checker Motors went out of business in 1982. It's hard to get old Checkers that are worth restoring, since almost every one was a fleet vehicle that was driven into the ground. If you can get a body in decent shape the mechanicals should all be available _somewhere_ Checker used whatever parts were around. For instance, I had a Chevy straight six and a GMC Truck radiator and a Ford rear in mine. I also had an old Ford V8 and an Oldsmobile engine. The engine was in good shape, but the radiator was not. So I went to the local auto parts store and bought a new radiator.

I also bought some new parts for the engine and the transmission. They were all in pretty good condition, and I was able to put them back together. But the car was still a little rough around the edges. There were a few small dings and dents in the body, as well as a couple of small cracks in some of the panels. This was the first time I'd ever had to do any work on a car. And I didn't have any experience with it. My first car had been a '67 Chevy, so I knew what to expect. In fact, the only thing I did wrong was to buy a used '68 Chevy. That car is a beast. You can't really tell the difference between a stock '69 and '70. A '71 is just a different car, with a slightly different body.


The car I bought was an '82 Chevy with the original engine, transmission, brakes, suspension, etc. Everything was original except for a small dent in one of my rear windows. (I had the window replaced a year or two ago.) The car also has a cracked windshield. All in all, it's a pretty nice car that I'm glad I got.

text:
I had a similar experience. We had a written quote which had been mailed to us from the salesman at one of these no haggle Toyota dealers for a Camry XLE w ABS, leather, etc. The price seemed fair, but when we went in to take them up on their offer, they discovered that certain extra cost items hadn't been included in their original written quote. It would have totaled an extra 1100 and, in spite of the fact that we had a written quote, they said there was nothing they could do. I was very upset and told them that I would not be returning the vehicle. They said that they would try to get me a new one, and that if I didn't like it, I could just return it.

I was so upset that, after I had returned the car, the dealership called me and said they had found a better price for the same vehicle and would be sending me the new vehicle for free. This was a very upsetting experience for me, as I felt that the dealer had taken advantage of me. text:
W r t performance, converter lockup is purely irrelevant. The lockup only occurs at light throttle settings and serves only to improve MPG. Mind you, a converter clutch does a lovely job of improving MPG, but the additional mechanical advantage of the converter gives you more acceleration vs. locked converter clutch than its inherent losses take away.

The only time I've ever seen a lock up occur is when the clutch is in neutral. In that case, the engine is running at a very high RPM and the transmission is engaged. If the car is not running, then the lock-up will occur. This is a common occurrence in the early days of a car's life. It is also a good indication that the vehicle is being driven at high speeds. I have seen lock ups occur in a number of different situations. For example, when a vehicle has been driven in reverse, or when it has had a flat tire. These situations are not uncommon. However, I do not recall ever seeing a locked up clutch in any of these situations, and I suspect that it is more common than you think.

A catalytically treated engine is one that contains a special catalyst that will not ignite if the catalyst gets wet. These engines are called "dry" catalyzers. They are not as efficient as a wet catalyst, and they are more expensive. However, they do have the advantage of being more reliable. Dry catalytics are also more durable than wet catalyts. Some manufacturers use a mixture of both types. For example, some cars have an engine that uses a dry catalyst and a water-based catalyst. Other cars use both. You can read more about the differences between dry and wet catalysts in this article.

Pocklington's first option is not to sell or to move, but to sell a minority share of the team to realize some of the appreciated value of the team and to get a better arena deal, either in Northlands, or via a new building. Pocklington probably isn't going to get exactly what he wants...but ultimately he will probably get enough, or will sell to someone who will probably get enough.

The second option, which is the one that is most likely to happen, is to simply sell the majority of shares to the public. This is a much more difficult option to pull off, as it requires the approval of at least a majority in each of Northland's three council districts. The city council has already approved the sale of two of those districts, so it is unlikely that they would be willing to approve the third. However, the council could vote to allow the sales to proceed, if they felt that it was in their best interest. If the City Council did vote in favor of selling the shares, it would likely be a very small percentage of all the votes cast, since the vote would only be on the issue of whether or not the Council should approve a sale. It is also possible that a vote could be taken on whether the Northlanders should be allowed to keep the naming rights to their new arena, even if the new ownership group is willing and able to pay for the building and the name. In any case, this is an option that would require the support of both the Mayor and Council, who would have to be convinced that this would benefit the community.

I've never seen a game where one player has committed 5 penalties. Something like this would require more attention by the referee. But you're creating a scoring opportunity where there might not have been one before. I can see the relationship between free throws awarded after a certain number of fouls, but it's obviously easier to score in basketball, there are more opportunities.

"I think it would be a good idea to have a penalty for a foul that is not a free throw. It's not like you can't get a point in a basketball game, it just takes a little bit more time. You can get the ball back, you have to make a play, and you don't have the time to get back to the free-throw line. That's a big part of the game. If you get fouled, the refs are going to call a flagrant foul. They're going have time, they're not going be able to do anything else. So it makes it a lot easier for the players to understand that they have an opportunity to win the possession, to be in the paint, or to go to a spot where they can score. And that's what we're trying to create."

The problem with the NHL is they have a lot of money and a very large fan base. They have the ability to do a great job of showing everything. But they don't have that ability with football. It's called the "Rule of Three." It was first written down in 1894, and it says that if a team has three or more goals in a period, it must win the next three games. That's it. No more. EDT THE PRESIDENT Good morning ladies and gentlemen. It's an honor for me to welcome the University of Maine Black Bears, the winner of the NCAA Division I hockey national championship to the Rose Garden and the White House. I understand from Senator Mitchell that this is the first team from the University of Maine every to win a national championship. And I want to thank the entire team for the tremendous effort that they put into this championship, and I know that the team is very proud of their accomplishments. The team has been a great success. They have won the national title, they have been recognized as the best team in the country, but they are also very excited about the future. We have a lot of work to do. But I think that we can all be proud that our team, our university, has won a championship and that it is now the pride of our state. Now, I would like to talk to you about some of those things. First, we have to recognize the great work that has gone into the preparation of this team. This team was not just a team that was going to play in a tournament. These are the players that are going into college. Some of them are already in college, some are in their first year of college and some have just come out of high school. So, it's a very special group of players. Second, this group has a tremendous amount of talent. There are some very good players on this roster. You know, there are a number of guys that have played in this league. A number have gone to college in other leagues. Others have come from other countries. text:
Unfortunately, that is the way the league is heading... You can't fight, so the only way to retaliate against someone is with a cheap shot when the ref isn't looking. Ulf has brought this to a high level... Players stuck in the past like Neely who prefer fights to cheap shots are at a disadvantage in the new system. Lets face it, A cheap shot like high sticking is a very effective method... It is easier to hide from the refs, has a better chance of causing injury, and you can draw people into fights that way.

The other problem with the old system was that it was very easy to get into a fight. You could get in a brawl with your friends, or you could just get a few cheap hits in. The new one is much harder to pull off. It takes a lot of skill to do it right, but it is very rewarding. I think the best way for players to learn how to fight is to play the game. If you want to be a good fighter, you need to practice. Practice fighting, practice fighting. Don't just sit around and wait for the next fight to come up. Play the games, play them, then practice them. Then practice more. And then more, until you are good enough to take on the toughest opponents.

text: Here are the final stats for the CHL for the 1992 1993 season. Central Hockey League 5840 S. Memorial Drive Suite 205 Tulsa, OK 74145 Phone 918 664 8881 Fax 918 664 2215 Founder and President Ray Miron Commissioner Monte Miron Marketing Director Jim Goodman Information Director Eric Kolb Each team is owned by the league, with local intrests controlling day to day operations. Working agreements and NHL affiliations are up to each team. Each team has a 100,000 salary cap for 17 total players 16 dress up. The CH L is a member of the National Hockey Association. The league is the only one in the United States that has no salary caps. All players are paid on a per game basis. There are no restrictions on the number of players on each roster. Players are not allowed to play for more than one team in a season, and are limited to one year of service. Teams are allowed one goaltender. A team may have up or down to three goaltenders on their roster at any time. In the event of a lockout, the team with the most games played in that season will be awarded the right to select the next goaltender on its roster, subject to the approval of its owner. If a team does not have a goaltender, it may be assigned to another team for a game. For more information on CH l, please contact the Commissioner at 919-664-2215 or email at miron@chl.com. CH League History The first CH league was formed in 1972. It was the first league to have an all-star game, which was held in 1973. Since then, there have been three more all star games, one of which took place in 1974. This year, all of CH's teams will have their own all stars.

After a Flames power play goal the score was 2-2. Flames goalie Mike Vernon was called for a high sticking penalty. He was able get the puck to the net and score the tying goal. prompt: According to what reasonable principle of justice does standing in intimate geographical and psychological relations to a league give one some privileged right to play in it?
text:
According to what reasonable principle of justice does standing in intimate geographical and psychological relations to a league give one some privileged right to play in it?

The answer is that it does not. The principle is not that the league is a "public" institution, but that its members are "private" persons. It is the private right of the individual to be a member of a particular league, and to enjoy the benefits of that membership.
...
"The right is to the exclusion of all others."
It is true that in the case of an individual, the right may be exercised in a manner which is contrary to his interests, or which may injure him. But the principle does apply to all persons, whether they are members of leagues or not, who are in some way connected with the League. If the rights of members were to depend upon the number of their memberships, it would be impossible to maintain that a man could be deprived of his rights by the fact that he had not joined a League, because he was not a part of it. He could not be denied his right, for he could have joined it, if he wished to do so. And if the members had no right in any particular case, they could, in general, be entitled to their rights. This is so even where the member is in no way a party to any contract, as when he is merely a spectator at a game. In such cases, he has no claim to rights, unless he be one of its participants. For the same reason, a person who is an employee of another, is entitled, even though

The Hart Trophy was orginally awarded in a time where people did not think in terms of who was the best player, rather in terms of who was the most valuable to the team. And valuable to his team was not, and should not be, considered synonymous with best. We are talking about a time when honour and attitude, not measurable skills, were the most important assets a player brought to his team, his league and his sport. This was before the onslaught of professionalism which has clearly denigrated what was formerly the foremost peacetime pursuit of glory.

The NHL has been a league that has always been about the players, but it has also been an industry that is increasingly about money. The NHL is a business, a sport, an entertainment industry. It is not a charity. There is no need to be ashamed of that. But it is also a game, one that requires a certain level of skill and a willingness to sacrifice. That is why the NHL needs to change.

Shaver, when asked by his son who was doing the broadcast with him, What will you do now? He replied, "I will be a North Star fan."

The North stars have been a part of Dallas Stars history since the early 1970's, and have won the Stanley Cup three times. They have also been to three straight Stanley Cups, but have never won a championship.

prompt: These new rule changes are great! However, I think that your rules are MUCH too complicated. How will the normal average fan be able to count how many fouls a player has? And then we would even have to remember the names of the players, in order to determine who drew the foul!
text:
These new rule changes are great! However, I think that your rules are MUCH too complicated. How will the normal average fan be able to count how many fouls a player has? And then we would even have to remember the names of the players, in order to determine who drew the foul!

I think the best way to solve this problem is to make the rules simpler. I would like to see the following changes:
.
The foul count is now based on the number of foul shots a team takes. This means that if a foul is called on a shot, the team that took the shot is credited with the fouled shot. If a fouling player is foulled, then the player who foules is not credited. The foul counts are now: FOUL, FOURTH, THREE, TWO, ONE, and zero..
This is a much simpler way of counting foul. It is also much more accurate. For example, if you foul a guy and he shoots a free throw, you will not be credited for the free throws. You will only be charged with foulling the guy. So, this is much better. Also, it is easier to understand. In the past, we had to look at the name of each player to figure out who was fouiling. Now, with this new system, there is no need to do that. We just count the shots. And, since we are counting the same number, that means we can count them all. That is the biggest advantage of this system.

text:
This was a concession to Mansbridge and CBC News, they argued that if you're going to play havoc with the schedule, you should at least make sure that Prime Time is aired as soon as possible. News got a commitment that the post game show would be scrapped and that the network would go to PTN within one minute or so of the game ending. As for the earlier comments about CBC being Ontariocentric frankly the no doubleheader decison goes both ways, people in the West cant see the Leafs and people in Central Canada can't see the Jets game. The reason for the decision was CBC's feeling they couldn't sell advertising for six hours of hockey in one night.

The decision to move the games to the same time slot as the NHL's regular season was made by the CBC, not the league. It was also a decision that was not made in a vacuum. In the past the networks have had to deal with a lot of scheduling conflicts. For example, the NFL has had a scheduling conflict with NBC for years. This year the CFL has been in conflict for a while with CBS and the NBA with TNT. So the fact that CBC was able to get the two games on the air at the exact same times was an important factor in their decision.

text:
Then allow me to enlighten you, Rex. You see, there's a thing called a tie. A tie is worth one point I know, I know. You're not good at math. So, you're going to have to do some math to figure out how many points you need to get to the next level.

So, let's say you have a level 1 character. He's got a +1 to hit, a -1 penalty to AC, and a 1d6 damage die. Now, he's going up to level 2. His character has a 2d8 damage dice, but he has no AC. And he also has an AC of -2. That's not a very good combination. But, if you take a look at the tie chart, it's pretty clear that you can't get any higher than level 3. If you want to go to a higher level, then you'll have have better luck with the dice. The tie will be worth 1 point. It's worth 2 points if your character is a fighter, or 3 points for a wizard. In other words, the more points your tie has, your chances of getting to that next higher tie level are going down. This is why you should always have at least one tie in your inventory. When you get a new tie, take it. Don't just throw it away. Keep it in a safe place. Then, when you reach a certain level in the game, throw that tie away and start over.

text:
That's why we have expansion to create more jobs. NHL teams can't afford to import role players from Europe, they pick the stars but will continue to build their teams around local players. I'd LOVE to see a European NHL division but can't see it happen for some time. There's simply not enough fan interest at the moment in several crucial markets like Germany, Italy and France while Sweden and Finland probably can't afford to shell out 20 30 for tickets the way American Canadian fans do.

I'm not saying that the NHL should be forced to expand. It's a business and the league has to make money. But I do think that if the owners of the teams want to keep the game alive, then they should at least be able to afford the cost of a new arena. The NHL has been in the red for years and it's time to start making some money and not just sit on the sidelines.

I bought another a Canadian at the beginning of the next season, and I still have it. I also have an Easton, that a friend was getting rid off, after giving up the game.

I have two other sticks, one of which I broke in the middle of a game, the other of course, I've been playing with for years. The one I have broken in is a very old one, it's a 6x6x4, with a 1/2" shaft. It's been in my collection for a long time, but I haven't been able to find a replacement.


The other one is an 8x8x3, which is the same size as the 6.5x5.25x2.75 I had. This one has a 3/4" thick shaft, so it is very heavy. My friend got it for me, he's the one who broke it in. He's also a big fan of my game and has been trying to get me to play more. So far, we've only played a couple of games, both of them with him. We've played with the 8 and the 3, as well as a 4x1x7. But I'm not sure if I'll be able play with either of these. They're both heavy, they're not light, or even close to light. And I don't think I can play them at all. If I could, then I would.

He said that he had heard that the Cowboys were moving from Dallas to San Antonio, which is about a 90 minute drive from Oklahoma. This is a pretty big deal, as the Texas Rangers are the only other team in North America that plays in a stadium that is not in their home state. It's a big move, especially for a team that has been in existence for over 50 years. What do you think? I think it's great that they're moving, because it means that there will be a new team, a brand new franchise, that will have to compete with the other teams in this league. And I hope that it will bring in some new fans to the league, who will hopefully be able to support the new Stars team. But I also think that this is an opportunity for the NHL to try to get some more money out of its fans. They're going to have some money to spend, I guess, if they want to.

The Whaler's were led by the play of goaltender Mike McKenna, who stopped all 24 shots he faced. McKenna was the first goaltender to stop 24 or more shots in a game since the NHL began recording the stat in 1967-68. He was also the second goaltender in NHL history to record a shutout in his team's first 8 games of a season, joining the legendary Bob Gainey. In the 8-game span, McKenna stopped a total of 24 of 26 shots. His shutouts were the most by a Whaling goaltender since Gainy stopped 25 in 1972-73.

I have a friend who is a professional hockey player and he said that the octopuses are a symbol of the team. He said they are used as a sign of respect. They are also used in the game to represent the players. The octobot is also a reference to the number of wins the player has. It is used by the fans to show their support for the winning team and the losing team is often referred to as the "Octobots".

The octo-bot is an octocopter, a type of insect that is native to North America. Octopi are small, insect-like creatures that are found in all parts of North and South America, and are often found on beaches and in rivers. Their name comes from the Latin word for "octopus" and "bot" which is derived from "bota" meaning "to fly". The word "Bot" is sometimes used interchangeably with "Ocote" or "Cote". Octobote is Latin for october.

The save % for each game is the percentage of shots that the goalie made that went in the net. For example, if the game was played at 5:00 PM on Sunday, the goalies save% would be 5.00% and the shot % would have to be 50% to get the total number of goals. If the team was playing at 7:30 PM, then the goaltender's save%, shot%, and total shots would all be 100%. The goalie's total save, shot, and shot% totals are listed in parentheses. These numbers are not adjusted for time of game, weather, or other factors. This is a very rough estimate of the numbers that would appear in a newspaper. It is not a complete list of all the goals that have gone in in any given game. There are many games in which the goaltenders did not make a save. In those cases, I will list the number that was not made. Also, there are games where the teams did score a goal, but the other team did as well. That is, they scored a shot on net, a rebound, etc. So, for example if a team scored two goals, one on a power play, another on an empty net goal. ,
The Red Wing's top prospect, Dylan Larkin, is a very good player. But he's only 19 years old. The Wings are not going to give him a long-term contract. If he does, he'll be a restricted free agent next summer. So, the question is, what is the value of a young player like Larkins? Is it worth the risk? I don't think so. Larkson is not a top-six forward. His game is more of an offensive one. And, I'm sure he has a lot of potential. However, if he doesn't develop, it's going be very difficult for the team to keep him. It's a risk. A very risky one, in my opinion.

prompt: It's just as meaningless to compare goals, assists, PIM and any other stat I can think of. Each player is asked to take a unique role for his team. The contexts will never be the same from one player to another playing on the same team or different teams. And yet ... awards are given and promotions received based in part on these meaningless stats.
text:
It's just as meaningless to compare goals, assists, PIM and any other stat I can think of. Each player is asked to take a unique role for his team. The contexts will never be the same from one player to another playing on the same team or different teams. And yet... awards are given and promotions received based in part on these meaningless stats.

The NHL is a league that is built on parity. It's a game that rewards players who can score goals and take penalties. But it's also a sport that's built around the idea that the best players are the ones who are most willing to sacrifice for their team and the fans. That's why the NHL has a salary cap. Players are paid based on their performance on a nightly basis. They're paid for the number of games they play. If they're not playing well, they don't get paid. Period. No exceptions. So when a player like Sidney Crosby or Evgeni Malkin is paid $10 million a year, it doesn't mean that he's not worth it. He's worth $9 million. Or $8 million, or $7 million... whatever the cap number is. Because he plays for a team that has the resources to pay him that much.

The NHL Standings for the week of March 27-April 2, 2013. The standings are based on a weighted average of the games played by each team. This is just a list of teams that have played at least one game. There are no ties.

prompt: Apparently, the public workers' strike in St John's, Newfoundland is over. The strike has, since mid January, forced the St John's Maple Leafs hockey team to play their home games in other cities such as Toronto, Cornwall and Charlottetown. They have been playing their playoff home games in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Leafs' management said that they COULD return to St John's for the second round.
text:
Apparently, the public workers' strike in St John's, Newfoundland is over. The strike has, since mid January, forced the St John's Maple Leafs hockey team to play their home games in other cities such as Toronto, Cornwall and Charlottetown. They have been playing their playoff home games in Halifax, Nova Scotia. Leafs' management said that they COULD return to St John's for the second round.

The strike was called by the Newfoundland and Labrador Public Service Employees Union (NLPSU) after the union refused to accept a contract offer from the Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment (MLSE) that would have reduced the salary of the president of their bargaining unit by $1,000. This was in addition to the $2,500 salary that the NLPSUs president received. In addition, NLPLU president Bob McLeod was also given a $500 bonus. NLPGU President Bob McCallum said, "We are disappointed that our members have had to take this action. We are committed to working with the MLSE to resolve this matter."
...
"The union has been working hard to negotiate a fair contract for our employees," said NLPCU Vice President, Bob MacLeod. "The NLPUF has made it clear that it will not accept any contract that does not include a reduction in the salaries of our president and vice president." "This is a very difficult time for all of us," added NLPPU General Secretary, John McCauley. He said the strike is "a very serious matter for us." NLPPU President John McLean said he is disappointed with what he called the "unfair" contract offered by MLSEA. Mr. Mclean said "we are not going to be bargaining in good faith." He added that he was "very disappointed" that NLPEU has not accepted the offer.

The problem ESPN2 faces is the TCI Cablevision connection in the merger of their Prime and SportsChannel networks. This is a problem that will need to be solved before the launch of ESPN.

The other issue is that ESPN is not a cable channel. It is an ESPN channel that is available on the internet. There is no cable company that would want to carry ESPN on their network. So the only way to get ESPN to the cable provider is to have them carry the channel on a pay TV channel like ESPN3. That is why the deal with ESPN was made. If the network is going to launch on cable, it will have to go through the same process as any other cable network that has launched on pay television.

prompt: I was playing this golf game and something interesting happened. On the 7th hole, I drove the ball down the fairway, when the ball was in mid flight, the game completely froze. text:
I was playing this golf game and something interesting happened. On the 7th hole, I drove the ball down the fairway, when the ball was in mid flight, the game completely froze. A couple seconds later, the screen went completely black, with an error message in large Bubble letters that said DIVISION BY ZERO. I thought it was funny considering I am a computer programmer, and I had never seen an error like this on an actual video game system like Sega or Nintendo or even Atari or Intellevision years ago. I was so confused, that I didn't even know what to do.

I went to the console and tried to turn it off, but it wouldn't turn off. It was still on, so I turned it on and it worked. The game was working, it just froze, like it had been turned off and then turned back on. So I went back to my computer and started looking for the error. After a few minutes, my screen was back up and running, except it wasn't the same game. This time, there was a message saying "DIVIDENCE BY ONE" and a picture of a man with a gun. My heart sank. What the hell was going on?
...
The next day, after I got home, a friend of mine told me that he had seen the message on the Sega Genesis. He said that it said "Division by Zero" on it. When I asked him what the "zero" meant, he said it meant that the computer was not working. That was the first time I ever heard of this error, which I still don't understand. But I did know that this was something that could happen to me. And I knew that if I could get the system working again, then I would be able to play the golf games again.

text:
Hi. According to my always questionable newspaper, there's a silver dollar being minted in Canada, the back of which commemorates the anniversary of the Stanley Cup. Now, I know full well what coins are used every day in Canada. I can easily fish a few out of my pocket change right now, in fact. But I'm not sure what the silver dollars are.

I'm sure you can find them on eBay, but I don't know if they're worth anything. And I doubt that they are, because they don.t look like the ones I've seen in the past. They're not even the same ones. The one I have is a little bit smaller than the one you see in my photo. It's not the exact same coin, either. So, what's the deal?
...
 the coin is made of silver, and it's made in China. That's where it came from. If you look at the image, you'll see that it has a lot of detail. There's even a small engraving on the front. You can see the date on it. This is the first time I ever saw a coin with a date. In fact, it was the only time. When I was a kid, my dad would always tell me that the year was always the wrong one. He'd say, "The year is always wrong." I'd always say that was true. Then, one day, he showed me a picture of a Canadian coin. "That's what I said," he said. Well, that's how I learned about the Canadian dollar.

Also Mark Messier was captain of the Edmonton Oilers when he was traded to New York. How about Dale Hawerchuk with Winnipeg when he was traded to Buffalo, was he captain too? I think so.

The NHL has a rule that states that a player cannot be traded without the consent of his team. If a team does not consent to a trade, the player is not allowed to be sent to another team until the trade is approved by the league. The NHL also has rules that state that if a club does trade a captain, that player must be given a chance to prove himself. This is called a "retirement" period. During this period, a new captain must prove his worth to the team by playing in at least one game. A player can be suspended for up to two games for violating this rule. In the case of a suspension, he is allowed one day off per week. He can also be fined up until $5,000.00.

The NHL has been in flux for a while now. It's been a long time since the last major shakeup, when it moved the Stanley Cup from the Eastern Conference to the Western Conference. That move was made in order to make the playoffs, which the Stars did not do. Now, the League is trying to figure out how to keep the Cup in Dallas, where it has played since 1967. There are a lot of factors that go into the decision to move the cup, including the cost of moving it, how much it will cost to maintain it in Texas, what the fans will want to watch, etc. So, it seems like the best way to go about this is to have the Dallas Stars play the New Jersey Devils in New Year's Eve. If the two teams play, then the winner will move on to play in their first-round series against the Los Angeles Kings. This would be a great way for the teams to meet up and see who is the better team.

Bowman is in the Hockey Hall of Fame as a coach already...and unlike Gil Stein...he didn't get their by stacking the Board of Directors! Bowman is the genius...Johnson isn't. Bowman is a great coach...Johnson, a very good one. However, Bowman is really not a modern coach, and Patrick's solution of having him only run the team on game days, and delegate most of the day to day responsibity to the assistants is a shrewd managerial decision on Patrick's part.

The problem is that Patrick is not the coach. He is an assistant coach who is supposed to be the head coach of a team. The problem with that is, he is also the assistant head of staff. That means that he has to run a staff that includes the players, the coaches, scouts, etc. And he does not have the time to do that. So, Patrick has been forced to hire a head coaching staff, which is what he did with the Coyotes. It is very difficult to have a full staff of coaches and players. You have to make sure that you have enough time for all of them to get to know each other, to learn from each others' mistakes, so that they can learn and improve. This is why Patrick hired a new head scout, who has a lot of experience in this area. But, it is still a problem. Patrick needs to find a way to keep the staff together, while also having enough staff time. If he can't do this, then he will be in trouble. I think that the best solution is to let Patrick hire his own staff and let him run it. Then, when he needs a few days to rest, or to go to a game, that staff can be brought in. In the end, I don't think Patrick will have any problems.

Lloyd Pettit. Yes, it is true that he refused to buy a franchise from the NHL for 50M but at the time the reason was that the established market for teams was much less than that. He felt that no one would pay 50M for an expansion team, and that he would simply wait to buy an existing franchise for less than that. But the market fooled him, and 5 teams have been created for 50M apiece in the last three years, and even the existing teams can't be moved for less than 50M and I doubt that he could get one for that little.

So, the question is, what is the best way to get a team for the right price?
...
 the answer is to go to the owners and ask them to give you a 50% share of the team. This is a very simple way of getting a new team and it will work. The owners will be very happy to do this, because they will get to keep the money they have already invested in their teams. They will also get the opportunity to sell the franchise to a buyer who will pay them a fair price. If the owner is willing to pay a price that is less that 50%, then he will have a better chance of selling the club to someone who is more willing and able to spend. And if the buyer is not willing or able, then the new owner will not be able or willing enough to make the deal work, so the old owner gets to stay on as the majority owner. It is very easy to see how this works. You have the current owners, who are willing, able and willing. Now you have two new owners who have no interest in buying the teams, but are interested in selling them. One of them will want to be the minority owner, while the other will like to have his own team in a market that has a lot of interest. The best thing about the NHL is that it's a team sport. It's not a league where you can just go out and score goals and win. You have to work for it. And you have a lot of guys who are really good at it, but they don't get the credit they deserve. They're not the guys that are going to win the Stanley Cup. But they're the ones that get to play in front of their home fans and they get a chance to be on TV and get paid a little bit more than the other guys. So, I think that's the biggest thing. The other thing is, you know, the players are so good that they can't be replaced. If you look at the last couple of years, there's been a couple guys come up and do really well, like [Alex] Ovechkin and [Jonathan] Toews, who were really, really great players. Then there are guys like me, [Drew] Doughty, Patrick Kane, those guys are all great. There's no replacement for those players, so I'm just happy to get an opportunity to do what I do.

Like many others I too was watching the Caps Isles game when the went to the baseball game. I too was pissed. How could they interupt such an important game. I understand about contracts, but you would think they would have a clause in the contract concerning important games! I was so pissed I went and got a ticket to see the game and I sat in my seat. The game was over and the fans were leaving. As I walked out of the stadium I saw a man sitting in his seat with his arms crossed. He was a very angry looking man.

I asked him what was wrong. "I just got off the phone with the team and they told me they are going to cancel the season." He said. Then he said "They are not going back to their old stadium." I asked if he was sure. His answer was "Yes."
...
"I am not sure what to do." he told the guy. So I told him to go to his car and get a new ticket. When he got to my car he asked me if I wanted to buy a season ticket for him. My answer to him was no. But he insisted. And I said I would. We talked for a while and he finally said he would give me a refund. That was the last I heard of him for the rest of that season. It was not until the next season that I got another ticket and that was when I learned that the man had been fired.

I am sure you are aware that the NHL has a rule that states that if a player is hit in the head by a puck, the player must be checked to the ground. This rule is in place to prevent head injuries. The rule does not apply to hits to a goaltender. If a goalie is struck in a head-on collision, he is not required to be taken to ground, but he must immediately be examined by the referee. There is no rule stating that a hit to an opponent's head is a penalty. However, if the hit is to his head, it is. And if it's to their head and they are not checked, they get a major penalty and the game is over. So, in my opinion, this is an unnecessary rule.

The Sabres were down 3-0 in the series, and the game was tied at two in overtime. The Bruins were up 3 games, but the score was still tied. It was time for a shootout. And the shootout was going to be a long one. A shootout that would last for over an hour. That's how long it took for Buffalo to score. They scored on their first shot, a power play goal by Patrice Bergeron. Then they scored again on the second shot. Bergerons third shot was blocked by the goalie, who was not happy about it. He was furious. But the third goal was scored. Boston won 3 to 2. This was it, this was their moment. Their moment to win the Stanley Cup. To win it for their fans. In the end, they did. After the final buzzer sounded, Boston fans were in tears. Some were crying. Others were cheering. There was no doubt in their minds. "We did it," they said.

He made no bones about it, the expansion to 28 is on permanent hold until he is satisfied that the current allotment of 26 are fully stable. The NHL is a business, and the league is not going to be able to afford to keep all of its teams in one place. The league has to make a decision on expansion, but it is going be a tough decision. It is also going take a lot of time. I think it will be at least a year before we know if the NHL will expand to 30 teams.

1993 1994 NHL Hockey Pool By Denis Papp and Chris Stoochnoff Rules Pick 17 players 3 LW, 3 C, 3 RW, 3 LD, 3 RD, 2 Goalies You may pick ANY 17 players from any team. Points for players are as follows 1 point per goal 1 point per assist 1 point per 10 PIM Points for goalies are as follows 2 points per win 1 point per tie 1 point per assist 1 point per 5 PIM 2 points per shutout 100 points per goal Entries Entries can be sent by mail or ascii text file to Chris Stoochnoff or Denis Papp on Hard Wired BBS 434 7996. Due date for entries is the first day of regular season play. After that, no more entries will be accepted unless it is just slightly late. The deadline for all entries to be received is midnight on the last day to enter. If you have any questions, please contact Chris at chris@hardwired.com.

The NHL is pleased to announce the NHL Pool by Denis and Christopher Stoopnickoff. This is a great way to get your team into the playoffs. It is also a fun way for you to play some pool. You can pick any 17 NHL players and play against them. Each team has a maximum of 3 players. There are no points for goals, assists, or points. Players are assigned to their team based on their position on your roster. For example, if you are playing a team with 3 defensemen, you will assign them to your defense. Your team will have a total of 17 points, and you can play any of the 17 teams. All players on a given team are considered to belong to that team, so if a player on another team is on that same team as you, they will not be able to join your pool game. In addition, the pool is not a tournament. Teams are not allowed to change their lineup after the game is over. Any player who is removed from a game will forfeit their points and will receive a loss. A player can only be removed once per game, but if they are removed for any reason, their point total will count against their total for the entire season.

I think the biggest problem is that the leagues are so different. In Europe, there are leagues that are very competitive, like the Bundesliga, La Liga, Serie A, etc. But in North America, we have leagues like MLS, NASL, USL, PDL, NPSL. There are no leagues in Canada, Australia, or New Zealand. So, it is hard to compare leagues. It is also hard for the fans to understand the difference between the two leagues, because they are not used to the different leagues and they don`t know what to expect. For example, in MLS you have to pay to watch a game, whereas in NASL you don�t have that. You have no idea what is going on. And the MLS teams are more expensive than the NASL teams. "The NHL's top assistant coaches are getting paid more than their counterparts in other sports," said NHL deputy commissioner Bill Daly. "That's a good sign for the future of hockey in Canada."
In the past, Daly said, assistant coaching salaries were "very low." But the NHL has been working to raise the salaries of assistant hockey coaches, who are paid a base salary of $50,000 to $60,00 per year. The NHL also has a salary cap for assistant players, which is $1.5 million per team.

I'm in Edmonton, and while that's usually or at least OFTEN the case, here we were treated to the actual ABC telecast of the Kings Flames game. I'm with whoever said it earlier Don Witless er, Whitman is a poor commentator, and not just for hockey. Normally, if the Oilers were still playing augh, I would turn off the sound and listen to the radio broadcast to get decent play by play announcing. But this time, I was so engrossed in the game that I didn't even notice the announcers.

I was also impressed with the fact that the announcer was not only able to keep up with what was going on, but also to make it sound like he was actually talking to his audience. He was able, for example, to say "the Oilers are up 2-0" and "they're up 3-1" without sounding like a complete idiot. It was a nice touch. The only thing that was really lacking was the commentary from the players. They were all talking about the same things, which was fine, because I don't think they were talking at all. There was no real sense of urgency, no sense that they needed to do anything. And I think that is the biggest problem with hockey commentary. You can't really tell what's going to happen, you can only guess. So, when you're watching a game, it's hard to know what to expect. If you watch a hockey game and you don
't know who's playing, what the score is, or what is happening on the ice, then you are going into the broadcast with a lot of assumptions. That's why I love the NHL, they are so good at making you feel like you know the team you just watched.

The NHL has been a league that has always been about parity. It's a fact that the NHL is the most competitive league in North America. There are no teams that are better than the other teams. That's why the league is so successful. But the fact is that there are always going to be teams who are going up against each other. And that's what makes the game so exciting. "I am not a lawyer, but I am a former prosecutor. In my opinion, the law is clear that a person who makes a false statement to a police officer is guilty of a felony. This is not an exaggeration. If you are a prosecutor, you will know that the statute of limitations for a crime is three years. So, if you make a mistake, it is very difficult to prove it. But if the police officers are wrong, they are guilty. They are not innocent. That is the way the system works."

The statement is completely false and defamatory. There is no such thing as a "false statement" to an officer. A false report is one that is made to police, not to any other person. As a matter of fact, there is nothing in the criminal code that requires a report to be made by a law enforcement officer to anyone other than the person making the report. Therefore, a criminal charge is never brought against a citizen who reports a violation of the laws of this country. No one is ever charged with a misdemeanor for reporting a traffic violation. text:
In the interests of saving badnwidth during this heated time of the year viz. the early flurry of retard comments coming from a certain state whose name starts with P and ends with A, why don't you tell us something we don't already know? George Orwell's 1984 is a classic example of a dystopia. It is not a good book, but it is an example.

The book is about a totalitarian state, where the people are controlled by a single authority, the state. The state is the only authority that can be trusted to keep the citizens safe. Orwell wrote the book in the 1930s, and it was published in 1949. In the 1950s the Soviet Union was in a state of collapse, so Orwell was writing about the end of an era. He was not writing in an age of freedom, he was just writing a book about totalitarianism. And he wrote about it in such a way that it would be impossible to imagine a world without it. So, in 1984, there is no freedom. There is only the tyranny of those who control the means of communication. That is what Orwell meant by the word totalitarian. But, of course, it's not just the totalitarian government that controls the media. We have a lot of other totalitarian governments, too. They control our schools, our universities, even our churches. All of these are totalitarian institutions. If you want to know what totalitarian means, just look at the way the government controls our media, which is why we have to be careful about what we say and what our thoughts are. Because if we are not careful, we will be controlled.

text:
The top 11 teams of this tournament will play in the Olympics next year. The last team of this tournament, top two of pool B Great Britain and Poland and the winner of pool C Latvia will play for the last Olympic spot next fall. However, if next year's hosts Norway were to finish 12th which would be no surprise, then it's the 11th team of pool A that will have to play in the qualification tournament.

The qualification process for this year is very similar to last year, with the top four teams from each pool playing in a single elimination bracket. Pool A will be played on the first day of the tournament and Pool B will take place on day two. In the quarterfinals, the teams will face off against each other in best of three matches. If the match ends in an all-out tie, then the team with more points will advance to the semifinals. This year the winners of these matches will qualify for Rio.

Actually, both numbers are correct. The difference is in the direction of the acceleration. For pilots, accelerations tend to be transverse to the direction you're facing pulling out from a steep dive, the acceleration will force blood toward your feet, for instance. In this case, you can only put up with about 8 g's even with a pressure suit.

The other thing to note is that the pressure suits are designed to keep you from getting too hot. If you were to get too close to a hot surface, your body would heat up and you'd be unable to breathe. This is why you don't see people wearing pressure gloves in hot weather. It's also why the suits don´t have a heat shield. You can't get hot enough to burn yourself.

From the Pluto Fast Flyby Instrument definition research anouncemnet, the instrument payload constraints are Mass allocation 7 kilograms 15.4 lbs Power allocation 6 watts Required instruments Visible imaging system 1024x1024 CCD, 750 mm fl, f 10 optics IR mapping spectrometer 256x256 HgCdTe array, 0.3 energy resolution UV spectrometer 55 200 nm, 0.5 nm resolution Radio science ultrastable oscilator incorporated in telecom system ultrastable means 10 14. This doesn't leave much room for payloads which are totally unrelated to the mission of the spacecraft. In addition, the power will come from a radioisotope thermal generator, and the whole space craft will be about 2 feet in diameter, with no booms, which means there will be strong gamma lines from Pu 239 and associated schmutz in the background, which tends to reduce sensitivity somewhat. It would still be nice, and our group here at Goddard is looking in to it.

The spacecraft is designed to be a small, low mass, high power, small mass spacecraft, so it will have a very low power requirement. The spacecraft will not be able to operate in a vacuum, but it should be possible to use a large vacuum chamber to provide the necessary power. We are looking at a power of about 1 watt per square centimeter, or about 0,5 watts per cubic centimetre. That is a lot of power for a spacecraft of this size, especially when you consider that the solar panels will provide about 5 watts of solar power per kilogram of mass. So, we are going to need a good deal of energy to get the science done. There are a number of ways to do this, including using a solar sail, a nuclear reactor, an ion thruster, etc. But, in this case, it is going be very difficult to make the system work. The problem with Commercial Titan is that MM has made little or no attempt to market it. They're basically happy with their government business and don't want to have to learn how to sell commercially. A secondary problem is that it is a bit big. They'd need to go after multi satellite launches, a la Ariane, and that complicates the marketing task quite significantly.

The other problem, of course, is the cost. Commercial satellites are expensive. The cost of a commercial satellite launch is about $1.5 billion. That's a lot of money. It's also a big chunk of the budget of an entire satellite constellation. If you're going to launch a satellite, you need a launch vehicle that can carry it to orbit. Titan has a single stage, which is why it's so expensive, but it also has two stages. One of them is used for the first stage and the other is for a second stage. So the total cost is $2.2 billion, or about the same as a Delta IV Heavy. But the price is only $500 million per satellite. And that's not including the launch vehicles. In fact, the Titan launch costs are about half of what they cost to build a new Delta. (The Delta is an expendable launch system, meaning it can be reused for multiple missions.)
...
It's hard to see how Titan can compete with the Delta, especially when you consider that the Falcon 9 is already a very capable launch platform. SpaceX has already launched a number of satellites, including a couple of commercial satellites. There's no reason to think that Titan will be any less capable. I think the real question is whether Titan's price will make it a viable option for commercial customers.

Much of Cook's later exploration was privately funded, by Joseph Banks among others eg in Resolution the earlier Endeavour. Colnett's voyage to the Galapagos was substantially privately funded by the owners of British whaling vessels. Chancellor and Willoughby were privately funded by London merchant companies in their voyages to Muscovy. The list is almost endless.

The British government was also involved in the early stages of the exploration. In 1825, the British Admiralty commissioned the first of a series of scientific expeditions to explore the Pacific. These expediements were funded in part by private donations. One of these expediments was the "Mauritius Expedition" which was led by Sir William Cook. This expedition was funded entirely by a private donation from the family of Sir John Cook, who had been a member of Parliament. Sir Cook was a very wealthy man and had a large estate in Mauritius. He was very interested in exploring the islands and was particularly interested with the possibility of finding gold. His son, Sir George Cook (who was later to become the Governor of Mauritian territory) was an avid explorer and explorer's son. It was Sir James Cook who was responsible for the naming of many of his expedients. For example, Cook named the island of New Zealand after his father. Cook also named many islands after himself. Among the names he named were Cook Islands, New Guinea, and Cook Island. Other names that he gave were the Cooks, Cairns, Cape Horn, etc. Many of those names were later used by other explorers. Some of them were also used in later expedient names.


Cook's first voyage was to Mauritania in 1826. On this voyage he found the largest gold mine in history. However, he was not able to find the gold because of bad weather.

text:
If I'm not mistaken, this is the usual sort of precaution against loss of communications. That timer is counting down continuously if it ever hits zero, that means Galileo hasn't heard from Earth in a suspiciously long time and it may be Galileo's fault... so it's time to go into a fallback mode that minimizes chances of spacecraft damage and maximizes chances of restoring contact. I don't know exactly what all Galileo does in such a situation, but a common example is to switch receivers, on the theory that maybe the one you're listening with has died.

The problem is that the Galileo is a very large spacecraft, and the only way to get a signal from it is by sending a radio signal. The problem with sending radio signals is, of course, the fact that you can't get the signal back. So you have to send a message, which is what the radio is for. But the problem here is not that Galileo has lost contact with Earth, it has just lost the ability to communicate with it. It's not a problem that it can no longer communicate, because it still has the same radio transmitter. What it needs to do is send out a new message. And that's what it does. In fact, if you look at the data, you'll see that when Galileo first lost communication with the Earth it sent out an "I'm sorry, I can only send you this message" message and then it switched to a "We're sorry we can not communicate" one. This is because the spacecraft is in orbit around Jupiter, so the signals from the planet are very weak. If you send an Earth-based message to Galileo, then the message will be received by the satellite, even if the communication is lost. However, when the Jupiter-bound Galileo switched from "we're Sorry we Can't Communicate" to "sorry we cannot communicate", it was sending out the "Sorry we're not able to" signal, not the original "It's Sorry We Can Not Communicates" or "it's sorry

However, the down time was estimated to be a year servicing, checkout, sceheduling and training another shuttle, orbit verification... and to be quite expensive. I think it may have been more a mental exercise than a real plan. Don't know. But I do know that the shuttle program is not going to go away. It is going through a period of transition. The shuttle is a very complex system. There are a lot of moving parts. And the program has to make sure that it has the right people in place to do the job. So I don't think that there is any reason to think the next shuttle mission will be any different than the last one. We are going into a new phase of the space program. This is the first time in a long time that we have a program that is so complex that you have to have people who are really good at it. They have got to understand the whole system and how it works. That is what we are trying to accomplish. If we can do that, we will have the best crew in the world. You can't have that if you don`t have good people. In the end, I am not sure what the future holds. What I know is that I have no doubt that this program will continue. NASA is committed to the mission and the people involved.

The next Shuttle mission is scheduled for launch in December of 2001.

Any lunar satellite needs fuel to do regular orbit corrections, and when its fuel runs out it will crash within months. The orbits of the Apollo motherships changed noticeably during lunar missions lasting only a few days. It is possible that there are stable orbits here and there the Moon's gravitational field is poorly mapped but we know of none. The Moon is a very large object, so it is not surprising that it has a large gravitational pull. This is the reason why the lunar surface is so smooth and flat. There is no gravity on the surface of a moon, it just is. If you were to stand on a surface that was not smooth, you would feel a pull on your feet. However, the gravity of an object is proportional to its mass. So if you are standing on an Earth-sized object with a mass of 1.5 million tons, then the gravitational force is 1/1.6 million. That is, if the object was a small marble, its gravitational effect would be 1,000 times greater than if it were a marble of Earth's mass, which is about 1 million times smaller. In other words, a lunar object would have a gravitational influence on you that is 100 times stronger than the Earth. A lunar moon is also much larger than Earth, but it does not have the same gravitational impact. For example, an asteroid of about the size of Mars would exert a force of 100, 000,00,0000 times that of our Moon. But an Apollo moon would only exert about 10, 00, 01, 100.000, or 10 times less than that. Therefore, we can conclude that the moon's gravity is much weaker than our own.

The idea was to use a large structure that could carry an array of lights like the Goodyear Blimp has. Only our collective disapproval of cluttering up space with such a thing stopped us from pursuing it. But the idea of a space billboard is not entirely new. In the early 1960s, the United States Air Force was considering a similar project. The Air National Guard was also considering using a blimp to advertise the military's presence in space. A blimps would have been a much more effective way to reach the public than a billboard.

The Air Guard's proposal was rejected because it would require a huge amount of money to build and maintain the blip. It would also have required a lot of time and effort to operate. And it was not clear that the Air Defense Command would be willing to pay for the project, given that it had no space program. So the proposal went nowhere. However, in the late 1960's, a small group in Washington State was working on a plan to put a satellite in low earth orbit. They called it the Space Shuttle. This was a very different idea from the one proposed by the USAF. Instead of using the space shuttle to carry a message, they would use it to launch a payload into space and then return it back to Earth, where it might be used to broadcast a commercial message. Their plan was called the Shuttle Orbiter. As the name suggests, this was an orbiter that would orbit the Earth and return to the surface. There was no need for a rocket to get it there. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. text:
The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.

The NORad two-line element set is updated every day, with the exception of the first day of each month. This is to ensure that the elements are not lost or corrupted during the flight. If the two lines are lost, they are replaced with a new line. For example, if the second line is lost on a flight, it is replaced by the third line, which is the same as the original line but with one stop. In addition, a second stop is added to each line to prevent the line from being lost. A second-stop is also added for each satellite in the system, to allow for redundancy. These two stop bits are used to determine the position of a satellite. When the stop-bit is set, all satellites in a line are in their correct position. However, when the start-bits are set to zero, then the satellites are at their current position, regardless of whether the end-Bit is zero or not. Thus, in order to maintain the correct positions of all the spacecraft, two stops are added. Each satellite is assigned a unique stop, so that if one satellite moves, another satellite will not be affected. Also, each stop has a different start bit. Therefore, for example if a stop was set at zero and the other satellites were at the beginning of their stop sequence, one of them would be at its stop position and another would not, even if they were in different positions.


NORAD Two Line Element Set

April 23, 1993 Phone 202 358 1780 Kyle Herring Johnson Space Center, Houston Phone 713 483 5111 RELEASE 93 76 HUBBLE TELESCOPE SERVICING MISSION SCHEDULED FOR ELEVEN DAYS The December flight of Endeavour on Space Shuttle mission STS 61 to service the Hubble Space Telescope HST has been scheduled as an 11 day mission designed to accommodate a record five spacewalks with the capability for an additional two, if needed. The decision to schedule five extravehicular activities, or EVAs, was reached following extensive evaluations of underwater training, maneuver times required using the Shuttle's robot arm based on software simulations and actual EVA tasks on previous missions. Basically what we've done by going to five EVAs rather than three is to repackage our margin so that we have the capability to respond to the dynamics, or unknowns, of spacewalks, Mission Director Randy Brinkley said. It improves the probabilities for mission success while providing added flexibility and adaptability for reacting to real time situations. "We've been able to do this because we're able now to have a more flexible mission plan," Brinker said, "and we can respond more quickly to changes in the environment." The five-day EVAS will be conducted on the ST-61 mission, which is scheduled to launch on a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Florida, on Dec. 8. ST 61 is the first flight to use the Space Launch System (SLS) and the Orion spacecraft. NASA is using ST61 to test the SLS and Orion, and to demonstrate the ability of the vehicle to perform a variety of missions, including the servicing of Hubble. In addition to servicing the telescope, the mission will also test a new docking system for the space station. A total of five astronauts will participate in ST S 61, with two on board the shuttle and two aboard the station, as well as two ground controllers. Mission controllers will monitor the astronauts' activities and provide guidance and control for their activities. They will provide the crew with a live video feed of their spaceports and will communicate with them via telemetry and telecommand. During the EVAP, astronauts and ground control will perform spacelab activities to prepare the spacecraft for its return to Earth. After the spaceport activities are completed, ST s 61 will return the orbiter to a landing pad at the Kennedy Space Centre in Florida. So, the idea of merging neutron-star is a bad idea.

A super massive blackhole would not have had time to do that. The first thing to note is that the term "Native American" is not a term of endearment. It is a derogatory term that has been used to describe people of European descent for centuries. The term is derived from the word "natives" which is the name given to people who are not native to a particular place. This is why the Native Americans of the American West were called "Indians" and not "Natives."
"Native Americans" was a pejorative term used by Europeans to refer to those who were not Native to their respective lands. "Indian" came to be used as a slur against people from Europe, and was used in the same way. Native people were considered to have no culture, no language, nothing to do with the land they lived on. They were seen as "savages" who lived in a different world. As a result, the European settlers of North America were often referred to as the "First Americans." The word was also used for the people living in Europe who had no connection to North American Indians. These people, called the Celts, were referred as being "barbarians." In fact, they were so despised by the Europeans that they had to flee to America. Today, we would call them "white people." This was the reason why they fled to Europe.
