text:
I didn't want to quote all the stuff that's been said recently, I just wanted to add a point. The whole question of a right to a dark sky revolves around the definition of a right. Moral rights and natural rights are all well and good, but as far as I can see, a right is whatever you or someone representing you can enforce. In most civilizations, the government or the church or both defines what the rights of the citizens are, and then enforces those rights for them.

The problem is that the right of people to have a natural right does not mean that they have the same right as the state or church. It is a different thing. A natural law right, for example, is something that is not subject to the laws of any government. If you have an individual right that you cannot enforce, then you are not a citizen of that state. You are a subject of it. That is why the natural laws are so important. They are the foundation of all rights. Without them, there is no right at all. So, if you want a law that says that people have to be able to see the stars, that means that there must be a legal right for people in that society to do that. And that right must not be subject, in any way, to any laws that are made by the people who are supposed to enforce it, because that would be an infringement on their natural and individual rights, which is what a state is. But if the law says, "You have this right," then that law is subject only to those laws. There is nothing in it that can be enforced by anyone else. This is the difference between a moral right and a civil right: the former is an absolute right; the latter is only subject in certain circumstances. Now, this is where the whole issue of right vs. wrong comes in. I think that it is important to understand that a person's right or wrong is determined by their own actions

prompt: Is English American, Canadian, etc. common law recognized as legally binding under international law? After all, we're talking about something that by its very nature isn't limited to the territory of one nation.
text:
Is English American, Canadian, etc. common law recognized as legally binding under international law? After all, we're talking about something that by its very nature isn't limited to the territory of one nation.

The answer is yes, but only in the sense that it is recognized by the international community. The United States is a signatory to a number of international treaties, including the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), the Convention on the Rights of the Child (CRC), and the United Nations Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment (UNCAT).
...
"The United Kingdom is not a party to any of these treaties. However, the UK has ratified the ICCPR and has signed the CRC. It is also a member of a group of countries that have ratified both the UN and ICCP. These countries are the Republic of Korea, China, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan. In addition, there are a few other countries, such as the Philippines, which have not ratified either the ICJ or the CRC. Therefore, it would be incorrect to say that the US is bound by these international agreements."
In other words, if you're a US citizen, you are bound to abide by international laws. But if your country is one of those that has not signed any international treaty, then you aren't bound. And if the law of your home country doesn't apply to you, that's your problem.

The planets in the solar systems are not all in a single orbit. They are all moving in different directions. This is because the planets have different masses. Jupiter is much heavier than the other planets, so it is moving faster. Saturn is lighter than Jupiter, but it has a much larger mass. Venus is the heaviest planet in our solar System, with a mass of about 1.5 times that of Earth. It is also moving at a very high speed. Mars is about the same mass as Earth, yet it moves at about half the speed of Jupiter. Mercury is a little lighter, about 0.8 times Earth's mass, while Venus and Earth are about equal in mass and are moving about twice as fast. Earth is in between the two. So the outermost planets move at different speeds. If you want to go to Mars, you have to move faster than Mars. But if you go there, it will take you a long time to get there. You can go faster, of course, if the planet is close enough to you. However, the distance between Mars and the Earth will be so great that you will have a hard time getting there in time.  the sunrises and sunsets are calculated by the following algorithm:

- The sun rises and sets every hour. (This is the same algorithm used by Google Maps.)

 - Each hour, the time is divided by 365.25. This is a constant. So, if the hour is 12:00, then the number of hours in the day is 1. If the hours are 12, 1, and 12.5, it's 12 hours. And so on. Each day, we divide the total number by 12 to determine the average. Then, for each hour of the year, that average is multiplied by 1/365.75 to give us the actual time. For example, in January, when the sky is clear, there is an average of 1 hour and 25 minutes of sun. In February, with the clouds in, this number is 2 hours and 45 minutes. The same is true for space travel. There is no government funding for it. No one is going to pay for the space program. If you want to go to space, you have to do it yourself. You have no choice. And you can't do that if you don't have a rocket. So, the only way to get to the stars is to build one. That's the way it is.

But we have no idea how to go about doing this, or how we can do it. So we do not have a plan. And that is why we cannot do long run monitoring, because we don't have the resources.

text:
One consideration to remember is that if you don't turn it off now, you may not be able to later. This isn't a case of reaching over and flipping a switch much of the spacecraft has to be working correctly to execute a turn off command successfully. Spacecraft do malfunction in their old age. The big concern is not radio clutter from idle spacecraft, but radio clutter from malfunctioning spacecraft that can no longer be turned off.

The other thing to consider is the amount of power that is being used. If you are using a lot of batteries, then you will need to turn the power off to the batteries. You can do this by turning the battery off and then turning it back on. However, if the vehicle is running on batteries that are not being charged, the system will not work. In this case, it is best to leave the engine running and turn on the engines. Once the fuel is used up, turn them off again.

I think you're both right. Teflon was actually discovered by accident before WWII. From what I've heard, they had some chemical I assume it was tetrafluoroethylene in a tank and but the valve got gummed up. Cutting it open revealed that it had polymerized. The polymerization process is a bit like the way that a rubber band forms when you rub it. It's a very slow process, but it's very strong.

The polymer is then heated to a high enough temperature to form a solid. This solid is called a teflonsite. When the taflon is heated, it forms a layer of tuflon. Then, the polymer layer is removed and the solid layer formed. So, you have a polymer that is very hard, very brittle, and very light. You can make a lot of these things. They're very useful for making things like bulletproof vests. But, I think the most important thing about taffloning is that you can use it to make very thin films. And, that's what you want to do with a bullet. If you make it thin enough, then you don't have to worry about the bullet breaking. That's the whole point of making a thin film. Because, if you break the film, there's no way to tell if it broke because of the impact of a projectile or because it got stuck in the material. There's nothing to say that the projectile broke. In fact, a good bullet will probably break if the metal is too thin. A good projectile will break when the steel is so thin that there is no metal to hold it together. The corn meal is mixed with water and then the flour is added. It's then mixed again with more water until it's a dough. Then it is kneaded and shaped into a tortillas. This is what I think the original tortillas were made of. They were pretty much just a mix of flour and corn. But I guess that's what they were. And I'm pretty certain that they weren't made with tortellini. Tortillas are made by mixing flour with corn and water. Corn is a starch and it doesn't have a lot of protein. So it can't be used to make tortillerias. That's why tortilas are usually made out of a combination of wheat flour, corn flour or a blend of both. You can find tortillo flour in the grocery store. text:
There is an interesting opinion piece in the business section of today's LA Times Thursday April 15, 1993, p. D1. I thought I'd post it to stir up some flame wars I mean reasoned debate. Let me preface it by saying that I largely agree that the Space Age in the romantic sense of several decades ago is over, and that projects like the space station miss the point at this time. Reading, for example, What's New the weekly physics update we get here on the net it's clear that the romance of the day lies in the ever more fine grained manipulation of matter by which I include biotechnology, condensed matter physics with its spinoffs in computer hardware and elsewhere, and the amazing things people are doing with individual atoms these days. I'm not sure that we are in a romantic era, but I do think that there is a lot of room for the kind of science fiction that is being done today.

The article is written by John M. O'Neill, a professor of physics at the University of California, Berkeley. He is also a member of NASA's Advisory Council on Science and Technology. The article begins with a quote from the late physicist and Nobel laureate, Richard Feynman, who said that "the future is not going to be like this."
...
,
"The future of space exploration is going not to look like that. It's going be a very different kind. We're going into space to explore the solar system, to study the universe, not just to go to the moon and back. And we're not doing it for a few years, or a decade, we want to do it right now. That's the way we should be doing things."...
In the article, Ollie O. Mearns, the director of research at NASA, says that he is "not sure" that space travel is the future. "I think we have to get back to a time when we were exploring the earth, exploring our solar systems, studying the stars, looking for life, finding out what's out there. Now we've got to move on to other things. But I don't think it will be the same kind." OLLIE

To summarize SPACE ADVERTISING First, advertising on space vehicles is not new it is very common practice to put the cooperating organization's logos on the space launch vehicle. For example, the latest GPS launcher had the very prominent logos on its side of McDonnell Douglas the Delta launcher Rockwell International who built the GPS satellite USAF who paid for the satellite and launch, and the GPS Navstar program office This has not been considered paid advertising but rather public relations, since the restrictions have been such that only organizations involved in the launch could put their logos on the side, and there was no money exchanged for this. However, putting a 10' high logo on the side of the launch vehicle facing the cameras is advertising as much as it is public relations, in my opinion. And by the way, I note that the DC X test vehicle has rather prominent McDonnell Douglas and SDIO logos on the side... There have been several studies looking at the revenue potentials for use of space vehicles for advertising, or placing large advertising signs in orbit. The most recent study was done by a group of researchers at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. They looked at a number of different advertising options, including placing a large billboard on a satellite, placing an advertisement on an orbiter, using a space vehicle as a billboard, etc. In their study, they found that a commercial space advertising campaign would generate $1.5 million in revenue per year, which is about $2.4 million per launch. This is a very small amount of money, but it does show that space is an attractive advertising medium. I have not seen any studies that looked into the potential revenue from using space for commercial purposes. But I am sure that there are many who would like to see this type of advertising. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. text:
The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.

The NORad two-line element set is updated every day, with the exception of the first day of each month. This is to ensure that the elements are not lost or corrupted during the flight. If the two lines are lost, they are replaced with a new line. For example, if the second line is lost on a flight, it is replaced by the third line, which is the same as the original line but with one stop. In addition, a second stop is added to each line to prevent the line from being lost. A second-stop is also added for each satellite in the system, to allow for redundancy. These two stop bits are used to determine the position of a satellite. When the stop-bit is set, all satellites in a line are in their correct position. However, when the start-bits are set to zero, then the satellites are at their current position, regardless of whether the end-Bit is zero or not. Thus, in order to maintain the correct positions of all the spacecraft, two stops are added. Each satellite is assigned a unique stop, so that if one satellite moves, another satellite will not be affected. Also, each stop has a different start bit. Therefore, for example if a stop was set at zero and the other satellites were at the beginning of their stop sequence, one of them would be at its stop position and another would not, even if they were in different positions.


NORAD Two Line Element Set

text:
That would not explain why widely separated detectors, such as on Ulysses and PVO and Ginga et al., would see a burst at the same time. In fact, be fore BATSE, having this widely separated Interplanetary Network was the only sure way to locate a random burst. With only one detector, one cannot locate a burst except to say It's somewhere in the field of view.. With two detectors, one can use the time that the burst is seen in each detector to narrow the location to a thin annulus on the sky.

The second possibility is that a single burst was seen by two separate detectors. This is the case with the two bursts seen on PVP and U. The first burst, seen at PVE, was not seen again until the second burst seen near U, at UVE. text:
Where does the shadow come from? There's nothing close enough to block sunlight from hitting them. I wouldn't expect there to be anything block our view of them either. What am I missing?

The shadow is a shadow of the sun. The sun is the source of light. It is not a reflection of itself.
...
,
"I'm not sure what you're talking about," said the man. "I've never seen a sun in my life."
I looked at him. He was wearing a dark suit, and his eyes were closed. His hair was a deep brown, but it was not long. There was no shadow on his face. But he was staring at me. And I was looking at the shadows. They were not the same. One was dark, the other was light, like the moon. Both were the reflection, not of themselves, of something else. Something that was far away. A shadow. That was the only thing that could be the cause of this. If I could see the light of that shadow, I would see that it had a source. Not a light source, a heat source or a fire. No, it must be something far more powerful. Perhaps a force that would destroy the world. Or perhaps it would be a power that created the universe. Either way, there was something that I needed to know. So I opened my eyes. My eyes had been closed for a long time. When I did open them, they were filled with a strange light that seemed to come out of nowhere. As I looked, my vision became clearer. Everything was in focus. All the colors were there.

text:
The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.

The NORad two-line element set is updated every day, with the exception of the first day of each month. This is to ensure that the elements are not lost or corrupted during the flight. If the two lines are lost, they are replaced with a new line. For example, if the second line is lost on a flight, it is replaced by the third line, which is the same as the original line but with one stop. In addition, a second stop is added to each line to prevent the line from being lost. A second-stop is also added for each satellite in the system, to allow for redundancy. These two stop bits are used to determine the position of a satellite. When the stop-bit is set, all satellites in a line are in their correct position. However, when the start-bits are set to zero, then the satellites are at their current position, regardless of whether the end-Bit is zero or not. Thus, in order to maintain the correct positions of all the spacecraft, two stops are added. Each satellite is assigned a unique stop, so that if one satellite moves, another satellite will not be affected. Also, each stop has a different start bit. Therefore, for example if a stop was set at zero and the other satellites were at the beginning of their stop sequence, one of them would be at its stop position and another would not, even if they were in different positions.


NORAD Two Line Element Set

Background The Orion spacedrive was a theoretical concept. It would be a drive using thermonuclear explosions to drive a spacecraft. The idea was that you'd detonate devices with somewhere from one to ten megatons yield behind a pusher plate attached to the main spacecraft. The shock wave from the explosions would transfer momentum to the ship. This would cause the spacecraft to accelerate to a high enough velocity to escape the explosion.

The idea of using a thermo-nuclear device to propel a spaceship was first proposed by the British physicist John Tyndall in the late 1920s. He proposed that a nuclear device could be used to launch a rocket to orbit. However, the idea never caught on. In the early 1930s, a group of American scientists, led by John von Neumann, proposed a similar idea. They proposed using an atomic bomb to create a space-based rocket. Von Neuman's idea would have used a bomb that was about the size of a small car to generate enough energy to push a ship to space. But the bomb would not have been powerful enough to get a vehicle to Mars. Instead, it would use a smaller bomb, about one-tenth the weight of the original bomb. A smaller nuclear bomb could have pushed a larger vehicle, such as a Mars probe, to an orbit around the planet. If the larger bomb was detonated in orbit, then the smaller one would detonation would occur at the surface of Mars, where the vehicle would burn up. (The original idea for the space probe was to use the same bomb as the one used on the moon to send a probe to land on Mars.)

Writer Kathy Sawyer reported in today's Washington Post that Joseph Shea, the head of the space station redesign has resigned for health reasons. Shea was hospitalized shortly after his selection in February. He returned yesterday to lead the formal presentation to the independent White House panel. Shea's presentation was rambling and almost inaudible.

The panel is expected to recommend a new design for the ISS, which is currently under construction. The panel will also recommend the design of a replacement for NASA's aging space shuttle fleet.

That has sort of happened for real. Back in the 1920's travellers in the Sudan would find strange cigar shaped designs on native huts. When asked the locals would say it was a picture of the great omen that appeared in the sky. This was LZ 53 a zepplin flying from Bulgaria to German East Africa with supplies in 1917 and back since it was fooled by the British secret service.

The Zepplins were a German secret weapon. They were designed to be flown by a single pilot and had a range of over 100 miles. The Zeppelin was the first of its kind and was designed by Heinrich von Kleist. It was powered by two Rolls Royce engines and could carry up to 1,000 passengers. In the early days of Zeppelins the Germans would fly them over the German cities of Berlin, Hamburg, and Leipzig. These were the days before the air raid shelters and the Berlin Wall. There were no shelters in Germany and it wasn't until the war that the Zepps were used to carry supplies to the front lines. During the Battle of Britain the RAF used the zeppelin to deliver supplies and ammunition to troops in France. After the end of World War II the Allies used them to transport supplies from the UK to Germany. Today the aircraft are still used by air forces around the world.

text:
Thanks to the people who have answered here and in email to my question about which countries engage in space surveillance. Unfortunately, I apparently didn't make the meaning of the message clear, since most replies have addressed satellite reconnaissance, rather than space surveillance What I meant was _not_ which countries use satellites to look at the Earth satellite reconnaissance, but _was_ which countries have programs to detect and track i.e., determine the orbital elements of satellites as they pass overhead space surveillance. The US uses missile defense radars, supplemented by a fascinating quasi radar operated by the Navy, to do this for satellites in LEO, and electrooptical systems for objects at altitudes above 5,000 km or so. The FEE, I understand, does much the same thing. I'm not sure what the FER does, but it's a very interesting project. It's also a project of interest to me, because it is a way to get a better understanding of what is going on in the world. In the case of FERS, it would be interesting to know what countries are using it, as well as what they are doing with it. If you have any information on this, please let me know. Thanks, -- David

Reading from a Amoco Performance Products data sheet, their ERL 1906 resin with T40 carbon fiber reinforcement has a compressive strength of 280,000 psi. It has a density of 0.058 lb cu in, therefore the theoretical height for a constant section column that can just support itself is 4.8 million inches, or 400,000 ft, or 75 Statute miles. Now, a real structure will have horizontal bracing either a truss type, or guy wires, or both and will be used below the crush strength. Let us assume that we will operate at 40 of the theoretical strength. The column will then be able to support the weight of a 747, which is about 1,500,00 lbs.

The column is then supported by a steel plate, and the column itself will support a load of about 2,200,0000 lbs, so the total weight is 2.2 million, 000 lbs., or about 4,800, 00 lbs..
...
 the columns are then connected to the structure by steel cables, with the cables being connected in series. This is a very simple system, but it is not very efficient. If we want to use the same column as the one above, we would have to connect it to a structure that is at least twice as tall as it. We would then have a column of 4 million feet, that would be about 6,400, 0 ft. tall. That is very inefficient. So, the solution is to have the steel columns be connected by cables that are connected together in parallel, in a series, to form a single column. In this way, it will not be necessary to make the cable connections in the vertical direction, as we have done in our example. But, if we are going to do this, then we must have some way of connecting the two columns together. One way is by using a cable that has been welded to both columns. This is why you can't just use a high frequency oscillator to drive a small signal. You need a large signal to do that. And if the high frequencies are too high, they will get attenulated. That's why the low frequencies of SSFs are so low. They are attenuating the signals. But if they are high enough, then they can get amplified. The European Satellite Organization (ESO) is a European Union agency that provides space-related information and services. It is the principal spacefaring agency of Europe. ESSO is responsible for the management of European space activities, and for coordinating the activities of other space agencies. Its activities include the development of a space situational awareness system, the launch of satellites, space weather forecasting, satellite navigation, communications, Earth observation, remote sensing, geodesy, meteorology, oceanography, astrophysics, astronomy, earth science, planetary science and space technology. ESO also provides a wide range of Earth science services, such as monitoring of climate change, monitoring and prediction of volcanic eruptions, weather and climate prediction, environmental monitoring, land use and land cover change prediction and monitoring. In addition, ESo provides the European Geosciences Network (EGN) and the Global Precipitation Measurement (GPM) network. GPM is an international network of ground stations that provide global precipitation measurements. Of course sorry for the misunderstanding. I was referring to the fact that far more aeronautical development took place in the '30's. For much of the '20's, the super abundance of Jennies and OX 5 engines held down the industry. By 1926, many of the obsolete WWI aircraft had been retired and Whirlwind had their power weight ratio and reliability up to the point where long distance flights became practical.

The '40's saw the introduction of a number of new aircraft, including the Douglas DC-3, Douglas C-47, and Douglas A-4 Skyhawk. The Douglas Skyraider was the first aircraft to be powered by a jet engine. It was a huge success and the Skyran was an instant hit. In the early '50's the US Air Force began to develop a new fighter, which was to become the F-86 Sabre. This was powered primarily by the Pratt & Whitney R-2800-A1, a single-stage, single turbine engine with a maximum thrust of 1,200 lbs. At the time, this was considered to have the potential to power the entire US air force. However, it was not until the mid-1960's that the R2801-D1 was developed. With a thrust-to-weight ratio of 2.5, its maximum speed was 1.6 Mach. Its maximum range was 2,000 miles. Although the Saber was never built, there were a few prototypes built. These were the Lockheed F4U-1 Phantom II and Lockheed SR-71 Blackbird. Both were powered entirely by jet engines. Lockheed's SR71 was also powered solely by an R2700 engine, but it had a range of only 1/2 the range and a top speed of Mach 1 (1.8 Mach). The F8U was another jet powered aircraft. The Hubble Space Telescope is the most powerful telescope ever built. The Hubble is a giant mirror that is about the size of the Empire State Building. Hubble has a mirror of about 1.5 meters in diameter. This mirror is so large that it is able to focus light from the entire universe onto a single point in space. In fact, the Hubble's mirror has been used to study the structure of galaxies and to measure the expansion of space itself. But the biggest thing about Hubble, is that the telescope is not just a telescope. Its mirror can be used as a computer. When the mirror was first designed, it was designed to be a "mirror" that could be rotated to reflect light back into space, but it has since been found that this is impossible. Instead, Hubble uses a special type of mirror called a coronagraph to block out the glare of light that would otherwise be reflected back to Earth. So, instead of focusing light onto the surface of our planet, we are able see the universe from a distance. And, because the mirrors are so big, they can also be very sensitive to light. For example, when the sun is shining on Hubble and we look at it, our eyes are actually able detect the tiny amount of heat that comes from that light, and that heat is what we can use to calculate the temperature of objects in the Universe. If you were to look through Hubble at the Earth, you would see that we have a very hot planet.

text:
Uh, no. These burst detectors are just that, burst detectors. They have no angular resolution. Now a network of burst detectors could have angular resolution, but we do not have a decent set of different networks at the distances neccesary from each other to determine if they're happening in the oort cloud or not.

So, we have to rely on the fact that the burst detector is a good detector. It's not a perfect detector, and it's certainly not perfect for the time being. But it is good enough for now. And it will be good for a long time.

Yes, the argument can and has been made that current government policy creates even larger market barriers than there were in the first place, but there is no such term as 'government failure', since the government can change policies whenever it pleases. I am not saying that the market is perfect, or that it is always right. I am saying, however, that there are many things that are not in it's best interest to do. And that is why I think that we should be careful about making moral arguments about taxes, and that they should not be used to justify government action.

prompt: I disagree with what to tout, although I agree that the space program is inherently a good thing. Most people today only care about what will it cost me? and what's in it for me? and could care less about whether something is simply worthwhile in and of itself.
text:
I disagree with what to tout, although I agree that the space program is inherently a good thing. Most people today only care about what will it cost me? and what's in it for me? and could care less about whether something is simply worthwhile in and of itself.

I think that's a mistake. I think we should be talking about the things that are worth doing, and the people who are doing them. And I don't think it's wrong to talk about how much money we're spending on space. But I also think there's something to be said for talking to people about why we do it. Why do we want to go to space? Why are we doing it? And why do people want us to do this?
...
The reason we go is because we have to. We have no other choice. It's not like we can go anywhere else. If we could go somewhere else, we would. So we've got to get to the moon. That's the only place we know of that has a reasonable chance of being habitable. The other places are just too far away. There's no way we'll be able to reach them in the next few decades. They're too expensive. You can't just go there and build a base. No one's going to pay for it, so we need to build it ourselves.

text:
You're assuming that their normal rotation carries all areas of the surface into sunlight. Not so. Even on Earth, each pole gets several weeks without sunlight in mid winter. Pluto and Charon have much more extreme axial tilt and a much longer orbit.

The Sun is a giant ball of fire. It's a very bright star. The Sun's surface is covered with a layer of dust and gas. This dust is so hot that it's actually a plasma. Plasma is the stuff that makes up the Sun. When the plasma is heated, it expands and expands. As it does, the temperature of this plasma increases. Eventually, this expansion causes the material to expand even more. At some point, all of that material is ejected from the star and the core of our Sun explodes. That's why the sun is called the "Hot Big Star".
...
"The sun's core is about 10,000 times hotter than the Earth's atmosphere. If you were to stand on the top of a hot, dense, hot star, you'd be vaporized in a few seconds."
- Dr. Robert Zubrin, author of The Case for a New World
This is why Pluto is not a planet. Its surface temperature is too hot to support life. And it is also why Charons surface has been frozen for billions of years. Charos is an ice planet, not an ocean world.

text:
I'll vote for anything where they don't feel constrained to use stupid and ugly PC phrases to replace words like'manned'. If they think they need to do that, they're more than likely engaging in 'politics and public relations as usual' rather than seriously wanting to actually get into space. So that eliminates Option A from the running. What do they call a manned station in Option C?

Option C: The Moon
.
,
The Moon is a great place to go to. It's a place where you can go and explore and it's also a very good place for people to live. The problem is that it is also very expensive. If you want to get to the Moon, you have to pay for it. And that's not a good thing. You can't just go there and say 'I want a moon base'. You have got to make a lot of money. That's the problem. I think that the best way to deal with that is to have a space station that can be built for a reasonable price. But that doesn't mean that you should just build a station and then go. There are a number of things that need doing before you build that station. One of them is getting the technology to be able to build it cheaply. Another is making sure that there's enough people on the station to support it and that they can afford to stay there. A third thing is ensuring that people can get off the ship and go back to Earth. Those are all things you need before a human can actually go into the space stations. They're not going to just be a bunch of people sitting around in a room. We need a whole lot more people. In fact, I'm not sure we need any more humans. Maybe we should have more of a focus on getting people off of the ships and back on to their home planet.

prompt: A bright light phenomenon was observed in the Eastern Finland on April 21. At 00.25 UT two people saw a bright, luminous pillar shaped phenomenon in the low eastern horizont near Mikkeli. The head of the pillar was circular. The lower part was a little winding.
text:
A bright light phenomenon was observed in the Eastern Finland on April 21. At 00.25 UT two people saw a bright, luminous pillar shaped phenomenon in the low eastern horizont near Mikkeli. The head of the pillar was circular. The lower part was a little winding. It was about 1.5 meters in diameter.

The light was seen for about 10 minutes. A few minutes later the light disappeared. No one saw it again.


On April 22, a light in a similar shape was reported in Kajaki, Finland. This light appeared in an area of about 2.2 km2. There was no wind. On April 23, the same light, with a diameter of 1 meter, was sighted in Vantaa, Estonia. In the evening of April 24, two persons saw the object in Hämeenlinna, Sweden. They saw two lights in front of them. One of these lights was white and the other was red. Both lights were moving in circles. After about 20 minutes the lights disappeared and no one could see them again, although they were still visible in their surroundings.

prompt: The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible . Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.
text:
The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.

The NORad two-line element set is updated every day, with the exception of the first day of each month. This is to ensure that the elements are not lost or corrupted during the flight. If the two lines are lost, they are replaced with a new line. For example, if the second line is lost on a flight, it is replaced by the third line, which is the same as the original line but with one stop. In addition, a second stop is added to each line to prevent the line from being lost. A second-stop is also added for each satellite in the system, to allow for redundancy. These two stop bits are used to determine the position of a satellite. When the stop-bit is set, all satellites in a line are in their correct position. However, when the start-bits are set to zero, then the satellites are at their current position, regardless of whether the end-Bit is zero or not. Thus, in order to maintain the correct positions of all the spacecraft, two stops are added. Each satellite is assigned a unique stop, so that if one satellite moves, another satellite will not be affected. Also, each stop has a different start bit. Therefore, for example if a stop was set at zero and the other satellites were at the beginning of their stop sequence, one of them would be at its stop position and another would not, even if they were in different positions.


NORAD Two Line Element Set

text:
They can be detached in an emergency. But expensive hardware is not thrown away casually bearing in mind that nobody knew the design was defective. If the deployment crew had found some nasty flaw the lid failing to open, for example it would have been a bit embarrassing to have to throw the solar arrays away to get the thing back in the payload bay.

The solar panels are mounted on the side of the spacecraft, and the panels can also be removed for servicing. The panels have a very low mass, so they can easily be moved to a different location. They can even be mounted in a vertical position, which is useful for the crew to access the panel. This is a great feature for a spacecraft that is going to be used for long duration missions. It is also a good feature to keep the cost down. If you have the ability to move the entire solar array, you can save a lot of money.

When I was young, we lived in rural New Hampshire, in one of the poorest areas of New York State. We had a very small house, with a small yard, a few cars, no electricity, nothing. It was very hard to get a good job, because the jobs were so few and far between. The only jobs that were available were in mines, which were very dangerous, dangerous jobs. text:
I am puzzled by the term concept. Drag free may already have been flown. It was the idea behind putting up a spacecraft that would more accurately respond to motions from the Earth's gravity field and ignore drag. It was proposed many years ago and involved a ball floating between sensors whose job it was to signal to little adjustment jets to keep the ball away from them. The idea was that the jets would be able to detect the motion of the spacecraft and adjust the trajectory accordingly.

The problem with this idea is that it is not possible to fly a drag free spacecraft. There is no way to make a craft that flies without drag, and the drag is so great that even a small spacecraft would have to be very large to avoid it. This is why the concept of drag-free flight was abandoned. In the early days of space flight, the problem was solved by using a rocket to launch the craft. But the rocket is very heavy and would not be suitable for a space craft, so the solution was a satellite. A satellite is a very small craft with a large mass and a relatively small mass. So the satellite would fly in a straight line, avoiding drag and flying at a high speed. However, this is only possible if the mass of a launch vehicle is small. If the launch mass is large, then the orbit of an object will be distorted and it will not fly straight. And if it flies in an orbit that is distorted, it won't fly at all. Thus, a concept that was once considered to have a good chance of success has now been abandoned because of its poor performance.

prompt: The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible . Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.
text:
The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.

The NORad two-line element set is updated every day, with the exception of the first day of each month. This is to ensure that the elements are not lost or corrupted during the flight. If the two lines are lost, they are replaced with a new line. For example, if the second line is lost on a flight, it is replaced by the third line, which is the same as the original line but with one stop. In addition, a second stop is added to each line to prevent the line from being lost. A second-stop is also added for each satellite in the system, to allow for redundancy. These two stop bits are used to determine the position of a satellite. When the stop-bit is set, all satellites in a line are in their correct position. However, when the start-bits are set to zero, then the satellites are at their current position, regardless of whether the end-Bit is zero or not. Thus, in order to maintain the correct positions of all the spacecraft, two stops are added. Each satellite is assigned a unique stop, so that if one satellite moves, another satellite will not be affected. Also, each stop has a different start bit. Therefore, for example if a stop was set at zero and the other satellites were at the beginning of their stop sequence, one of them would be at its stop position and another would not, even if they were in different positions.


NORAD Two Line Element Set

If we find a planet around a star that's not expanding at all, then we'll have to conclude that it must be expanding. And if it is, that means that there must have been a period of time when the expansion of our universe was slower than it has been in the past. So, if the stars in this region of space are expanding faster than they were in past times, they must also be getting bigger. This means we must find more stars like Proyas, or else we will have found a new universe.

text:
TRIAD, the first drag free satellite, was designed and built by the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory and launched 2 Sept 1972. The satellite was in three sections separated by two booms. The central section housed the DISCOS Disturbance Compensation System, which consisted of a proof mass of special non magnetic alloy housed within a spherical cavity. The proof mass flew a true gravitational orbit, free from drag and radiation pressure.

The second section of the satellite contained the Disruptive Disruption System (DDS), which was a modified version of DISCO. This system consisted in a large spherical chamber containing a magnetic field and a mass that was used to generate a disturbance in the field. A small magnetic coil was attached to the mass and the disturbance was generated by a small electric current. In the third section, a third DISCOM system was installed. It consisted a second DISCONNECT system, and an additional DISSAT system. These systems were used in conjunction with the DDS to provide a complete system for the system to operate. DISCS was the primary system used for all of these systems.


DISCUS was launched on a Delta II rocket on 2 September 1972 and was placed in orbit around the Earth. On the launch pad, DISCs were installed in two sections. One section was located at the top of each tower and contained a DISCMOS system and DISDISS. At the bottom of this section were the two DISCLOS systems, one for each DISCU system installed on the tower. Each DISCLE system contained two coils, each with a different magnetic polarity. When the coil is energized, it generates a current that is directed to a coil in another DISCCU system located in an adjacent tower, causing the current to be directed in opposite directions. As the coils are energised, they generate an electric field that disrupts the magnetic fields of nearby objects

text: Posted to the Internet by wmiler nyx.cs.du.edu 000062David42 041493003715 The Lunar Tele operation Model One LTM1 By David H. Mitchell March 23, 1993 INTRODUCTION In order to increase public interest in space based and lunar operations, a real miniature lunar like environment is being constructed on which to test tele operated models. These models are remotely controlled by individuals located world wide using their personal computers, for EduTainment purposes. Not only does this provide a test bed for simple tele operation and tele presence activities but it also provides for the sharing of information on methods of operating in space, including, but not limited to, layout of a lunar colony, tele operating machines for work and play, disseminating educational information, providing contests and awards for creativity and achievement and provides a new way for students worldwide to participate in Twenty First century remote learning methods. Because of the nature of the LTM1 project, people of all ages, interests and skills can contribute scenery and murals, models and structures, interfacing and electronics, software and graphics. The model is a remote controlled model of an actual lunar base, complete with a large lunar landscape, and a small lunar moon base. It is also a model for a teleoperated model, which is controlled remotely by a person located in the United States. This model will be used to demonstrate the use of remote control techniques to operate a space model in a simulated lunar environment. A remote-controlled model can be operated in any location, at any time, by any person. Remote control of this model has been demonstrated in several ways. First, the model was used in an educational program for elementary school students. Second, it was demonstrated to a group of NASA employees in Washington, D.C. Third, an individual was able to control the remote model remotely from his home in California. Fourth, remote operation of these models has also been used for tele-operated telepresence activities. In addition, this project has provided a means for sharing information about the operation, design and construction of lunar bases, lunar colonies and other lunar activities with the general public. As a result of its success, many people have expressed interest and interest has grown. There are many other projects in progress, some of which are being developed by the Lunar Remote Operations Group. One of them is the development of models for remote operations of space vehicles. Another is to develop models of teleoperations of spacecraft. Finally, there are plans to build a miniature model lunar city. All of those projects are in various stages of development

text:
McDonnell Douglas rolls out DC X HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif. On a picture perfect Southern California day, McDonnell Douglas rolled out its DC X rocket ship last Saturday. The company hopes this single stage rocket technology demonstrator will be the first step towards a single stage to orbit SSTO rocket ship. The white conical vehicle was scheduled to go to the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico this week. Flight tests will start in mid June.

The company is also working on a new rocket called the DCX. This is a two stage vehicle that will have a larger payload capacity. It will also be able to carry a heavier payload. McDonnell is hoping to have the new vehicle ready for flight tests in the second half of this year.

A H1 can also be used to launch a satellite into orbit. H2 rockets are larger, heavier, more powerful, but are not as easy to use. They can only carry about 500 pounds of payload. Its maximum payload is 2,500 pounds, which is more weight than the entire payloads of the Saturn V and the Space Shuttle. In fact, it's the only rocket capable of lifting a human into outer space. There are two versions of this rocket: the Atlas and Delta. Both are based on the same basic design, with the Delta being the more advanced of them. text:
Things could be worse. A lot worse! In the mid eighties the teen adult sci fi comic 2000AD Fleetway produced a short story featuring the award winning character Judge Dredd. The story focussed on an advertising agency of the future who use high powered multi coloured lasers search lights pointed at the moon to paint images on the moon. The agency's client is a company called the Moonbase. They are looking for a new moon base to use as a base of operations for their new space station. Judge is the only one who can see the images. He is also the one that can use the lasers to see them.

The story was a huge success and spawned a series of sequels. In 2000 AD's sequel, Judge was given a more humanised backstory. His father was killed in a car accident when he was young. As a result he has a very strong sense of justice and is very good at using his powers to help others. However, he is not above using them to get what he wants. This is shown in the story when Judge decides to take on a case against a corrupt judge. It is revealed that the judge is actually a robot and that he uses his power to manipulate the court. When Judge finds out that his father is alive he decides that it is time to put an end to the corrupt judges. To do this he must use his laser eyes to find the judges and destroy them with his lasers. Unfortunately, the Judge's laser vision is so powerful that even the most powerful laser can't destroy him. Instead, it causes him to become more powerful. Eventually, his eyes become so bright that they can be seen from space. After this, a group of people called The Judges decide to stop him and he becomes a fugitive.

text: Forwarded from Neal Ausman, Galileo Mission Director GALILEO MISSION DIRECTOR STATUS REPORT POST LAUNCH April 23 29, 1993 SPACECRAFT 1. On April 22 and 23, delta Differenced One way Range DOR passes were performed over DSS 14 63 Goldstone Madrid 70 meter antennas and DSS 14 43 Goldstone Canberra 70 meter antennas, respectively. This was all badly reported in the news. There is no evidence that signs of life found in old rock predate putative planet sterilizing events. The evidence for the sterilization of the planet is not in rocks, it is in fossils. Fossils are the only evidence we have for life on the Earth. They are found all over the world. In the fossil record, we find evidence not only of organisms that have been alive for millions of years, such as the dinosaurs, and organisms which have not been around for that long, like the bacteria that live in our stomachs. We also find fossils of animals that are not alive, which are called "extinct" fossils, because they are no longer alive. These fossils are very rare, so we do not know how many there are. But we know that there were many of them. And we also know from the fossils that the animals were not sterile. So, if the evidence is that organisms were sterilized, there must have existed organisms in which the cells were sterile, or at least sterile in a way that would have prevented the formation of new cells. This is the conclusion that has been reached by many scientists. It is a conclusion which has not yet been accepted by the majority of scientists, who have accepted the theory of evolution.

In any case, a bright point of light passing through the field doesn't ruin observations. The only thing that would be a problem would if the point was too bright to be seen. That's why the'satellite' is a good idea. It would give the billboard a nice, bright, point.

The billboard would also be visible from the ground. This is important because the sky is not a flat surface. There are many different levels of brightness. If the light is too dim to see, it will not be as bright as it could be. So, the best way to make the billboards visible is to have them be at the highest level of visibility. And, of course, they would have to stay in the same place. They would not move. But, if they were to move, then the effect would only be to increase the brightness of a point that is at a lower level. A billboard that was at an altitude of 10,000 feet would still be bright enough to show up on the horizon. However, at 10 miles, or even 10 kilometers, there would no longer be any point to the image. At that altitude, you would see the entire sky. You would never see a single point in it. Even if you were at that height, and you could see it clearly, what would you see? The sky would look like a huge, flat, empty expanse. Hardin FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE April 15, 1993 1506 Scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory report the successful flight of a balloon carrying instruments designed to measure and study chemicals in the Earth's ozone layer. The April 3 flight from California's Barstow Daggett Airport reached an altitude of 37 kilometers 121,000 feet and took measurements as part of a program established to correlate data with the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite UARS . The data from the balloon flight will also be compared to readings from the Atmospheric Trace Molecular Spectroscopy ATMOS experiment which is currently flying onboard the shuttle Discovery.
text:
Forwarded from PUBLIC INFORMATION OFFICE JET PROPULSION LABORATORY CALIFORNIA INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY NATIONAL AERONAUTICS AND SPACE ADMINISTRATION PASADENA, CALIF. 91109. 818 354 5011 Contact Mary A. Hardin FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE April 15, 1993 1506 Scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory report the successful flight of a balloon carrying instruments designed to measure and study chemicals in the Earth's ozone layer. The April 3 flight from California's Barstow Daggett Airport reached an altitude of 37 kilometers 121,000 feet and took measurements as part of a program established to correlate data with the Upper Atmosphere Research Satellite UARS. The data from the balloon flight will also be compared to readings from the Atmospheric Trace Molecular Spectroscopy ATMOS experiment which is currently flying onboard the shuttle Discovery. "This is a very exciting time for the ozone research community," said John Grunsfeld, associate administrator for NASA Headquarters' Science Mission Directorate. Grunfeld said the data collected by the UARS experiment will be used to help determine the role of ozone in climate change. Uars is the first instrument to be launched on a space shuttle. It is designed and built by a team of scientists at the University of California, Berkeley, and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. NASA is funding the project through the Advanced Technology Demonstration Program (ATDP) and is using the ATDP funds to support the development of the instrument. ATDMP is an initiative of NASA to develop technologies that will enable the agency to conduct research in space and on the ground. For more information about ATDS, visit: http://www.nasa.gov/atds. This release was prepared by John Aravosis, NASA JPL, Pasadena, Calif. and John M. O'Brien, JHU, Washington.

The H2B orbiter is a very large satellite, about the size of a football field. Its orbit takes it around the Earth at a speed of about 1,000 miles per hour. That's a lot of speed, especially for an object that is about half the diameter of the International Space Station. But it also means that the satellites are constantly in motion. They are not stationary, they are moving around. And they have a tendency to drift away from the center of their orbit as they move around, which is what causes the problem. I think that's a very good point. I think it's very important to have a clear idea of what the costs are. If you're going to do a big project, you need to know what it is you are going do. You need a plan. And you also need the ability to say, 'I'm going in this direction, I'm not going there'.
...
 the problem is that the cost of doing a project is not the same as the amount of money you spend. It's not just the number of people you hire. There are a number, a cost, of things you have. So if you want to get a billion dollars for a space project you've got to think about the things that you'll need. That's why I say that it doesn't matter how much money is spent, it matters how you use it.

text:
Regarding drag free satellites, Joe Cain gives a good description of the concept. It is however more than a concept. The Navy's Triad satellite succesfully used drag free control. Drag free control is an integral part of the Stanford Gravity Probe B spacecraft, due to fly in 1999.

The concept of drag-free satellites is not new. In the 1960s, the US Air Force developed a satellite called the "Drag Free Satellite" (DFS). The DFS was a small satellite that was designed to be launched into orbit using a rocket. However, it was not designed for drag control, and it did not fly. Instead, a dragless satellite was developed. This satellite, called "DAS", was launched in the 1970s. Two developments have brought these type of activities back to the forefront in 1993. First, in February, the Russians deployed a 20 m reflector from a Progress vehicle after it had departed from the Mir Space Station. While this Banner reflector was blank, NPO Energia was very active in reporting that future Banner reflectors will be available to advertisers, who could use a space based video of their logo or ad printed on the Banner in a TV commercial, as filmed from the Mir. The second development, has been that Space Marketing Inc, the same company responsible for merchandising space on the Conestoga booster and COMET spacecraft, is now pushing the Environmental Billboard. This is a large, flat, transparent, reflective banner that can be hung on a wall or ceiling. It is designed to be used as a billboard, and is intended to provide a visual representation of the environment in which the space station is located. This type is also being used by the Russian space agency, Roscosmos, to advertise the International Space station.

The Environmental Banner is being developed by a company called Environmental Marketing, Inc. (EMI). The company is based in the United States, but has offices in Moscow and St. Petersburg. EMI is the only company in Russia that has the capability to produce the banner. According to EM I, it is possible to make the banners in large quantities, which would be useful for advertising space stations. However, they are not yet able to manufacture them in quantities sufficient to meet the needs of commercial space agencies. In addition, EM is not able, at this time, even to print the environmental banners on paper. Instead, these banners are printed in high resolution on high quality paper, using a laser printer. These banners can then be printed and hung in any location. They are also available in different sizes, including a 10 x 10 foot banner, a 30 x 30 foot one, or a 50 x 50 foot. All of these sizes are available for purchase. A large number of environmental billboards are being produced by EM, although the company has not been able at present to sell them. text: Forwarded from the Mars Observer Project MARS OBSERVER STATUS REPORT April 28, 1993 12 40 PM PDT Flight Sequence C9 is active as of 00 11 AM, Tuesday, April 27. With activities beginning at shortly before 5 00 AM yesterday, C9 commanded the spacecraft to execute a series of slews and rolls to provide the MAG Magnetometer Team data points in varying spacecraft attitudes and orientations for the purpose of better characterizing the spacecraft generated magnetic field and its effect on their instrument. The spacecraft was commanded back to Sun Star Init state at 9 07 AM to re establish Inertial Reference. Transition back to Array Normal Spin began at 11 17 AM, after which the sequence powered on the on board transmitter at 11 18 AM. At 11 20 AM the transmitter was switched off and the mission was terminated. A final check of the data was performed at 12 00 PM. C8 was in the same state as C7, but with the exception of a slight change in attitude. This was due to the fact that the magnetometer data were being read from a different data source. After the final data check, the Mission Control Center (MCC) was notified that C6 was still in a state of In-Tune. MCC was instructed to initiate a "Tuning" sequence to correct the attitude of C5. During the course of this process, MDC was informed that a change of attitude was required. As a result, a new attitude determination was made and a correction was applied to C4. In the process of correcting the orientation of M6, it was determined that M5 was not in tune with M4 and was therefore in an Inverted state. It was decided to move M3 to a position in which it would be in Invert-In-Out (I-IO) mode. Once the I-O mode was established, all of its data would now be read in from M2. All of these changes were made in order to ensure that all data from C3 would also be available for use in C2 and C1. prompt: It's not quite what you were asking, but a few years ago I helped some EE remote sensing people run some experiments on the microwave emmissivity of ice they used the sky for a background calibration source. They said that from Earth's surface the sky looks like a 60K blackbody.
text:
It's not quite what you were asking, but a few years ago I helped some EE remote sensing people run some experiments on the microwave emmissivity of ice they used the sky for a background calibration source. They said that from Earth's surface the sky looks like a 60K blackbody. I was skeptical, so I did some calculations and found that the emissivity is about 0.1W/m2. So, if you're looking for the black body temperature, you'd have to look at the ice.

The problem is that ice is not a perfect blackbodies. It's a very poor reflector of radiation. The reason is because ice has a lot of water vapor in it. Water vapor is a good reflectant, and it absorbs a fair amount of the radiation that hits it, because it's so cold. But it also absorbs some of it that doesn't hit it at all. This is why ice can be so dark. If you look up at a dark sky, the stars are very bright, they're very far away, there's no water vapour in the air, it looks very dark, even though it is very reflective. Ice is much more reflective than water. And so, ice absorbs more radiation than the sun. That's why the temperature of a black hole is so low. You can't see the light coming from it because the water is too cold to reflect it back. In fact, water absorbs about 90% of all the energy that comes from the Sun. When you put water in a vacuum, that's what happens. There's nothing to absorb it and nothing for it to emit back to the universe. A low option of 5 billion, a mid range option of 7 billion and a high option of 9 billion will be considered by the committee. Each option would cover the total expenditures for space station from fiscal year 1994 through 1998 and would include funds for development, operations, utilization, Shuttle integration, facilities, research operations support, transition cost and also must include adequate program reserves to insure program implementation within the available funds. Over the next 5 years, 4 billion is reserved within the NASA budget for the President's new technology investment. The President has requested that the Congress provide an additional $1.5 billion for this purpose. This additional funding would be used to develop and test new technologies and to support the development of new space technologies.  the other day, I was wondering if you could tell me what the delta-winged Delta-V is. I'm not sure if it's a delta or a winged version of the Atlas V. It's the same basic design. The delta is a two-stage rocket, with a single stage booster. There are two main engines, one on each side of a central core. Each engine has a nozzle, which is attached to the center of each stage. A single nozzle is used for both stages. In the case of Delta, it has two engines. One is on top of it and the second is below it. Both engines are powered by liquid oxygen and kerosene. They are also powered with krypton. This is an important distinction. Liquid oxygen is not used in the rocket engines of any other rocket. Kerosenone is, but it is only used as a propellant in liquid hydrogen. If you look at the pictures of Atlas, you'll see that the engines have a very large diameter. That's because they are used to push the vehicle forward. When the booster is in orbit, they have to be very small. Delta is designed to have very little thrust. Its engines will be used only to accelerate the spacecraft.

What would all of you out there in net land think of the big 6 Martin Mariatta, Boeing, Mcdonell Douglas, General Dynamics, Lockheed, Rockwell getting together, and forming a consortium to study exactly what the market price pints are for building reusable launch vehicles, and spending say 3million to do that. Recognizing that most of the military requirements for launch vehicles are pulled out of a hat somewhere say, has the shuttle ever really used that 1200mi crossrange capability? You get the idea, figure out how many, how often, where to, etc... Then taking this data, and forming a sematech type company bad example, I know... but at least its an example... To develop between 3 and 5 craft designs. Then to take all of those designs, and figure out EXACTLY what the technologies are, and demonstrate those technologies, in order to eliminate designs that can't be built today. And then to figure OUT how to build those craft, using the same technologies. This is a very, very long term project. I'm not sure how long it will take, but I think it's a good idea.

I think the best way to get this done is to have a group of people who are willing to work on this for a long time. The best thing to happen to the industry is if we can get a bunch of folks who have the right skills, who can work together to solve this problem. If we don't, then we're going to be stuck with a lot of crap.

prompt: The main effect of the spherical aberration problems with the primary mirror was to drive the computer engineers to develop the image processing software that much faster. When they use the _same_ deconvolution software on the images from the fixed Hubble, be ready for some incredible results! There is every reason to believe that the results will _exceed_ the original specs by a fair margin. Adaptive optics is a combination of hardware and software.
text:
The main effect of the spherical aberration problems with the primary mirror was to drive the computer engineers to develop the image processing software that much faster. When they use the _same_ deconvolution software on the images from the fixed Hubble, be ready for some incredible results! There is every reason to believe that the results will _exceed_ the original specs by a fair margin. Adaptive optics is a combination of hardware and software. The software is the hardware.

The software has been developed by the Hubble Space Telescope Imaging Science Center (HSTIC) at the University of Arizona. It is called the Image Processing System (IPS). The IPS is an open source software package that is available for download from http://www.hstic.arizona.edu/software/ipss/. The HST is operated by NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland. H STIC is managed by Goddard's Imaging Sciences Division.

text:
I was reading Popular Science this morning and was surprised by an ad in the back. I know that a lot of the ads in the back of PS are fringe science or questionablely legal, but this one really grabbed my attention. It was from a company name Personal Missle, Inc. or something like that. Anyhow, the ad stated that they'd sell rockets that were up to 20' in length and engines of sizes F to M. I'm not sure what the M stands for, and I don't know if they're selling rockets with a rocket motor or a motor. The ad also stated they had a "high-performance" rocket that could reach Mach 5.

I'm sure that's a good thing, because I've never heard of a high-powered rocket reaching Mach 4. But I was curious about the rocket's thrust, so I did some research. Here's what I found:
 the thrust of an engine is the force that the engine produces when it is operating. This is a force, not a mass, which is what we're talking about. So the amount of thrust is proportional to the square of its mass. For example, a 1,000 lb. rocket engine has a thrust equal to 1.000 x 10^-6 lb-ft. (1,100,400,800,600,200,500,300,250,150,125,110,80,50,10,5,2,1).
The thrust for a 20 ft. long rocket is 1 x 1/20 x 20 = 1 lbf. That's about 1% of what a typical rocket has. If you're interested in rocket thrust and how it's measured, I recommend reading this article.

prompt: Several people have enquired about the availability of the book about the Great 72 reflector built at Birr Castle, Ireland in 1845 which remained the largest in the world until the the start of the 20th century. The Astronomy of Birr Castle was written by Patrick Moore who now sits on the committee which is going to restore the telescope. The remains are on public display all year round the massive support walls, the 60 foot long tube, and other bits and pieces . This book is the definitivie history of how one man, the Third Earl of Rosse, pulled off the most impressive technical achievement, perhaps ever, in the history of the telescope, and the discoveries made with the instrument.
text:
Several people have enquired about the availability of the book about the Great 72 reflector built at Birr Castle, Ireland in 1845 which remained the largest in the world until the the start of the 20th century. The Astronomy of Birr Castle was written by Patrick Moore who now sits on the committee which is going to restore the telescope. The remains are on public display all year round the massive support walls, the 60 foot long tube, and other bits and pieces. This book is the definitivie history of how one man, the Third Earl of Rosse, pulled off the most impressive technical achievement, perhaps ever, in the history of the telescope, and the discoveries made with the instrument.

The book was published in 1996 and is available from the National Library of Ireland. It is also available on Amazon.com.

This was not a new idea, as the steam engine had been used in ships since the early 1600s. However, it had never been built before. In fact, there was no ship that could be called a'steam ship' until the Southern. There were two main reasons for this. Firstly, steam power was expensive, so the cost of building a large ship was prohibitive. Secondly, a great many ships were built in Europe, where the technology was much more advanced. These ships had to be built to a very high standard, to meet the requirements of their owners. They were also built with a high degree of safety in mind, in order to ensure that the ship would not sink. A ship with the same safety standards as a modern aircraft carrier would be a disaster waiting to happen. So, when the South was built, they had a lot of extra safety features built into the hull. Yes, but that's because interstellar grains are very poor radiators, not remotely black bodies. As a consequence they are a lot warmer than the ambient. When I was in graduate school, a long time ago, we used 10,000 deg K with a DILUTION FACTOR of 10 4 for representative values of the radiant energy background in the galaxy due to starlight. So the stellar temperature of a galaxy is not a good proxy for the blackbody temperature.

The black body temperature depends on the mass of an object, the density of its gas, its temperature and its luminosities. For a black hole, all these parameters are the most important. If the gas is very dense, then the star will be very hot, so the radiation will have a very high temperature (and hence a high black-body-temperature). If it is much denser, it will radiate less, hence the energy will not be as high. In the case of our galaxy, there is no gas at all, only a few stars, which are all very close together. Therefore, our black holes are not very cold, they have very little radiation. They are also very small, about the size of Jupiter. This is why they radiated so much energy. But the fact that they were so hot is also a sign that the universe is expanding. It is only when the expansion is slowing down that we see the cooling. Well, almost. It turns out that clever orbital mechanics can engineer things so that resonant interactions with the higher order harmonics of the Earth's gravitational field can pump energy into a satellite, and keep it from experiencing drag effects for periods of months to years. My favorite example of this is the Soviet Russian heavy ELINT satellites of the Cosmos 1603 class, which are in 14 1 resonance. In particular, C1833 has undergone two periods of prolonged gain in altitude, the current one having started in June 1991 the mean altitude of the satellite is now as high as it has ever been since launch on 18 March 1987.

The satellite has experienced a period of gain of about 1.5 km/s, with a maximum of 2.2 km. This is a very large gain, but it is not the maximum gain that is important. prompt: Tom's right about this. It's only a grantable right if the granter has the will and the ability to stop anyone from taking it away from you. Never mind the legal status. Nick's right about this.
text:
Tom's right about this. It's only a grantable right if the granter has the will and the ability to stop anyone from taking it away from you. Never mind the legal status. Nick's right about this.

The problem is that the grant of a right is not a legal right. The grant is a promise. A promise that you will not be taken from your property. That's the only legal way to grant a property right, and it's not even a good way. If you want to give someone a gift, you have to make it clear that it is for a specific purpose. You can't just say, "I want you to have this."
...
"I'm going to take this away." "You can have it.". "But I don't want it. I want this for myself." That is the problem with the "right to be forgotten." It is an empty promise, a meaningless promise to the person who is being forgotten. And it doesn't even work. There is no legal mechanism to enforce it, because the promise is meaningless. So the right to "be forgotten" is just a way of saying, in effect, that I will never be remembered.

prompt: Nope, you're confusing separate programs. Atlas was the first generation US ICBM Titan I was the second generation one Titan II, which all the Titan launchers are based on, was the third generation heavy ICBM. There was essentially nothing in common between these three programs. Yes, three programs.
text:
Nope, you're confusing separate programs. Atlas was the first generation US ICBM Titan I was the second generation one Titan II, which all the Titan launchers are based on, was the third generation heavy ICBM. There was essentially nothing in common between these three programs. Yes, three programs.

The first Titan was a single stage, solid rocket booster. The second was an intermediate stage with a solid motor. And the final was basically a liquid rocket. So, the three Titan programs were all different. They were different in their design, in the way they were built, and in how they operated. But they all had the same basic design. It was just a matter of how you put it together. That's why the US Air Force was able to build the Atlas and Titan ICBMs. Because they had all of the components in place. All of them were the right size, all were in good shape, they just had to put them together in a way that made sense.

text: In article 1993Apr29.121501 is.morgan.com, jlieb is.morgan.com Jerry Liebelson writes... I want to know what weightlessness actually FEELS like. For example, is there a constant sensation of falling? Ron Baalke baalke kelvin.jpl.nasa.gov replied Yes, weightlessness does feel like falling. It may feel strange at first, but the body does adjust. The sensation is similar to the sensation you get when you are in a car that is going down a steep hill. You feel the car slowing down and you feel a slight pull on your chest. This pull is the same sensation that you experience when your body is in weightless conditions. When you fall, your heart rate slows down, and your blood pressure drops. Your body adjusts to this change in blood flow and heart rhythm. As you descend, the pull becomes less and less. Eventually, you will feel as if you have fallen for a long time. If you do not fall for long enough, it will be difficult to adjust to weight loss. Weightlessness is a very different sensation than weight. In weight, there is no sensation at all. There is only a feeling of weight and a sensation in your stomach. With weight you can feel your weight in the air, in other words, feel it. But with weight there are no sensations. So, when I say weight is weight without sensations, I mean that weight does not feel weighty. I do feel that I am heavier than I was before I lost weight (I am now about 5 pounds heavier). But I don't feel any weight at the moment. My weight has not changed. And I have not lost any of my weight since I started losing weight a few months ago. (The weight I had before was about 100 pounds.) I feel no weight when my body falls. That is, my heart is not beating.

But the problem is that in order to do that, they had to make the system very robust. Astronomy Space magazine's UK telephone newsline carries the times to see the Russian Space Station Mir which will be visible every EVENING some time between 9 o'clock and midnight from April 27 to May 7. It's about as bright as Jupiter at its best. There are two cosmonuats on board. For the time to watch, tel. 020 7292 7500.

The Russian space station Mir is visible from the UK from 9pm to midnight on April 28 to June 7, and from 8pm on June 8 to 9. The station is about the same size as the moon. You can see it from any time of day. If you're in the middle of the night, you can watch it with binoculars. But if you want to be sure, it's best to get up early and go to bed early. This is the only time you'll be able to view the station from UK soil.
