prompt: Having read in the past about the fail safe mechanisms on spacecraft, I had assumed that the Command Loss Timer had that sort of function. text:
Having read in the past about the fail safe mechanisms on spacecraft, I had assumed that the Command Loss Timer had that sort of function. However I always find disturbing the oxymoron of a NO OP command that does something. If the command changes the behavior or status of the spacecraft it is not a NO OP command. Of course this terminology comes from a Jet Propulsion Laboratory which has nothing to do with jet propulsion.

The Command Failure Timers are used to control the failure of spacecraft. The failure is detected by the timer and the mission is aborted. This is a very important function and is used in many spacecraft to abort the flight. In the case of Apollo, the abort was to the moon. It was not to land on the earth. I have read that in some cases the Mission Control Center (MCC) has the ability to override the NOOP command and abort a mission. There is no way to know if this is true or not. But I do know that it has been done. So I am not sure what the purpose of this function is. Perhaps it was used for aborting the landing on earth?
...
I have also read about a command called the "Fail Safe" that is sent to spacecraft when the system is in a state of failure. That command is to shut down the systems and to stop the countdown. When the Fail Safe command was sent, it did not stop all the functions of that spacecraft but it stopped the Countdown. Since the MCC has no control over the operation of any spacecraft in flight, this command does not have any effect on that mission and it does nothing for the Apollo missions.

Todays New York TImes just wrote about a pact being negotiated between us and the Russians to develope High Temperature Gas Cooled Fission Reactors using Re Cycled Weapons Grade plutonium from Warhead stockpiles. THe fuel will be pelletized in ceramic for safety, and then after depletion will be sufficiently contaminated with by products to make extraction of the remaining plutonium hazardous enough to deter re use. Apparently the project will be led by General Atomics of San Diego with funding from the US GOvernment. THe pilot plant will be built and operated by the russians. The reactor will have a capacity of about 1.5 MW, but will produce about 2 MW of heat. It will use a fuel that is a mixture of plutonium and uranium. This will make it a very safe reactor.

The reactor is expected to be operational in about 20 years. In the meantime, the United States will continue to build a nuclear weapons stockpile. We will also continue our efforts to reduce the number of nuclear warheads in the world.

prompt: This is one of those yes, but things. It's true that a hydraulically pressurized tube can be somewhat more rigid than an unpressurized tube, but even at 2000 PSI levels a hydraulic hose will bend rather easily, though it's straight on compressive strength is high, and it's torsional resistance increase is practically nil. text:
This is one of those yes, but things. It's true that a hydraulically pressurized tube can be somewhat more rigid than an unpressurized tube, but even at 2000 PSI levels a hydraulic hose will bend rather easily, though it's straight on compressive strength is high, and it's torsional resistance increase is practically nil. On the other grasping member, there's no doubt that hydraulic leverage exists in nature. Tree roots are an example. The tree roots can bend, they can flex, the tree can move, it can even bend back and forth. But the fact is that the roots don't have any leverage. They're just a mass of water.

The same is true for the human body. We have no leverage, we're a fluid mass. And the reason we have leverage is because we can use our muscles to move our bodies. If we were a solid mass, like a tree, then we wouldn't be able to use the muscles. So, if we could use muscles, our body would be a rigid mass that would have a very high compressing strength. That's why we use a lot of strength in our joints. Our joints are the only part of our anatomy that can actually move. In fact, in the case of a human, a joint is a kind of "motor" that allows us to do things like walk, run, jump, etc. A joint can also be used to compress the body, to make it more stable. For example, when you're standing up, you can compress your spine, which is the part that supports your body weight. When you compress it, your muscles can contract to help you stand up. This is why you have to stand on your toes when standing on a chair. You can't just stand there and let gravity do the work. Your muscles have got to work to keep you standing. There's a reason why the knees of the average

text:
Sure. Why keep using oil? A hydrogen electric economy would likely be cleaner and more efficient in the long run. The laws of supply and demand should get the transition underway before we reach a critical stage of shortage.

The problem is that the oil industry is not going to let go of its oil. It is going after the next big thing. And it is doing so with a vengeance. In the past decade, the U.S. has added more than 1 million new oil rigs, and the industry has spent more on lobbying than on research and development. Oil companies are spending more money on lobbyists than they are on R&D. They are lobbying for more tax breaks, more subsidies, less regulation, higher oil prices, lower taxes, fewer regulations, a bigger government, bigger budgets, etc. This is a recipe for disaster. If we don't get our act together, we will be in for a long, long time without a viable alternative to oil, which is why I am calling for an end to the war on oil and a transition to a sustainable energy system.

text:
The following press release was distributed April 1 by NASA Headquarters. Space Station Redesign Advisory Members Named Along with Dr. Charles M. Vest, recently named by Vice President Albert Gore to head the advisory committee on the redesign of the Space Station, NASA has announced the names of representatives from government and industry and academic experts from across the country to participate in an independent review of the redesign options being developed by NASA. I am extremely honored to have been selected to lead this important review panel. America's future in science and technology and as a world leader in space demands our utmost attention and care, said Vest. "The Space Shuttle program has been a tremendous success, and I look forward to working with the new leadership to ensure that the Shuttle remains a vital part of our nation's space program for many years to come." The Space Center Houston, which is home to the International Space station, is the home of NASA's Johnson Space Centre, where the shuttle is built. The Johnson Center is also home the Johnson Shuttle Landing Facility, the launch pad for the space shuttle, as well as the Vehicle Assembly Building, Vehicle Integration Building and the Launch Complex. NASA is currently in the process of selecting a new name for this facility. This is a joint effort between the NASA Johnson and Johnson Enterprise Services divisions. In addition to Drs. David A. Koepp and Charles A Vest as members of this advisory panel, other members include: Dr David Meech, Director, Johnson Aerospace Center, Houston; Dr John Mather, Chief, Space Flight Operations, Kennedy Space Centers, Fla.; Dr Robert L. Crippen, President, Cravath, Swaine & Moore, Inc., Houston. Dr Charles E. Mazzucchelli, Vice Chairman, National Space Council, Washington, D.C.

The first eclipse will occur on May 1, at 03:05 UT. The second will take place on July 20, when the shadow of Jupiter will pass over Iapoetus, the largest moon of Titan. IAPETUS IS THE LARGEST MOON IN THE SOLAR SYSTEM. It is the only moon in the solar system that is larger than the Earth. Its diameter is about 1.5 times that of Earth's moon. In fact, it is so large that it has been called the "Earth's Moon." The moon is also the second-largest object in our solar neighborhood, after the sun. This is because the moon's orbit is tilted by about 30 degrees from the plane of our planet's orbital plane. When the Moon is closest to the Sun, its orbit takes it about 4.6 million miles (7.2 million kilometers) from Earth, while when it's farthest from us, about 2.4 million (3.1 million) miles. As a result, Iapsetus is much closer to us than any other moon, including the other moons of Mars. Because of its size, astronomers have been able to study the effects of tidal forces on the surface of this moon by studying the tidal bulges that form on its surface. Each network has its own set of resources, but the net has a common resource, the Internet. This resource is the 'net' itself. It is not a single entity, it is an interconnected network. There are many different kinds of 'nets', but they all have one thing in common: they are all interconnected. A network is made up of a number of interconnected networks and each network can be thought of as a 'node' in the network, a node in a chain of nodes. For example, if you are on the internet, you can connect to any of your local networks (the local network) and you will be able to access any other network (any other local or remote network). The internet is also a series of network nodes, each of which is connected by a link. These links are called 'hops' and they can take many forms. Some of them are direct connections, others are indirect connections. You can also use a hop to connect from one network to another, for example from the local internet to the remote internet. If you want to send a message to someone on another network you use the hop. When you send an email to a person on a different network they will receive it. They will then send you a reply. The Sun's position in relation to the earth is called the ecliptic. It's a circle that circles the plane of our planet. This is the same plane that the moon orbits around. So the Moon is also in a plane with the planet, which is why it's called a "satellite".
This is a very interesting concept, because it means that we can actually see the planets from the other side of Earth. We can see them from space, as well as from our own planet!
So, if we could see planets in space from Earth, we would be able to see their moons, too. And if they were in orbit around the solar system, they would also be in our orbit. That would mean that they could be seen from other planets, or even from outer space. I'm sure you've heard of some of these ideas, like the idea of a planet orbiting the center of mass of an object, so that it would appear to be a single point. But this is not the case. The other process, the sulfide process, is the one that is most commonly used. It is also the most expensive. In fact, it is so expensive that it has been banned in some countries. But it's still used by some companies. And it works. I've seen it used to make a lot of things. For example, I have a few of these in my office. They are used for the glassware. You can see the difference in color. If you look at the picture of the glasses, you can tell that the color is different. That's because the sulfur is removed. So, if you want to use the same color, just use a different sulfur. Or, use different colors. There are many different ways to do this. Some people use sulfur in a very thin layer, like a thin film. Others use it in layers. Still others use sulfides in different layers, so that you get different color changes. This is called a "sulfide-solution."

prompt: This is a good question. There are major blind spots in our understanding of what makes the earth habitable. For example, why does the earth's atmosphere have the concentration of oxygen it does? The naive answer is photosynthesis , but this is clearly incomplete.
text:
This is a good question. There are major blind spots in our understanding of what makes the earth habitable. For example, why does the earth's atmosphere have the concentration of oxygen it does? The naive answer is photosynthesis, but this is clearly incomplete. The oxygen in the atmosphere is not a byproduct of photosynthetic activity, but is produced by the photosystems of plants and animals.

The oxygen is also produced in a number of other ways, including the production of carbon dioxide and methane. These are all important, and they are important for the life of the planet. But the oxygen produced is only a small part of our total oxygen supply. We also need to consider the amount of water in Earth's oceans. Water is the most important element in life, so it is important to understand how much water is in these oceans, how it changes over time, what the water content is, etc. This is an important question, because it affects the ability of life to survive. It also affects how we can use the oceans to grow food. If we don't know how many oceans there are, we cannot grow enough food to feed the world. So, the question is: how do we know the total amount and how can we use it?
...

The image below is a stereo view of Mars taken by the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter. It is the first stereo picture of any planet taken from orbit. This is an image that was taken in 2004, so it is not as good as the images from Hubble. However, it does show the surface of Martian surface features. You can see the bright, dark, flat, cratered, or smooth surface. There are also some bright features on the Martian side. In the lower left corner of this image is Mars' equator. Mars is about 1.5 million kilometers (1.1 million miles) from Earth.

text:
Well, no, during the original deployment mission the HST aperture door was not opened until after the Shuttle had landed. I presume that during a re boost mission HST would be berthed in the orbiter with the orbiter bay doors shut but still there would be lots of contamination worries. I understand that the EVA suits are one of the hardest things to keep clean. But I still don't know where the idea is coming from that HST _NEEDS_ a re boost. It's not like the shuttle is going to be in orbit for a long time. The shuttle has been in space for only a few months. If the reboost is to happen, it should be done in a hurry.

The other thing that I don´t understand is why the crew would have to go through the hatch to get to the space station. Why not just open the door and let the astronauts go in? I´m not sure if the doors are designed to open automatically or if they are manually opened. Maybe the astronaut would need to press a button on the control panel to do it. Or maybe the buttons are not programmed to automatically open. In any case, I think that it would make more sense to have the windows open and the air flow through them. That way the cabin would not be contaminated. And the window would also be protected from the vacuum of space.

text:
Original to wats scicom.AlphaCDC.COM G'day wats scicom.AlphaCDC.COM 20 Apr 93 18 17, wats scicom.AlphaCDC.COM wrote to All wAC wats scicom.AlphaCDC.COM Bruce Watson, via Kralizec 3 713 602 wAC The Apollo program cost something like 25 billion at a time when wAC the value of a dollar was worth more than it is now. No one would wAC take the offer. If we assume 6 inflation since 1969, that 25B would be worth about 100B GD reckon a moon mission today could cost only 10B. Thats a factor of ten reduction in cost. The cost of the Apollo missions was about 10% of what it would cost to build a new moon base. So the cost reduction is about 50% or more. I think the best way to think about this is to compare it to the price of building a house. A house costs about $100,000 to $200,00. It takes about a year to finish. You can buy a used house for $50,0000. Now you can build it for about the same price. But you have to pay for the materials, the labor, and the electricity. And you need to buy the land. In the case of Apollo, you could build the moon bases for a fraction of that cost, but you would have a much smaller base and you wouldn't have the resources to do it. Apollo was a great program, it was the greatest technological achievement of our time. We should be proud of it, we should not be ashamed of its cost and its limitations. However, I don't think it should have been done. There are many other ways to go about it that would not have cost so much. For example, if we had a lunar base, then we could have built it in a few years. Or we can use the lunar surface as a base for other things. This is a very good idea. What I am saying is that the costs of doing the program were too high. They were not justified by the benefits.

The Apollo Program was not a success

text: Space Station Redesign Leader Says Cost Goal May Be Impossible Today 4 6 the Washington Post ran an article with the headline shown above. The article starts with A leader of the NASA team in charge of redesigning the planned space station said yesterday the job is tough and may be impossible. O'Connor is quoted saying whether it is possible to cut costs that much and still provide for meaningful research is a real question for me. O'Connor said everything is fair game, including dropping or curtailing existing contracts with the aerospace industry, chopping management of the space station program at some NASA facilities around the country, working closely with the Russian space station Mir, and using unmanned Titan rockets to supplement the manned space shuttle fleet. "We're going to have to make some tough choices," O 'Connor told the Post. He said the cost of a new space lab is $100 million to $150 million, but he said that's a conservative estimate. NASA has been working on a redesign of its space center since the late 1990s. It's been a long time coming. In the early 1990's, the agency was planning to build a space laboratory in the former space shuttles' hangar at the Kennedy Space Center. But the shuttle program was cancelled, so the new lab was never built. Now, NASA is working to redesign the facility to be more like the International Space Station. That's the goal of NASA's Commercial Crew Program, which is being run by Boeing and SpaceX. Boeing is building the CST-100 Starliner, a capsule that will be used to ferry astronauts to and from the station. SpaceX is developing the Dragon capsule, used for cargo delivery to the ISS. Both companies are working with NASA to develop the spacecraft. If the company can't get the Starliners to orbit, it will have no choice but to use the cargo ships. So, if the commercial crew program is not successful, then NASA will need to find a way to get astronauts into space. One option is to continue using the shuttered space stations. However, that would mean NASA would have a lot of shut down hardware in its facilities. Another option would be to keep the current space labs, such as the Space Shuttle

text:
Hello out there, If your familiar with the COMET program then this concerns you. COMET is scheduled to be launched from Wallops Island sometime in June. Does anyone know if an official launch date has been set?

The COMETS program is a joint effort between NASA and the Russian space agency Roscosmos. The goal of the program, according to NASA, is to "provide a means for the United States to conduct a series of low-cost, high-quality, and reliable space launches."
.
"The goal is for us to have a capability to launch a variety of payloads into low Earth orbit," said NASA's Glenn Research Center Director, Dr. John Grunsfeld. "We're going to do it in a way that is cost effective, reliable, safe, secure, efficient, that we can do in the shortest time possible." Grunfeld said that the first launch of COMets will be in July. Gruntfeld added that NASA is working with Roskosmos to develop a launch vehicle that will allow the U.S. to compete with Russia for launches. He said the launch will take place from the Wallop Island Launch Complex in Virginia.


NASA's Walloping Island launch site is located in Walla Wall, Virginia, about 30 miles north of Washington, D.C. It is the only launch pad in North America that can accommodate the large rocket that would be used to carry the spacecraft to the space station. NASA has a contract with Orbital Sciences Corporation to provide the rocket for this mission. Orbital is currently developing a new rocket, the Antares, which will carry a Cygnus spacecraft. This will replace the Atlas V rocket.

The 'edge' of a distribution is the point where the distribution has a'sharp' edge, and the 'whiteness' is a point at which the distributions are 'thin'. The 'Whitening' point is where a particular distribution becomes 'white' and is not a part or a component of any other distribution. The distribution of 'White' in the above example is called the Gaussian distribution and it is found in many different ways. It is also called a Gauss-Jordan distribution or the normal distribution because it has the same shape as a normal curve. In the case of this example, the white point of an Gauste-Küster distribution (the Gaus-Jensen distribution) is at the edge of its distribution which is 'black' (i.e. the black point in a black curve).

text:
Although the 1 billion scheme is a fantasy it's an old canard in the space business called trolling for billionaires, there is a good chance that a much smaller program 65 million will pass the 103rd Congress. This is the Back to the Moon bill, put together by the people who passed the Launch Services Purchase Act. The bill would incent private companies to develop lunar orbiters, with vendors selected on the basis of competitive bidding. There is an aggregate cap on the bids of 65 million.

The bill is not a new idea. It was first introduced in 2009 by Rep. John Culberson (R-TX) and has been introduced by a number of other members of Congress, including Reps. Mike Rogers (MI), Mike Conaway (TX), and John Mica (FL). The idea is to encourage private sector investment in space exploration. In the past, the idea has not been popular with the public. A recent poll found that only 30% of Americans support the concept of private space companies competing for government contracts. But the bill has a strong chance of passing. And it is likely to be a major factor in determining the future of the US space program.

Every aircraft has flight constraints for speed AOA power. When graphed, these define the 'flight envelope' of that aircraft, presumably so named because the graphed line encloses envelopes the area on the graph that represents conditions where the aircraft doesn't fall out of the sky. Hence, 'pushing the envelope' becomes 'operating at or beyond the edge of the flight or operational envelope'. Note that the envelope isn't precisely known until someone actually flies the airplane in those regions up to that point, all there are are the theoretical predictions.

The graph above shows the AOAs of a number of aircraft. The graph is a little noisy, but it's a good starting point for understanding the concept. Note the vertical axis, which is the speed of sound. This is important because it is what determines the maximum AOCA (AOA) of an aircraft at any given speed. It is also important to note that this is not the same as the actual AODA, or actual altitude. ABOA is defined as 'the maximum altitude at which the aerodynamic lift is sufficient to maintain the lift-to-drag ratio at the specified A/D ratio'.

A blackhole is a point in space where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape. It's a very special kind of object, and it's not a real object.

The idea that a gamma ray burster is "very far" away is just a fancy way of saying that it is not very close to us. The gamma rays are coming from a source that is far from us, so they're not coming very fast. They're coming at a rate that's very slow. So, if you were to look at the gamma-ray bursts coming out of the source, you'd see that they were coming in a straight line. If you look closely, though, they would appear to have a curved shape. That's because the curvature of space is such that the light is bent in the direction of travel. This is the same thing that happens when you see a star in your backyard. You can see the star's light coming straight out from the sky, because it has a flat surface. But if the surface of your house is curved, the stars will appear curved. And that means that if we were looking at them from our backyard, we'd be seeing them coming towards us from all directions. We'd have no idea where

Instead it is flexible and can be bent and stretched. This is important because the solar sail needs to be able to bend and stretch in order to generate the energy needed to power the sails. In order for the Sail to work, the Sun must be shining on the surface of it. If the sun is too far away, then the wind will not be strong enough to push the material around. So the materials need to have some flexibility. Solar sail materials are made up of many different materials. Some are rigid and some are flexible. There are also materials that are both rigid (like the carbon fibers) and flexible (such as the Kevlar). The material that is used to make the Carbon Fiber Composite Sail is called Carbon Fibre Composite. Carbon fiber is the most common material used in Solar sailing. When the temperature of the atmosphere reaches a certain point, the pressure of this plasma becomes so great that it can no longer hold the heat. As a result, a coriolis effect occurs. I hold that space cannot be curved, for the simple reason that it can have no properties. Of properties we can only speak when dealing with matter filling the space. The second objection is that the curvature of space is not a property of the universe, but of matter. The universe is a collection of particles, and the particles are not themselves curved. If the matter is curved then the curved space must be a curvating space, which is impossible. This objection has been refuted by the work of many physicists, including Einstein. It is also refuted in a recent paper by David Deutsch, who has shown that there is no curvation in space itself. He has also shown how the laws of physics are consistent with the existence of curvatures in matter, as well as in other parts of nature. Deutch's paper is available here.

With the success in finding Neptune to explain the odd movments of Uranus, it was postulated that there might be another inner planet to explain Mercury's orbit. The theory of the inner planets is still a theory, but it's a good one. The theory is that the planets are all in a common orbit, and that they all have a similar mass. This is the same idea that explains why the moon orbits the earth. If you have two planets in the center of a sphere, they will all be in that same orbit and have the exact same mass, so they are in one big sphere. But if you put two more planets into the middle of that sphere and put them in different orbits, then you will have different masses. So the mass of each planet is different. And the orbits of all the other planets will be different as well. That's why we have four planets. They all orbit the Earth in exactly the right way.

.. One thing to recall. Putting a satellite as high as possible is one thing. Coming back to not only that altitude, but matching the position of it in its orbit on a subsequent mission is another thing. Any misalignment of the plane of the orbit during launch or being ahead or behind the target will require more fuel to adjust.

The problem is that the satellite is not in a stable orbit. It is in an elliptical orbit, which means that it is moving around the sun. The satellite's orbit is elliptic because it has a circular orbit around Earth. This means the satellites are moving in the same direction as the Earth, and the earth is rotating. So the spacecraft is spinning. And the rotation is causing the aircraft to move. In fact, the speed of rotation of a spacecraft can be measured by the angle between the axis of its rotation and its orbital plane. If the angular speed is greater than the orbital speed, then the vehicle is accelerating. But if the velocity is less than orbital velocity, it's not accelerating, so the craft is slowing down. That's why the pilot is trying to slow the ship down, because the acceleration is too great. As the vessel slows down it will be in more of an orbit that is more stable. Once the trajectory is stabilized, there is no need to worry about the altitude.

In the April edition of One Small Step for a Space Activist, Allen Sherzer Tim Kyger write Another problem is what are called 'wraps' or sometimes the 'center tax'. When work for a large program like Freedom or Shuttle is performed at a NASA center, the center skims off a portion which goes into what amounts to a slush fund. This money is used to fund work the center manager wants to fund. This sum is estimated to be over a third of the funds allocated. The center is then free to spend the money on whatever it wants. For example, if the Center wants a new building, it can spend all the slosh funds on it. If the Space Center is looking for new employees, they can use the fund to hire them. It is a way for the space center to get around the law that requires the centers to use a certain percentage of their funds for space activities.

The H STOL design is a bit different than the S S design. The H design has a single H-shaped payload fairing, and the ST design uses two Hs. This is because the payloads are not designed to be deployed in a straight line, but rather in an arc. In the case of a H, the fairings are designed so that they can be folded up and folded down, which is why the two fairs can have different lengths. Also, in the design of an H/ST, there is no need for a fair-basket, because there are no payload-fairing assemblies. Instead, a payload is attached to a "battery" that is mounted on the aft end of each fair. A battery is basically a battery-like structure that can store energy. It is also used to store the energy that would be generated by the solar arrays. So, if you have a solar array, you can use the battery to power the panels. If you don't have an energy source, then you need to use a generator to generate the power. That's why there's no fair basket. There is, however, an "energy storage" fair that holds the batteries. text: FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE Contact OASIS 310 364 2290 15 April 1993 Los Angeles, CA LOCAL NATIONAL SPACE SOCIETY CHAPTERS SPONSOR TALK BY L.A. ADVOCATE OF LUNAR POWER SYSTEM AS ENERGY SOURCE FOR THE WORLD On April 21, the OASIS and Ventura County chapters of the National Space Society will sponsor a talk by Lunar Power System LPS co inventor and vice president of the LPS Coalition, Dr. Robert D. Waldron. It will be held at 7 30 p.m. at the Rockwell Science Center in Thousand Oaks, CA. Dr. Waldron is currently a Technical Specialist in Space Materials Processing with the Space Systems Division of Rockwell International in Downey, California. He is a recognized world authority on lunar materials refinement. The talk will cover the history of lunar power systems, including the development of LPL, LPP, and LSP, as well as the current status of these systems. This will include a discussion of current and future lunar energy systems and the potential for lunar resources. The BATse team has been working on this problem for a while. They have been able to improve the timing by using a technique called "quantum tunneling" to measure the time it takes for light to travel from one detector to the next. In this way, they can measure how long it took for the light from the first detector (the "first light") to reach the second detector. Then they measure it again to see how much time the same light took to go from that second to that first. By doing this, the BATses can get a better idea of how fast the signal is traveling. It is a very accurate measurement. But it is still not fast enough to be able measure a signal that is moving at a speed of a few nanosescond. So the team is working to make the measurement more accurate. One of the problems is that the detectors are not very sensitive. If the signals are moving very fast, then the measurements will be off. And if the data is off, it will not be possible to tell if it was the actual signal or just a noise. To solve this issue, BATes are using the technique of "superposition" where they are measuring the arrival times of two signals at different locations. When the two detectors have the exact same arrival timing, this is called a "perfect" measurement, and the difference between the times is the "signal time."

prompt: I know its semantics, but the no op _doesn't_ do anything. The Command Loss Timer is simply looking for a command, any command. A no op is simply a spacecraft command that drops bits into the big bit bucket in the sky. No op also get used as timekeepers to provide millisecond delays between command sequences used on the thruster preps on GRO, er, Compton and to verify command links at the beginning of TDRS events.
text:
I know its semantics, but the no op _doesn't_ do anything. The Command Loss Timer is simply looking for a command, any command. A no op is simply a spacecraft command that drops bits into the big bit bucket in the sky. No op also get used as timekeepers to provide millisecond delays between command sequences used on the thruster preps on GRO, er, Compton and to verify command links at the beginning of TDRS events.

The noop is also used to check the status of the command link. If the link is not working, the spacecraft will not be able to send commands to the ground. This is a very important check, because if the connection is broken, then the mission is over. It is important to have a good connection to ground, so that the crew can send the commands and the satellite can receive them. In the case of a broken link, it is very easy to lose the signal and not know what happened. So, if you have an unreliable link and you are not sure what is going on, you should not send any commands. You should wait for the next link to be established. That is the only way to know if a link has been established or not.

text:
in answer to Amruth Laxman Apart from the fact that you get G in the pull out, not the dive, that figure is about right for sustained G, no protection. The duration of G, it's rate of onset, body position and support aids are all critical parts of the equation. I remember one note about instrumented gridiron players recording peaks about 200G. Stapp, the aviation doctor, either by accident or design, took a short period 80G in a rocket sled decelleration, eye balls out against a standard 1950's harness. He was able to record a peak of about 300G, but it was a very short peak. It was not sustained.

The other thing to consider is that the G-force is not a linear function of time. If you are going to be in an airplane, you need to have a good deal of control over the rate at which you accelerate. You need a lot of acceleration to get to the point where you can accelerate to G. That's why you have to do a G test. A G is a function, in part, of your body's ability to accelerate, and it is also a product of how much you're accelerating. So, if you want to go fast, your G will be high. But if your acceleration is slow, then your peak G may be low. And if the acceleration rate is high, there will also be a high G peak, because you will have been accelerating for a long time, so you'll have accumulated a large amount of energy. This is why it can be difficult to find a steady state G for an aircraft. There are many factors that affect G and the way it changes. For example, a pilot who is flying at a constant speed will not have the same G as a person who has been flying for some time at different speeds. In fact, he will probably have less G than a new pilot. Also, G can change with altitude. At high altitudes, acceleration will slow down, which will make the peak

text: Speech by Pete Worden Delivered Before the U.S. Space Foundation Conference Colorado Springs, Colorado April 15, 1993 What a delightful opportunity to cause some trouble. For providing me this forum I would sincerely like to thank the U.S. Space Foundation. My topic today is the Single Stage Rocket Technology rocket or SSRT. By I intend to speak of more. I will not be talking about the SSR, but rather the SST. The SRT is a single stage rocket. It is not a rocket that can be used for a space station. In fact, it is an SS rocket, and it has a very different purpose. This is because the purpose of the rocket is to carry a payload to orbit. That payload is called a satellite. A satellite is made up of a number of small satellites. Each satellite has its own propulsion system. These propulsion systems are called thrusters. They are used to move the satellite around the Earth. When the thruster is used, the spacecraft moves in a circular motion. If the thrust is too great, then the satellites will be thrown out of orbit and will crash into the ground. But if the engine is set too low, they will stay in orbit, just as a car stays in the center of its circle. So the single-stage rocket has two purposes. One is for carrying a spacecraft to a high orbit where it can then be launched into space. And the other is that it will carry the payload into orbit to be retrieved by the space shuttle. Now, I am not going to talk about how the rockets are made. There are many different types of rockets. Some are very simple, some are more complicated. All of them are based on the same basic principle. You have a propellant, a liquid fuel. Then you have an oxidizer, an oxygen. Finally, you add

I have included only those servers where there are special subdirectories for astro stuff or much material included into a general directories. This list is not a complete data set of possible places, so I would be very happy of all kind of notices and information depending on this listing. The newest version of this file is available via anonymous ftp as nic.funet.fi pub astro general astroftp.txt There are also many mirror copy archives for simtel 20.army.mil PC and sumex aim.stanford.edu Mac which are not included into this list. There is also a mirror of the US Naval Observatory which is included in the list of mirrors. It is located at the Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, DC. (The mirror is in a room in room 6B of Building 6, Room 6A, Building 7, room 7B, and room 8.) The mirror has a large mirror and a small mirror. Both mirrors are about 1.5 meters in diameter. A mirror mirror can be made of glass, aluminum, or other materials. Glass mirrors have a very high reflectivity and are very good for astronomy. Aluminum mirrors can have very low reflectivities and can also be used for telescopes. Aluminium mirrors, on the other hand, are much more expensive and have much lower reflectance. They are used in telescopes for the same reason as glass mirrors: they are more efficient. In general, the reflectances of a telescope are determined by the size of its mirror, its reflectiveness, how much light is reflected, etc. For a given reflectancy, a larger mirror will have more light reflected than a smaller mirror; a lower-reflectance mirror with a higher reflectency will be more reflective than one with lower reflection. If you want to know the exact reflectancies of your telescope, you can use the Reflectance Calculator. You can find the mirror's reflectant index in its description. To find out the approximate reflectants of any mirror you are interested in, use a simple formula: Reflectant Index = Reflectivity x Reflect

The International Astronautical Federation (IAF) is the international organization of space agencies and their members. It is a non-profit organization, and its members are the governments of the world. The IAF is responsible for the coordination of international space activities. Its members include the United States, the European Space Agency (ESA), the Russian Federal Space Administration (Roscosmos), Japan, Canada, Australia, India, China, South Korea, Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, Russia's National Space Science Center (NSSC), and the Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO). The International Space Station (ISS) was launched on April 24, 1998, by the Space Shuttle Discovery. NASA is an IAAF member. I am a member of IASA, IAC, ISA and IATC. My current position is as a Member of NASA Advisory Council. In addition to my work as an astronomer, my research interests include astrophysics, planetary science, space weather, solar physics, astrophysical and cosmological modeling, cosmology and astrophotography, astronomy and space science education, as well as the development of new technologies for space exploration. For more information, please visit my website at: www.tonyryan.com.

prompt: You're assuming that the low cost delivery system has to be a separate project. But why? If you are spending hundreds of millions of dollars in hopes of winning a billion dollar prize, it is cheaper to develop your own launch system, charging its entire development cost against your contest entry, than to try to do it with existing launchers. text:
You're assuming that the low cost delivery system has to be a separate project. But why? If you are spending hundreds of millions of dollars in hopes of winning a billion dollar prize, it is cheaper to develop your own launch system, charging its entire development cost against your contest entry, than to try to do it with existing launchers. No other demand is necessary.

The only other option is to build a new launcher, but that is a huge investment. It would be cheaper, and it would also be more reliable. The only way to get a reliable launcher is by building a rocket that can launch a lot of satellites. That is not a realistic option for a small company. So, the only option left is for the small companies to use existing launch systems. And that's what they are doing. They are using existing rockets. If they can't get the price down, they will build their own. This is the way it has been done for decades. There are no new entrants into the market. All the existing companies are just using the same old launchers, which are not reliable, or not cheap enough, to compete.

prompt: According to this reasoning there are no rights, at least none that I can think of.... Let's see. Do I have a right to unpolluted air? No, because the majority drive cars and use goods that create air pollution in the manufacturing process. Do I have the right to clean water?
text:
According to this reasoning there are no rights, at least none that I can think of.... Let's see. Do I have a right to unpolluted air? No, because the majority drive cars and use goods that create air pollution in the manufacturing process. Do I have the right to clean water? Yes, but the water is polluted by the sewage that is pumped into the city. So, I don't have any right.

The same logic applies to the rights of the people. The people have no right, and the government has no power to protect them. If the state is going to do anything, it has to be done by people, not by government. And the only way to get people to obey the law is to make it easy for them to disobey it. That's why the police are there. They are the ones who enforce the laws. But the cops are not there to enforce rights. In fact, they are often the very people who violate rights by violating the rules. For example, the cop who stops you for speeding is not enforcing your rights; he is violating your right not to have your car towed. He is enforcing the rule that you can't drive a car that has been damaged by a speeding ticket. You can get a ticket for that, too, if you are caught speeding. It is the same with the policeman who arrests you. His job is simply to arrest you, to take you to jail, where you will be held until you pay the fine. This is why you have to pay your fines. Otherwise, you would be free to drive away. (See the article "The Right to Drive" by John Lott.)
...
In the end, there is no such thing as a "right" to anything

I don't think a reboost exercise is analogous to a shuttle landing launch in terms of stresses misalignments etc. I would think of the reboost as a gentile push, where a landing, then launch as two JOLTS which would put more mechanical stress on the instruments. Additionally, there might be a concern about landing loads to the shuttle in the event of a laden landing. Finally, probably some thought went into possible contamination problems if the instruments came back to earth.

The re-boost is a very different thing from a launch. The re boost is not a rocket engine burn. It is an effort to get the spacecraft to orbit. In the case of re boosters, the goal is to increase the speed of an object that is moving at a constant velocity. This is done by increasing the thrust of one engine. If the object is accelerating at the same rate as the engine, it will accelerate at that same speed. However, if it is slowing down, or if there is some other factor that slows it down (such as atmospheric drag), then the acceleration will be less. So, in order to accelerate the vehicle, you need to change the velocity of that object. That is, to make it accelerate faster. To do this, a booster needs to be able to generate a thrust that can overcome the drag of air. A booster can be made to do that by adding a second engine to it. But, that second rocket is going to have to go faster than the first one. And, since the second booster is also going faster, this second one is actually going slower than it was before. Therefore, when the two boosters are combined, they are going at different speeds. As a result, one of them will have a higher acceleration than before, and the other will slow down. Since the booster has to overcome drag, its acceleration is greater than that of its predecessor. Thus, as it accelerates, so does the satellite. When

The shuttle is a great vehicle and I'm glad we have it but it's not the only vehicle that can do the job. There are other vehicles that are better suited for the mission. For example, the Space Launch System is an expendable vehicle. It's a heavy lift vehicle with a very large payload capacity. That's what we're doing. But it has a limited payload capability. So it can't do everything that the shuttle can. And it doesn't fly as often as it could. If you look at the cost of the Shuttle, it was a huge investment. You can see that in the budget. They spent $1.5 billion on that vehicle alone. Now, if you add up the costs of all the other things that we need to do to get to Mars, you can get a pretty good idea of what it would cost to fly the vehicle for one mission and then to keep it going for another mission, which would be a long time. In fact, I think it might be more cost effective to just keep the spacecraft in orbit for several years and just fly it once a year. A large telescope is needed to get a decent image, but it also needs a huge aperture to capture the full amount that has been radiating away. So, to make the most of the energy available, an array of telescopes is required. And this is where the problem arises. If the telescopes are too large, they will be too big to fit into the space available. They will also be very expensive to build, as they need to accommodate the large mirrors and other equipment that are required to take the images. But if the arrays are small, then they can fit in the available space, because they are not as large as the mirrors. Gaia is a mission to map the Earth's surface and atmosphere. This is an important mission because it is able to measure the composition of our atmosphere and the amount of water in the atmosphere, which is important for understanding the origin of life on Earth. In addition, it can measure how much energy is being emitted by the Sun and how that energy affects the climate. So, the more data we have, we can better understand the processes that are going on in our solar system. I think that the Gaia data is going to be very useful for the search for life. And I hope that it's going be available to us by mid-2015.

text: Forwarded from the Mars Observer Project MARS OBSERVER STATUS REPORT April 30, 1993 11 30 AM PDT DSS 65 Madrid 34 meter antenna did not acquire the expected Mars Observer Spacecraft signal at the scheduled beginning of track yesterday morning 4 29 at approximately 6 00 AM. Indications were that the spacecraft had entered a Fault Protection mode sometime between that time and receipt of normal telemetry at the end of the previous station pass DSS 15 Goldstone 34 meter antenna at approximately 8 00 PM the evening before. Entry into Contingency Mode was verified when signal was reacquired and telemetry indicated that the spacecraft was sun coning. After subsystem engineers reported all systems performing nominally, fault protection telemetry modes were reconfigured and memory readouts of command system Audit Queue and AACS Attitude and Articulation Control Subsystem Starex performed. The spacecraft entered the Fault Prevention Mode at about 9:00 PM. DSCA-1 was activated and the DSI-2 and DSE-3 antennas were activated. A second DSO-4 antenna was also activated, but the antenna had not been activated by the time the first DSA-5 antenna reached the Earth. At approximately 10:30 PM, the second antenna activated its antenna and was in the same Fault-Protection Mode as the other antennas. This antenna is the only antenna that is capable of transmitting data to the ground. It is also the most sensitive antenna on the mission. During the next few hours, DSB-6 and 7 antennas, which are also in Fault Protected Mode, were also active. All antennas are in a state of readiness to receive data from Mars. Mark Prado Old pioneer song from the 1850's or so goes as follows In a cavern, in a canyon, Excavating for a mine, Dwelt a miner, forty niner, And his daughter, CLEMENTINE Chorus Oh my darling, Oh my darling, Oh my darling Clementine. You are lost and gone forever, Oh my darling Clementine. I've also had it explained but not confirmed from a reliable data source that CLEMENTINE is an acronym. Something like Combined Lunar Elemental Mapper Experiment on Extended Non Terrestrial Intercept Near Earth. The name is a reference to the fact that the moon is the only place in the solar system where the elements are not in equilibrium. It is also a play on the word "clementine" which is Latin for "sweetheart". The song is about Clementines love of the earth and the love that she has for her mother.

The song was written by the late, great, and beloved songwriter, John Lennon. Lennon was a huge fan of Clementina and was very fond of her. He wrote the song in his spare time and it was recorded by his friend, the legendary, songwriting genius, George Martin. Martin was also an avid Clementinist and would often sing the songs with Lennon and his band. In the early 1970's, Martin and Lennon were in London and were invited to perform at the Royal Albert Hall. They were also invited by Clementino's mother, who was in attendance. She was so impressed with the performance that her son, Clemente, was named after her daughter. This was the first time that a song about a child was given a name. Clementini was born in Italy in 1892. Her father was an Italian immigrant and her father's family was from Italy. When she was young, she lived in England and studied at a school in Oxford. After graduating, her family moved to Italy and she studied in Rome. There she met her future husband, Paul McCartney. Paul was her first love and they married in 1947.

text:
The most current orbital elements from the NORAD two line element sets are carried on the Celestial BBS, 513 427 0674, and are updated daily when possible. Documentation and tracking software are also available on this system. As a service to the satellite user community, the most current elements for the current shuttle mission are provided below. The Celestial BBS may be accessed 24 hours day at 300, 1200, 2400, 4800, or 9600 bps using 8 data bits, 1 stop bit, no parity.

The NORad two-line element set is updated every day, with the exception of the first day of each month. This is to ensure that the elements are not lost or corrupted during the flight. If the two lines are lost, they are replaced with a new line. For example, if the second line is lost on a flight, it is replaced by the third line, which is the same as the original line but with one stop. In addition, a second stop is added to each line to prevent the line from being lost. A second-stop is also added for each satellite in the system, to allow for redundancy. These two stop bits are used to determine the position of a satellite. When the stop-bit is set, all satellites in a line are in their correct position. However, when the start-bits are set to zero, then the satellites are at their current position, regardless of whether the end-Bit is zero or not. Thus, in order to maintain the correct positions of all the spacecraft, two stops are added. Each satellite is assigned a unique stop, so that if one satellite moves, another satellite will not be affected. Also, each stop has a different start bit. Therefore, for example if a stop was set at zero and the other satellites were at the beginning of their stop sequence, one of them would be at its stop position and another would not, even if they were in different positions.


NORAD Two Line Element Set

text:
I feel compelled to complain the statement that recent observations rule out merging neutron stars as sources of gamma ray bursts is utterly false, even though it is popular enough to make it to BATSE press releases. The idea behind the statement is as follows if you smack two neutron stars together, or have a neutron star be gobbled up by a black hole, a lot of energy is released, enough for a gamma ray burst at a cosmological distance. But, so the reasoning continues, this energy is released below a lot of matter, so the radiation becomes thermalized and you expect to see roughly a blackbody spectrum. The observed spectra are strongly non thermal, so this model must be wrong.

The problem is that the observed spectrum is not thermal. It is a spectrum of the gamma rays, not the thermal radiation. This is because the energy released by the neutron is absorbed by matter. So the spectrum does not show the expected thermal emission. In fact, the spectroscopic data show that there is no thermal energy release at all. There is only a very weak thermal spectrum, and the only way to explain this is to assume that a large amount of thermal matter is present. If this were the case, then the black holes would be emitting thermal gamma radiation, but the data do not support this. Instead, we see a strong thermal signal, which is consistent with the idea that matter exists in the vicinity of neutron-star binaries. However, if the matter were present, it would have to be very dense, because it has to absorb a great deal of radiation to produce the same amount. And this would not be the way that it works. A neutron has a mass of about 1.5 times that of an electron, while an atom has about 10 times the mass. Therefore, there would need to have been a huge amount, about 100 times more than the amount that is emitted by neutron and atom stars. That is, to get the 100x10^-3 mass, you would require a 100,000,0000,00,0001,100,0002,10,3x1010,1,5x100^3 neutron, an atomic nucleus

The Capabilities Maturing Model is a set of criteria that is used to rate software quality. The model is based on the following criteria:
,
. Capable of being used in a mission critical environment.2
This is the most important criterion for software developers. It is important to note that the Capabilites Maturer Model does not consider the quality of the software itself. For example, a software developer may be able to write a program that does something that a human can do, but the program may not be as good as the human's.3
 the ability to be used by a large number of people.4
In order to meet the requirements of a contract, the contractor must be capable of meeting the needs of many people at the same time.5
the ability of an organization to maintain the contract.6
A contract is considered to have a high Capablity Maturance if the organization can maintain it for a long period of time without major problems.7

Has anyone ever heard of a food product called Space Food Sticks? I remember those awful things. They were dry and crumbly, and I recall asking my third grade teacher, Miss G'Francisco, how they kept the crumbs from floating around in zero G. She had no clue. The food is made of the same stuff that astronauts eat. It's a mixture of corn starch and corn meal. The corn is mixed with water and then the cornmeal is added. This mixture is then heated in a microwave oven. When the mixture reaches a temperature of about 180 degrees, it is heated again. At this point, the food has been heated for about 30 minutes. After this, a small amount of water is removed from the mix and the water evaporates. Then the remaining corn and water mixture are mixed again and heated. Finally, this mixture has reached a boiling point of 180°. Once the temperature reaches this temperature, all the moisture is evaporated and all of it goes into the microwave. As the microwaves heat up, they are able to break down the starch into smaller pieces. These pieces are then mixed into a liquid form. A small quantity of this liquid is poured into each of these food sticks. Each stick is about the size of an orange. You can see the sticks in the picture below.

Having just started this a couple of months ago, our sub us currently subscribed by only about ten other boards, but more are being added. We get our news articles re on Internet, via ftp from NASA sites, and from a variety of aerospace related periodicals. We get a fair amount of questions on space topics from students who access the system.

We have a very active and friendly community of users, who are all very knowledgeable about space and space related topics. Our BTS is a great place to get information on the latest space news, as well as to discuss current events and current space activities. The BMS is also a good place for students to learn about the various space programs and activities, including the Space Shuttle program.

text: Press Release No.19 93 Paris, 22 April 1993 Users of ESA's Olympus satellite report on the outcome of their experiments Today Europe's space telecommunications sector would not be blossoming as it now does, had OLYMPUS not provided a testbed for the technologies and services of the 1990s. This summarises the general conclusions of 135 speakers and 300 participants at the Conference on Olympus Utilisation held in Seville on 20 22 April 1993. The conference was organised by the European Space Agency ESA and the Spanish Centre for the Development of Industrial Technology CDTI. OLYMPUS has been particularly useful in bringing satellite telecommunications to thousands of new users, thanks to satellite terminals with very small antennas VSATs. The first of these terminals was installed in the United States in 1993, and since then the number of users has grown rapidly. In the first quarter of 1993 the total number was over 100,000, with the majority of them in Europe. This is a significant increase on previous years, when the figure was around 20, 000. OlyMPus has also been a major factor in helping to develop the services and products of Europe in this area. For example, the development of a new satellite communication system, called the "Olympus" system, has resulted in a number new services being developed. These include the use of satellite communications for telemedicine, tele-education, telecommunications, television broadcasting, radio broadcasting and satellite navigation. A number more services are in development, including the provision of telecommunication services for emergency services, for example in case of earthquakes, floods, fires, etc. Other services include telemarketing, e-mail, internet access, satellite television, telephone services. All of this is possible thanks, in part, to the Olysus satellite terminal. It is the only terminal in use in Spain that has a very tiny antenna, which allows it to be used in remote areas. As a result, it has become a key component in providing services to remote communities. But a human driver is much easier to design, because it is easier for the human to control the vehicle. And the Voyager is an extremely large vehicle, so it has to have a huge amount of power. So it needs a big, huge power source. Voyager has enough power to run for about a year, which is about the same as a typical car would need. If you were to take a regular car and put it in the middle of a desert, you would have to put a power plant in there. You would not be able to get the power from the sun. text:
If you're doing large scale satellite servicing, being able to do it in a pressurized hangar makes considerable sense. The question is whether anyone is going to be doing large scale satellite servicing in the near future, to the point of justifying development of such a thing. You'd almost certainly use air. Given that you have to pressurize with something, safety considerations strongly suggest making it breathable even if the servicing crew is using oxygen masks for normal breathing, to avoid needing a ventilation system, it's nice if the hangar atmosphere is breathable in a pinch it makes mask functioning much less critical.

The other thing that's important is that the air is not going into the cabin. It's going out the back of the vehicle. That's the only way to get it out. If you want to put it into a cabin, you'd have a problem.
 the other way around. I don't know if you've ever seen a space shuttle launch. There's a lot of air in there. In fact, the shuttle is so big that it has a huge amount of cabin pressure. So if it were to blow up, there's no way you could get the oxygen out of it. But if there was a leak, that would be a disaster. And if that leak were large enough, then you would have an explosion. This is why the space shuttles are so safe. They have huge amounts of oxygen in them.

text:
Astronomy Space magazine's UK telephone newsline carries the times to see the Russian Space Station Mir which will be visible every EVENING some time between 9 o'clock and midnight from April 27 to May 7. It's about as bright as Jupiter at its best. There are two cosmonuats on board. For the time to watch, tel. 020 7292 7500.

The Russian space station Mir is visible from the UK from 9pm to midnight on April 28 to June 7, and from 8pm on June 8 to 9. The station is about the same size as the moon. You can see it from any time of day. If you're in the middle of the night, you can watch it with binoculars. But if you want to be sure, it's best to get up early and go to bed early. This is the only time you'll be able to view the station from UK soil.

Well, I was dead wrong. text:
sci.space readers can skip the first paragraph Yesterday, in response to Henry Spencer's question about the temperature of a blackbody in interstellar space, I said Dust grains acts as blackbodies, and they're at 40 150 K. Well, I was dead wrong. Our local interstellar dust expert, Bruce Draine, has informed me that dust grains _aren't_ good radiators in the far IR, which is why they are so warm actually, the ambient radiation field from distant stars can bring a true blackbody to only 3 or 4 Kelvin. Sorry, Henry, and anyone else I misled. Obviously, time for me to take another ISM class In other news, Alan Stern of the Southwest Research Institute gave a talk on the Pluto Charon binary system yesterday. He said that the system is a "perfect storm" of conditions for life, including a large, cold, dense, rocky core, a small, warm, icy, gas-rich outer shell, an atmosphere, water ice, methane, ammonia, carbon monoxide, nitrogen, oxygen, hydrogen, helium, argon, neon, xenon and other elements. The system has a mass of about 1.5 times that of Earth, but it's only about 0.1% the size. It's a very interesting system, with a lot of potential for future exploration. I'll be watching the talk.

The spacecraft is in a very low orbit, so it's not going to be able to get very far from the Earth, but it will be in the right place at the correct time to receive the signals. The spacecraft will then be instructed to go to a search orbit and wait for the data to come back. If the search is successful, the command will tell the craft to return to Earth and re-enter the atmosphere. This is a good thing, because if the probe is not able reenter, it could be destroyed by the heat of reentry. But if it does reenters, there's no way to tell if there was a problem with the attitude control system. So the mission is to find out what happened. And if you're lucky, you'll get a signal back from your home planet.

They could have beaten us if either Their rocket hadn't blown up on the pad thus setting them back, and or A Saturn V went boom. If they had beaten us, I speculate that the US would have gone head and done some landings, but we also would have been more determined to set up a base both in Earth Orbit and on the Moon. Whether or not we would be on Mars by now would depend upon whether the Soviets tried to go.

The Soviets would not have had the luxury of time to build a rocket that could beat us. The Soviets could not afford to wait for us to catch up. So they would probably have tried a lander first, which would give them a chance to beat the Americans. But they could only do that if they were able to land on a moon. And they couldn't do it if the moon was in the way. In other words, the Soviet Union would never have gotten a shot at the first moon landing. It would take a lot of work and a long time. I think the Russians would also have wanted to do a landing on Venus, because they knew that they wouldn't be able get a good shot of the Earth from there. That would mean that we wouldn the be in a position to try to take them out. We would then have to decide whether to stay on Earth or go to Venus. Venus would make it easier to keep the USSR out of our way, since we could just go there and take out the Venusians. On the other hand, if we went to the Sun, we'd have a much harder time keeping them from getting a foothold on our planet. This would leave us with a choice. The bibliography for the article cited a philosophical paper the name and author of which I sadly forget I believe the author was Italian on what constitutes a legal and or moral person, i.e., a being entitled to the rights normally accorded to a person. I think the paper was called "The Ethics of Alien Law" and it was written by a man named Giuseppe Mazzini. He was a lawyer and a professor of philosophy at the University of Padua. His paper is a very interesting read. In it he argues that the alien is not a human being, but a "non-human being" (i. e., an "alien") and that he is entitled, as a non-alien, to certain rights and privileges. M.M. is also a member of a group called the "Society for Alien Rights" which is an organization of lawyers and philosophers who are concerned with the legal rights of aliens. They are not, however, a formal legal organization. Their main activity is to provide legal advice to aliens who wish to challenge the legality of their alien status. This is the main reason why they are called a society. There are other groups, such as the International Society for Human Rights, which are more formal organizations. But the Society of Humanists, the most prominent of these, is more of an informal organization, and is concerned primarily with human rights issues. So, in the case of alien law, we have a situation where the question is, what is our legal system for aliens? The answer is that we do not have one. We have no legal systems for non humans. These engines burn for about 10 minutes, then shut down. After the shuttle re-enters the atmosphere, it is powered up for another 10-15 minutes. This is called reentry. Reentry is a very slow process, taking about 2 minutes to complete. During reentering, there is no air to slow the vehicle down, as the air pressure is so low that the engines cannot operate. text:
Correct, we have no parallax measurements on the bursts. Therefore, we can't tell whether they're slightly extra solar or not! which means that parallax can't tell us whether or not it's real close.

The only way to tell is to look at the brightness of the stars. The brightness is a measure of how bright the star is compared to the background. If the light from the burst is brighter than the average brightness, then it must be real. Otherwise, it could be a fake. So, the best way we know to determine if the event is real is by looking at how much the sky is lit up. This is the same way that we measure the distance to a star. We measure how far away the object is from us. Then, if we see a bright star, that means it is closer than we thought. It's a good way of determining if a burst was real or fake!

 the rocket is made of a single piece of aluminum. There are two pieces of the motor, one on each side. One piece is attached to the bottom of an aluminum tube. On the other side of this tube is an air-filled chamber. Inside the chamber is another piece, which is connected to a motor shaft. When the air is released, it pushes the two parts together. prompt: Hmmmm.... The prefix peri is Greek, not Latin, so it's usually used with the Greek form of the name of the body being orbited. That's why it's perihelion rather than perisol , perigee rather than periterr , and pericynthion rather than perilune . So for Jupiter I'd expect it to be something like perizeon .
text:
Hmmmm.... The prefix peri is Greek, not Latin, so it's usually used with the Greek form of the name of the body being orbited. That's why it's perihelion rather than perisol, perigee rather than periterr, and pericynthion rather than perilune. So for Jupiter I'd expect it to be something like perizeon.

The prefix is also used to refer to the planet's orbit around the Sun. For example, the prefix terra means "earth" in Latin. So Jupiter would be terranus. The suffix -ion is used for the orbit of a planet around its parent star. Jupiter's orbital period is about 4.5 years, and its distance from the star is roughly 1.3 AU.
. The Greek prefix -ios means the "sun" or "moon" and is usually associated with a constellation. In this case, Jupiter is the constellation of Leo. It's also the Latin name for Leo the Lion. Leo is a Greek god of war and the sun. He's the patron of soldiers, sailors, hunters, fishermen, farmers, travelers, lovers, warriors, poets, musicians, philosophers, astronomers, astrologers, magicians, priests, monks, mystics, healers and philosophers. His name is derived from a word meaning "light" (leos) and "star" -ioi. Leo's name was also derived by the same Greek word, meaning the light of heaven. This is why the Roman god Jupiter was called Leo, because he was the god who was "the light" of all the heavens.

text:
Here is a way to get the commericial companies into space and mineral exploration. Basically get the eci freaks to make it so hard to get the minerals on earth.. You think this is crazy. Well in a way it is, but in a way it is reality. There is a billin the congress to do just that.. Basically to make it so expensive to mine minerals in the US, unless you can by off the inspectors or tax collectors.. ascially what I understand from talking to a few miner friends of mine, that they the congress propose to have a tax on the gross income of the mine, versus the adjusted income, also the state governments have there normal taxes. So if you are a miner and you make $100,000 a year, you would pay $1,500 in taxes, and if the miner is making $50,00 a week, he would only pay a $500 tax. The other thing is that the mining companies would have to pay for the space station, the rocket, etc.. So the miners would be paying for all of this. And the companies that are mining the earth would also be getting a cut of that. But the big companies, like the ones that make the most money, would get a big cut.

So the way this works is the government would give the company a loan, say $10 billion, to build the station. Then the corporation would take the money and pay off all the interest on it. They would then pay the taxes on that money. Now the corporations would not be able to use the tax money to buy the mineral rights, they would just pay it off. This is how the system works. It is not a free market. You can't just go out and buy a piece of land and then go and mine it and sell it to the people. That is illegal. If you want to go to space, then you have got to be a company. I think that is what is going on. We are not going to see a lot of mining in space. In fact, I would say that mining is probably not even going into the future.

text:
Ron Miller is a space artist with a long and distinguished career. I've admired both his paintings remember the USPS Solar System Exploration Stamps last year? and his writings on the history of spaceflight. For several years he's been working on a big project which is almost ready to hit the streets.

The project is called "The Space Station" and it's a massive, multi-million dollar project to build a giant, permanent space station. The station will be a huge, floating structure that will house a crew of astronauts and a variety of other space-related equipment. It will also be home to a number of scientific experiments and research facilities. This is the first time that a large, permanently-occupied space facility has been built in the United States. And it will have a lot of people working there.


Miller's work is very much in line with the themes of the project. He's using the imagery of a station as a metaphor for the human condition. In his work, the station is seen as an extension of our own bodies. We are all connected to the space around us. Miller's paintings are a way of showing us that we are connected, and that our bodies are part of this vast, vast universe. They are also a reminder of how much we have to learn about ourselves.

text:
stuff deleted You mean like seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, years... Remember, the Fahrenheit temperature scale is also a centigrade scale. So, if you're talking about a temperature of -40 degrees Fahrenheit, that's a -4 degree Fahrenheit difference.

The Fahrenheit scale was invented by the British in 1859. It was used to measure the temperature in the atmosphere. The Fahrenheit system was based on the fact that the air is warmer at higher altitudes. This is why the Earth is round. At the top of the world, it's colder than it is at the bottom of a lake. But at sea level, there's no difference between the two. In fact, at -400 degrees, you can see the difference in temperature between a hot and a cold day. And at that temperature, a person would be able to feel the heat of their body. That's why it was called the "Fahrenheit scale."

text:
You should have been following the discussion of GRBs going on in sci.astro. It's been discussed in some detail, with references even. I'm not sure if you've read it, but it's a very good article.

I'm going to try to summarize it here, and I'll try not to get too technical. The basic idea is that the GRB is a pulsar, which is an extremely dense object that emits a beam of radio waves. These waves are then picked up by a telescope, where they are converted into a radio signal. This signal is then sent to a receiver, who can then pick up the radio wave and convert it into an image. In the case of a GRBM, the signal comes from a supermassive black hole, so the image is actually a picture of the black holes. So, in the end, we get a composite image of all the objects in our galaxy. We can see the stars, galaxies, nebulae, etc. in this image, as well as the supernova remnant. And, of course, it is possible to see all of these objects, even if they're not visible to the naked eye. But, if we can't see them, then we have to make a guess. If we know the distance to an object, or the mass of an individual object in a galaxy, that can be used to estimate the size of that object. Here are some selected excerpts of the invitation registration form they sent me. Retyped without permission, all typo's are mine. Low Cost Lunar Access A one day conference to explore the means and benefits of a rejuvenated human lunar program. Friday, May 7, 1993 Hyatt Regency Crystal City Hotel Arlington, VA ABOUT THE CONFERENCE The Low Cost Lunar Access conference will be a forum for the exchange of ideas on how to initiate and structure an affordable human lunar program. The conference is being organized by the Lunar Exploration Institute (LEI) and the National Space Society (NSS). The purpose of this conference, as stated in the program, is to "explore the feasibility of an inexpensive human Lunar program." The program is designed to be an opportunity for participants to exchange ideas and to discuss the issues that will determine the future of human space exploration. Participants will have the opportunity to meet with representatives of NASA, the U.S. Air Force, and other space agencies. They will also have an open forum to share their ideas with other participants. This conference has been designed as a one-day event, but will continue to evolve as the conference progresses. It is anticipated that the first session will take place on Friday May 6, at the Hyattsville Marriott Hotel in Arlington. Registration is now open. Please contact the LEI at (202) 693-8500 or the NSS at nss@nss.org for more information.

This is a very important result, because it means that we are moving away from the Big Bang. If we were moving towards the big bang, we would have to be moving faster than the speed of light. So, if we're moving at the same speed as the universe, then we must be accelerating away. We can't be speeding up, so we have a new problem. But, it is still a good result.

Many of you at this point have seen a copy of the Lunar Resources Data Purchase Act by now. This bill, also known as the Back to the Moon bill, would authorize the U.S. government to purchase lunar science data from private and non profit vendors, selected on the basis of competitive bidding, with an aggregate cap on bid awards of 65 million. If you have a copy of the bill, and can't or don't want to go through all of the legalese contained in all Federal legislation,don't both you have a free resource to evaluate the bill for you. Your local congressional office, listed in the phone book,is staffed by people who can forward a copy of the bill to legal experts. The bill is available on a variety of websites, including the Congressional Research Service, the Library of Congress, or the National Archives.

The bill would also authorize NASA to develop a plan to return to lunar orbit by the mid-2030s. It would require NASA's Space Launch System rocket to be capable of returning to low Earth orbit within the next decade. NASA would have to submit a detailed plan for how it would accomplish this by 2033. In addition, NASA could use the funds to establish a Lunar Exploration Program, which would include a lunar landing mission. These are the two major goals of this bill. I'll discuss the other two goals in a moment. First, however, I want you to know that the legislation is not a "do-nothing" bill; it is a bill that would provide a path forward for NASA.
