text:
I haven't seen any mention of this in a while, so here goes... When the Hubble Telescope was first deployed, one of its high gain antennas was not able to be moved across its full range of motion. It was suspected that it had been snagged on a cable or something. Operational procedures were modified to work around the problem, and later problems have overshadowed the HGA problem. The problem is that the telescope is not designed to move. This is a problem that has been known for a long time, but it was never fixed.

The problem was that Hubble's mirror is made of a very thin material, which is very light. When it is moved, the mirror will be pulled back and forth, causing the light to scatter. If the mirrors were made thicker, they would be able move more freely. However, this would require a lot of extra power, as the telescopes are designed for the maximum amount of light they can receive. So, it has always been assumed that if the optics were thicker they could move freely, even though this is simply not true. In fact, Hubble is the only telescope that is designed specifically to receive light from the universe. As a result, its mirrors are very thick, making them very difficult to shift. They are also very heavy, weighing in at over a ton. Even if they were able, moving the entire telescope would take a huge amount more power than it would need. And, of course, if it were to happen, there would have to have been a way to get the power to the other telescopes. That is, unless the whole thing was a hoax.

That would then be attached by a string to another piece, which would in turn be connected to an object that was floating in a different part in orbit. In this way, the two pieces would move together. If the string were to break, then the pieces could be pulled apart. They would still be floating, but they would not be in contact with each other. Also, if the object were in an orbit that had a very low inclination, it would take a long time for the objects to move apart, so the whole thing would look like it was moving very slowly.

text:
Depends. If you assume the existance of a working SSTO like DC, on billion would be enough to put about a quarter million pounds of stuff on the moon. If some of that mass went to send equipment to make LOX for the transfer vehicle, you could send a lot more. Either way, its a lot more than needed.

The other thing is that the amount of mass needed to get to the Moon is not the same as the mass required to bring the payload to it. The payload is the total mass of the spacecraft, and the propellant is what makes it go. So if you want to go to Mars, the rocket is going to be a little bit bigger than the cargo. But if the Mars mission is a one-way trip, then the fuel is just going into the engine. And if it's a two- or three-day trip to a Mars orbit, it will be the exact same amount. It's just the ratio of propellants that is different. That's why the Apollo missions were so big. They had a big payload, but they had to use a smaller rocket.

prompt: Well, first you work out how much cold gas you need, then make the tanks big enough. Working out how much cold gas is another problem, depending on vehicle configuration, flight duration, thruster Isp which couples into storage pressure, which may be a factor in selecting tank wall thickness etc.
text:
Well, first you work out how much cold gas you need, then make the tanks big enough. Working out how much cold gas is another problem, depending on vehicle configuration, flight duration, thruster Isp which couples into storage pressure, which may be a factor in selecting tank wall thickness etc.

The tank size is also a problem. The tank is a very large volume, so the tank must be large enough to hold the cold gases. This is where the "tank wall" comes in. A tank with a wall of 1mm is not big, but a tank of 2mm wall is big. So, the wall must have a thickness of at least 2.5mm. If the walls are too thin, you will have too much gas in the system, and the pressure will be too low. You will also have to add a lot of cold air to the air inlet, to keep the temperature in check. In the case of a small tank, this is easy, just add more cold water to it. But, if the size of the gas tank and tank walls is too large, it will not be able to store enough cold gasses. And, in case you have more than one tank in your system (like a multi-tank system), you may have problems with the hot gas leaking out of one of them. It is better to have one large tank for the main tank (the one that will hold all the gass), and one smaller tank to house the other tanks.


So, how do you decide on the thickness? Well, there are two ways. One is to use a calculator, or to measure the volume of your tank. Another way is by using a caliper. I use the calipers, because they are easy

prompt: Joint Press release ESA UN No 18 93 Paris, 19 April 1993 UN ESA joint training course on satellite applications to be held in Italy, 19 30 April The United Nations and the European Space Agency ESA are jointly organising a training course on the applications of satellite data gathered by the European Remote Sensing Satellite ERS 1 , to be held in Frascati, Italy, from 19 to 30 April. The training course will discuss the applications of satellite data concerning natural resources, renewable energy and the environment. The training course, organised for the benefit of francophone African experts, will be hosted by ESRIN, the European Space Agency's establishment in Frascati, which is responsible for coordination with the users of data from ESA's remote sensing satellite. Twenty four experts in the field of remote sensing, selected from 19 francophone countries from northern, western and central Africa, and three regional African centres, will attend the two week session.
text:
Joint Press release ESA UN No 18 93 Paris, 19 April 1993 UN ESA joint training course on satellite applications to be held in Italy, 19 30 April The United Nations and the European Space Agency ESA are jointly organising a training course on the applications of satellite data gathered by the European Remote Sensing Satellite ERS 1, to be held in Frascati, Italy, from 19 to 30 April. The training course will discuss the applications of satellite data concerning natural resources, renewable energy and the environment. The training course, organised for the benefit of francophone African experts, will be hosted by ESRIN, the European Space Agency's establishment in Frascati, which is responsible for coordination with the users of data from ESA's remote sensing satellite. Twenty four experts in the field of remote sensing, selected from 19 francophone countries from northern, western and central Africa, and three regional African centres, will attend the two week session. This is the first time that the training programme has been organised by ESA. It is expected that this will become a regular programme. ESA is also organising an international conference on remote sensor applications in Africa. A number of experts from the African countries will participate in this conference. In addition, ESA will host a workshop on "The Future of Remote Sensor Applications in African Countries" in Rome, on 19 May 1993.

ESA's Remote sensing Satellite Programmes
...
,
The European Union's Space Programme is a major contributor to the development of the space industry in Europe. Since its inception in 1958, it has provided more than €1 billion in funding to ESA and its Member States. More than 80% of this funding has gone to satellite programmes. These programmes include the launch of more satellites than any other single programme in history, including the Galileo satellite, Galileo navigation system, Earth observation satellites, meteorological satellites and Earth science satellites.


In addition to these programmes, there are a number that are of particular interest to Europe, such as the Space Shuttle programme, Space Station, European Satellite Constellation, Europe's Galileo network, EUSAT, SES, Arianespace, Astrium, Ariane, Soyuz, Vega, Progress, Proton, Thales Alenia Space, LISA, Cryogenic and CryoSat.

text: Ocean Reconnaissance Launch Surprises West Space News, April 5 11, 1993, p.2 Excerpts Russia launched its first ocean reconnaissance satellite in 26 months March 30, confounding Western analysts who had proclaimed the program dead. The Itar TASS news agency announced the launch of Cosmos 2238 from Plesetsk Cosmodrome, but provided little description of the payload's mission. However, based on the satellite's trajectory, Western observers identified it as a military spacecraft designed to monitor electronic emissions from foreign naval ships in order to track their movement. Geoff Perry of the Kettering Group in England... said Western observers had concluded that no more would be launched. "The Russians have been very careful about what they have done," he said. He said the Russians had been "very careful" about the Cosmos program, which was supposed to be a test of a new satellite-launching system. But he added that the system had failed to work properly. Perry said that he had seen no evidence that Cosmos had malfunctioned. In a statement, the Russian space agency said it had launched Cosmos to study the effects of space weather on naval vessels. Cosmos was launched from the Pleskoe-Kamchatsky Cosmonaut Training Center in the city of Krasnoyarsk, in southern Russia. It was the first time a Russian satellite had flown from a space center. A Russian military spokesman said Cosmos would monitor the "effects of cosmic radiation" on ships. According to the statement from Roscosmos, Cosmos will be used to "study the effect of electromagnetic radiation on military ships." The statement said Roskosmos had planned to launch the spacecraft in April, and that it would have a "long-term" mission of monitoring the electromagnetic environment. Rosko said he could not comment on whether the mission would continue. Western experts said they were surprised by the timing of Roskomos' announcement. They said there was no reason to believe that a failure of this type of satellite would not have occurred in March. Some observers said a launch in early March would make sense, given the fact that Russia had just completed a series of tests

I have a question about the "aircraft grade" bolts. They are not. The bolts are made of steel, and are rated for the weight of the aircraft. There is no such thing as "Aircraft Grade" bolt, it is just a term used to describe the strength of a bolt that is used in a particular aircraft, not the bolt itself.


The bolts used on the F-16 are the same as those used for F/A-18s. These are "standard" aircraft bolts, which are used by all aircraft manufacturers. This is not to say that they are better, just that the standard bolts have been used since the beginning of aircraft manufacturing. It is the quality of these bolts that makes them so popular. In fact, the only reason that these are so widely used is because they have the highest strength rating of any bolt in the world. That is why they can be used with the best of them.

If you want to go to the moon, you have to have the ability to fly to it, but you don' have that ability if you go all the way to Mars. So, I think it's a bit of an oversimplification to say that you could go from Earth to a moon and back. It's not that simple.


You could, however, go a long way from a planet to an asteroid, which is what I was thinking about. But I can't see how you would do it. There's no way you'll be in orbit around the asteroid. And you might be on the surface of the planet, so you wouldn't be orbiting it at all. That's the problem. Even if it were possible, it would be very expensive. A lot more expensive than a Mars probe. text:
If you've got a good propulsion system that's not useful for deceleration, sure you can use chemical rockets for that part... but even just doing the deceleration chemically is a major headache. We're talking seriously high cruising velocities taking the velocity down nearly to zero for a Pluto orbit isn't easy with chemical fuels. Incidentally, solar sails are not going to be suitable as the acceleration system for something like this. They don't go anywhere quickly.

The other problem is that the solar sail is going nowhere fast. It's going at a constant speed, and it's only going so fast that it can't get away from the Sun. The Sun is so bright that even a small solar flare can be enough to make the sail burn up. So the only way to get the spacecraft to go fast enough is to use a nuclear rocket. Kepler's idea was that the planet Mercury orbits the sun in a way that is similar to the way the Earth orbits Earth. The Earth is the only planet in the solar system that orbits in such a manner. This is because the planets are not perfectly circular, but rather elliptical. In other words, the orbits of the other planets in our solar systems are elliptic. text:
From another space forum When workers at the Kennedy Space Center disassembled the STS 56 solid rocket boosters they were surprised to find a pair of pliers lodged into the outside base of the right hand SRB. The tool survived the trip from the launch pad up to approximately a 250,000 foot altitude, then down to splashdown and towing back to KSC. NASA spokesperson Lisa Malone told the media, It's been a long time since something like this happened. We've lost washers and bolts before but never a tool like this. It was a very rare occurrence.

The tool was found by a maintenance worker who was cleaning the SRBs after the first flight of ST S-56. He was surprised when he found the tool in the base. "I was just cleaning them and I was looking at them, and then I saw the plier sticking out," he said. Malone said the tools are not used for anything other than cleaning. She said they are used to remove the screws and nuts that hold the boosters together. They are also used in a few other ways. For example, they can be used as a hammer to break off the top of a booster.

The solid motors are typically made of a mixture of Aluminum and Carbon. Aluminum is a good conductor of heat and is very strong. Carbon is also a very good conductive material. However, they are not very efficient. In fact, solid propellent motors can only achieve a maximum acceleration of about 1.5 g's. That is, a solid booster motor can accelerate a payload of 1 kg to about 2.2 g. A solid solid-propellant motor is about twice as efficient as a booster. So, if you want to accelerate your payload to a speed of 2 g, you need a rocket with a thrust of at least 2,000 kg's (3,500 lb's).

text:
But I believe that there is a fundamental difference here. The other x three instruments are focusing instruments, that, more or less, form an image, so positional errors are limited by craft attitude and the resolving power of the optics. BATSE is an altogether different beast, effectively just 8 coincidence counters, one on each corner of the craft. Positional information is triangulated from the differential signal arrival times at each of the detectors. This is the basis of a very sophisticated system of calibration and correction.

The BATse system is not a simple one. It is based on a complex system that is designed to be robust and reliable. In the case of BATSe, the system has been designed and built to withstand the most extreme conditions. We have been able to test the BAT Se system in the harshest conditions imaginable, including the extreme cold of Antarctica, and we have also been successful in testing the systems in a variety of atmospheric conditions, from high pressure to low pressure. Our tests have shown that the Batse systems are robust, reliable and robustly calibrated. They are also very accurate. For example, we were able, using the same data, to calibrate the batse to within a few millimeters of its actual position. That is, it was able calibrating the position of an object that was about a meter away from it. And we did this using a single bat signal. So, in other words, BAT SE is very robust. But it is also extremely accurate, because it uses a combination of bat signals and other data. There is no single signal that can be used to precisely calibrates the instrument. All of these things combine to make the accuracy of this system very high.

text:
Called gas. The balloons were in sufficiently low orbit that they experienced some air resistance. When they were finally punctured, this preasure and the internal preasure that was needed to maintain a spherical shape against this resistance caused them to catastrophically deflated. The large silvered shards that remained were easily visible for some time before reentry, though no longer useful as a passive transponder.

The balloon was recovered by the US Navy and was used to test the new "Boeing" design. It was launched on April 15, 1962, and successfully returned to Earth on May 1, 1963. This was the first successful test of a "balloon" that could be launched from a rocket.

The Moon is a very large object, and the data collected is very small. The data from the first orbit is only about 1/10th of the total data. It is also important to note that the lunar gravity is measured in the opposite direction to that of Earth's gravity. Therefore, if you are on the surface of a planet, your gravity will be the reverse of that on Earth. For example, on Mars, gravity on a surface is the inverse of your own gravity, because you have to move to get to Mars. On the moon, however, there are no gravity sources on or near the ground, which means that your gravitational pull is always the exact opposite of what you would experience on earth. In other words, when you go to a moon base, all you need is to be on your side of it. If you were on an Earth-like planet and you wanted to go somewhere else, then you'd need a gravity source on that planet. But on another moon like the one we are visiting, no such source is available. You can't go anywhere else.
